name: PlanetSide 2
description: PlanetSide 2 is an all-out planetary war, where thousands of players battle as one across enormous continents. Utilize infantry, ground and air vehicles, and teamwork to destroy your enemies in this revolutionary first-person shooter on a massive scale.
minimum_requirements: OS: 64-bit Windows 7 or later CPU: Core i5-760 or better / AMD Phenom II X4 or better [Quad-core CPU] Memory: 6 GB RAM (64-bit) Hard Drive: 20 GB free Video Card: nVidia GeForce GTX 260 or better / Radeon HD 4850 or better
recommended_requirements: OS:64-bit Windows 7 or later Processor:Intel i7 processor or higher / AMD Phenom II X6 or higher Memory:6 GB RAM Graphics:nVidia GeForce 560 or higher / AMD HD 6870 or higher DirectX®:9.0 Hard Drive:20 GB HD space Sound:DirectX compatible Sound Card  Other Requirements:Broadband Internet connection

reviews.review_text: + Free to play.  + NOT pay to win. (Don't believe me? Ask anyone else with actual experience in the game) + Still having updates even after 2+ years + Small and large battles everywhere + Hundreds of bases on 4 different huge maps + Very freindly and helpful community compared to most other fps + Infinite gameplay opportunities + Infinite loadouts on 5 different infantry classes + Infinite loadouts on 7 different ground vehicles + Infinite loadouts on 6 different air vehicles + HUGE map and gameplay update  coming soon in 2016  out!  - Slightly buggy. - Steep learning curve (I suggest asking for help on reddit and finding noob freindly squads early on)  = Once you get good at it it's the best fps ever made. 10/10

I'm running around the point with the platoon as a combat medic, and see my teammates going down left and right. I put down the shield regeneration bubble to recover my teammate's shields up and I start reviving my teammates. Also our engineers are supplying our teammates in the front. We all know that we're in a pich and that we need immediately some help. I see several friendly inflantrators sniping down enemies from behind, which is pretty much helping us a lot, but not nearly enough. Then I hear something beautiful behind us and from the Platoon chat. Our max crash is coming, and it's going to push the enemies back by a bit. We might be able to turn this war upside down for now.   This game... It's a fantastic game, especially if you are in a platoon with people who know their stuff and know how to give and listen to orders. It's basically a neverending war in a huge zone, where you capture areas and with some main areas, you will gain bonuses for your faction.    Once a faction is getting together and making up plans, strategies and orders, this game is an incredible game. It's not just a basic futuristic battlefield, but it's something where you really need and want people to stick together and fight together.   I know several friends though, who love to play this game alone than in a platoon. I don't myself see the interest in that, but I guess it will give you more freedom. I just myself love to move in a huge mass with other people, always managing to make people push back and supporting my teammates with either ammo or heal.   When the game was still pretty new (in the first year of it's publishment), it was poorly optimized and gaining certs (which is the free in-game currency) was nearly impossible and a long process. Now though, the game works much better and certs are easier to get, turning the game not to be so pay-to-win anymore. Sure, you need 1000 certs for a gun, but the first guns you're using is pretty much as good as the guns you can only buy with SC.   This game seriously is a must-to-try. It's an interesting game and really has some decent graphics and an amazing gameplay. When I stopped playing this game because of my low FPS, I felt like always coming back, but never being able to. But now, after getting a new computer, I'm running on semi-stable 60fps, even in huge fights. There still are some minor bugs and minus sides, but those don't really affect the gameplay that much. Only sometimes, but not usually.  9/10, you should try this out, even if you're not into huge battlefield games.

The game that puts the 'Massive' in MMO, PlanetSide 2's scale is simply unmatched by any other game in the market. Despite having a rather long grind in order to get the items you want, the game's good teamwork based gameplay makes it a thoroughly enjoyable game for any FPS fan.

This game is dope. hands down best MMOFPS, and personally my fav FPS.  **Pay-to-Win elements? Sure...** (See below)  Is paying, to be competitive, mandatory? Lol no.  Money doesnt buy skill and I've taken down many a ~insert name here~ without spending a dime on this game  Shotgun light assault trooper and going behind enemy lines can prove how much money doesn't help.  Your 'Credit-Card-loaded-Tank' still has nothing on my hard earned packs of C4 and my Death-from-Above-Jetpack.  *Phwmb Phwmb* *Click* *BOOM* = Free ^placing c4^  P.S. ignore my steam hours as i play through planetside 2's own launcher, not steam   as for a real review.  Pros.  Free + Fun + Intense+ Awesome+ Lots of different combat scenarios. Tanks, Aircraft, Infantry, Bases, Loadouts, Large... LARGE maps, And all that mixed on different scales. sometimes you will get into 1v1 combat, sometimes 6v20, sometimes 400 v 400, sometimes 1 v 400, sometimes sniper wars, you name it.  Cons.  A powerful PC is reccomended though not mandatory. - No Helicopters =( - ^I can understand why there are no Helicopters. but they would still be cool   **As has been pointed out. This game isn't P2W. Yes you can use money to buy guns, perks, attachments, customization and other small things. All items that can boost stats can be earned in game without any RL money. Money is more of a 'shortcut' to some things. Though any moderate gamer would be able to earn even the most expensive items in just a day or two. Hardcore PS2 gamers can probably earn them faster. You will never play this game and feel like you were only beaten because he spends money and you didnt. unlike some games I will not mention... ArcheAge.
When you can't afford Arma 3 so you gotta improvise

This game has a lot of potential, but unfortunately it has a lot of what the devs refer to as 'Quality of Life' issues.  First off, here's what the game does right. There's an incredible amount of diversity in what you can do. For infantry, there's a ton of class diversity. Infiltrators can snipe or make good usage of their cloak and SMGs to get up close and personal with the enemy. Light assaults can fly up buildings and take advantage of people's lack of situational awareness to rain C4 on them. Heavy assaults can wreck havoc with enemy vehicles and other infantry, and you also have medics and engineers which perform about as they do in other games. Infantry combat is great, and while it does need some tweaks, it's overall pretty balanced. Then there are ground vehicles, one specific tank to each empire, an all purpose 1 man vehicle, armed buggies, ATVs, troop tranports, and each empire with it's own flavor of weaponry. Again, some small balance issues, but things are largely balanced. Flying in this game is a bit different than others, and while it doesn't take long to get the hang of it, mastering it is fairly difficult. If you can get it down, though, it's easily the best way to make your presence known among your enemies. Again, there are balance issues, especially between the 3 types of combat (Infantry / Ground / Air), but overall the weapons feel pretty good and once you've learned the various quirks the game has it can be a real blast.  The bad. This game uses client side hit detection, which is not bad in and of itself, but when you combine that with any degree of latency and the game's low time to kill for most weapons, you can often be dead before you are even informed that you are under attack. This can make getting into the game extremely frustrating, as you often die before you even know what's happening. Vehicles can be an utter nightmare to infantry, even infantry equipped to fight them, as most vehicle AI weapons kill infantry so fast that you don't even have time to aim a weapon, much less charge or lock a target. But as a vehicle, if a single infantry gets near you and manages to put C4 on you, it's pretty much game over. In short, everything feels like a glass cannon, Spawn times are so short that people you have killed can be back in the fight and shooting at you before your own shields have even started to regenerate. Killing someone just doesn't feel effective because they're just going to be right back before you can even think twice about them. Logistics and tactics in the game are becoming less and less necessary as you can immediately deploy to any base that is being captured. There are vehicles in the game specifically designed to transport squads, but they're useless for those purposes because they just aren't needed.  But my main reason for not recommending this game is not gameplay design, but what the develoeprs refer to as 'Quality of life' issues. Multiple bugs are introduced with every patch, and many of them go for months upon months without seeing a fix, if they ever see a fix. The game honestly ran smoother for me in beta than it does now, despite my computer being vastly more powerful and having fewer people to render. Around March of 2014, they introduced a hit detection bug which causes anywhere between 50%-80% of my shots to do no damage, even though their server 'verifies' each hit as part of it's anti-cheat measures. Myself and several dozen other players have been reporting this and done everything we can to get the devs' attentions, but as of yet it has seen no fix, or even an acknowledgement that it's being looked into. Try playing a game where you have to land twice as many shots as your opponent does to accomplish the same effect. It's not fun.   In August, a bug was introduced that caused people leaving vehicles to be ejected into the air, often falling to their deaths. It's hilarious, sure, but imagine playing that way for more than a night. We're more than halfway through October, and there's no fix for it. It had been reported on their test servers for more than 2 weeks before the patch with the bug went live.   These are just two issues when each patch introduces a dozen more, often the same ones that then get hotfixed a week or two later as if the devs forgot to make it a part of the standard release. Patches recently have implemented half finished resource systems, altered UI elements that made upgrading things more difficult, or changed small notifications about being in a queue to take up 10% of your screen and contain less information with broken buttons. For the UI, it's like they have people changing things for no good reason without any overarching design in mind when the things already there are doing a perfectly good job. Month after month goes by with changes that are supposedly being worked on not being released, in favor of seasonal content which most players find frustrating or annoying.  As a side note, twitter and reddit are your best bets for information about the game and reporting bugs to developers. The official forums are lucky to even get patch notes.  So in short, the game has a ton of potential and offers a wide variety of combat that can be a lot of fun. Give it a shot if you want, it's free. Unfortunately, it's in the hands of people who don't understand basic concepts like not pushing out a patch that contains game breaking bugs.  Edit as of 9/10/2015: All of the bugs I complained about are still in game in some form or another, along with tons of new ones, over a year later. Avoid this game if you want a quality experience.

DON'T BE DISCOURAGED! I'm not going to cover what is good and bad about the game, since I'm sure it's already been done thousands of times and you can see another review for that information. I'M going to make something very clear and give you a warning. When you first start playing this game, you'll feel completely out-classed. You will die a lot, you will be confused often, and sometimes you just won't know what to do. However, at the same time, it will be an awesome experience. This game's trailers speak the truth. There are lots of players of all classes waging war against the enemy. Aircraft of all kinds will be constantly flying overhead, chasing each other in dog fights and strafing the battlefield. There will be tanks and Armored Personnel Carriers dotted throughout the escalating battles.  And while it's a cool spectacle, you will be understandably overwhelmed. 'Where is the objective? What do I do when I get there? Where is my team? Where is the enemy? Why does the announcer keep saying random stuff??? AAAHHH!'  So I - being a fellow noob - am here to give you some advice. You have to focus on one thing at a time. Yes, it's ok to take the scenery and the battle into spectacle appreciation, but don't let it crowd your focus. Listen very carefully to everything the announcer is saying. Take a minute or two to collect yourself. Ask yourself a couple things before charging into battle: 'What is the objective?' 'What is the lay of the land?' 'Is my Team's offensive large enough?' 'What kind of support do they need / how can I help?'  Next, you should try every aspect of combat. Do you want to specialize in ground combat, air combat, or heavy armor? And just because you aren't doing as good as you had hoped, don't get discouraged. EVERYTHING in Planetside 2 takes time to get good at. I for example, decided that I'm very good at a supportive role on the ground and in the air. On the ground, I'm an engineer, making sure all the tanks and other vehicles are in tip-top shape, and that every soldier has ammunition spilling out of their pockets. Or even placing turrets to provide suppressing fire. In the air, I transport troops and other much-needed reinforcements to the field of battle, and that has been one of the deciding factors in battles more than once for me.  The point is, you need to find some way that you can contribute and make a difference in the battle. But if you let your focus get away from you, you'll develop this mindset of 'charging and randomly firing will work' And that is a bad habit. You'll always die like that. You aren't just another player. If by the time you stop playing for the day, you can confidently say: 'I made a difference' Then you're doing it right.   Now get out there! The continents won't conquer themselves! You need to help!

You'll hear a lot of complaints about this game: that it's not very newbie friendly, that it's full of casuals, that there are a lot of things to learn, that the shooting is difficult due a combination of recoil and long time to kill, that it feels pointless due to a lack of story and reards, that it's demanding on hardware, and that the graphics aren't anything special. All these complaints are, to some greater or lesser extent, true, but I still love this game. The scale is like nothing else I've ever seen: this is a pure PvP shooter where the server is an entire planet with thousands of players rather than a single battlefield with a few dozen players at most. Infantry, ground vehicle, and air vehicle combat are all seamlessly integrated with one another. It's free, and it's perfectly viable and enjoyable to play without ever paying a cent. It has a broad and very helpful internet subculture around it. There are three different factions to choose from, alike enough that skills learned in one faction will be useful in another but different enough that there are clear pros and cons to each. I recommend everyone give this game a chance. It's free, it does a lot of things well, and there is nothing else like it.

Amazing game. The surface game is easy to get into - jump into a battle with instant action and just fight until you get bored. However, since I've played since day 1 of the launch, I have to say I LOVE this game. it's in my top 5. I have sunk actual money into it and don't regret a single penny.   Constantly being updated, with a team who may not be the greatest at making decisions but who excel at relating and communicating with the community. Especially developer Wrel, who livestreams the game often, and posts in the /r/planetside subreddit on reddit - along with many other developers.  Creating and managing outfits of hundreds of soldiers, getting a group of 50 people to cooperate enough to get a squad of tanks to form a column of death, fleets of aircraft flying overhead as you fire off into the middle distance. I love this game. I play on both Connery and Emerald in all factions, so message me if you ever need a friend.  Cannot recommend this game enough. 11/10

WARNING: While the minimum system requirements are reasonable, this game is HORRIBLY unoptimized. That being said, if you have a decent GPU this will be one of the best looking games you can play.  The basic idea is fairly uncreative and boring: Three factions fight endelessly to control the four continents of Auraxis.  The GAMEPLAY, on the other hand, can be glorious. Imagine an entire army of bombers and gunships descending upon the unsuspecting enemy base, launch troops with jetpacks, mech suits, and all manner of explosizes and shooty things. The enemy reacts with AA guns and tanks firing skyward, but are ultimately defeated.  So then what?  Well, here's where my critisisms come in. The objectives are so watered down that there is no real reason to do anything. 'PROTECT ______ TECH PLANT!' 'Why?' 'I don't know, this game has no backstory, plot, NPCs, or any sense of life to it, so go shoot things to earn monies!'  'What do I do with my monies?' Well, first of all, you're going to have to accept that experienced players will rekt you, not necessarily because they are more skillful (although that is almost always true), but because more certs (monies) = more advanced armor, weapons, grenades (which noobs don't get at all), and flashy neon camo patterns (which increase your coolness by -300%).  So if it's F2P, it's P2W, right? No. Strangely, while there is a definite advantage given to more experienced players, this game isn't really about 'winning' since no one every really wins. What it's about is getting on voice chat with some friends, going out in a Sunderer, and rekt-ing the New Conglomerate. This game is NOT about story, adventure, conquest, or COD of Duty. It's about jumping from one gunship to another 600 feet above the Warpgate.  And that is why I'd recommend it.

Excellent Free MMOFPS. The developers work really hard at keeping the content entertaining by keeping in touch with their base. You can play the game based on your playstyle. It does take a little bit of time getting familiar with the game, but once you do it's quite addicting. I would say the Battlefield games are the most comparable.  I would recommend having a decent computer to run game, at least an offboard graphics card at the least.

SoE had a clear goal in mind with Planetside 2: the same game with prettier graphics and more accessibility. In both regards, it's a success. The massive war atmosphere is there. Let's hope that it will evolve in order to trump a possible weariness of the basic war mechanics with new stuff and a storytelling element that writer Marv Wolfman could contribute.  70/100

I honestly can't reccomend this game to the average player. It's very difficult to pull off a MMOFPS like this well, and unfortunately Daybreak falls somewhat short of the bar. In short, this game is ahead of its time. The graphics and sheer amount of activity (there's several hundred players on a given continent at any time, and each continent is similar in size to the Oblivion world) cause many players to be forced to play at minimum resolution and graphics settings, which for an FPS is detrimental because it becomes difficult to aim at distant targets. In addition, the servers frequently lag, you rarely feel as though you're accomplishing anything, and battles for control of an area (especially biospheres and tech centers) can take hours. There are no 'bot games' to play to get used to things- you are given a basic controls tutorial for your chosen faction and then dumped into the game immediately. For new players, this can be incredibly overwhelming. Throw in the fact that colors are somewhat muted and NC and TR armor looks similar at a distance, as well as friendly fire being on, and you get a huge cluster♥♥♥♥ everywhere there's fighting. It's hard to tell if you're 'winning', because there's no objectives other than 'capture this area' which can be completed by any faction at any time, provided an area is adjacent to one of their controlled areas. In summary: Too graphics intensive for most players, no sense of accomplishment, no adequate preparation for newbies, and no clear objectives other than 'kill everything that moves that isn't [insert team color here].

Solid game, being a FPS more along the lines of the Battlefield franchise, rather than the original Planetside. This is a squad based shooter, and you'll almost always have more fun in a squad. I recommend joining an outfit, and finding some people you like to play with.

Note this review is very strict :P .  Planetside 2 review  I USED to like the game , now I dont. I stopped playing about 3 months since March 2014 and came back during the Hossin Continent update, in hopes of a more fun and balanced gameplay. But it dissapointed me on so many levels. I was rusty when I came back but none the less I still remember the core mechanics and how to point and shoot. I played a few hours and died a lot, but its was to be expected after 3 months of leaving the game. About 15 hours in and not only my PPH (points per hour) was still drop to a measely 500/hr but my kill death ratio per game was more or less 0.2 to 0.1, not that I'm complaining since I'm an objective based player, but there is a lot of scenarios that I would have gotten a kill and survived with heavy injuries, but still alive before this update rolled out.  The changes are noticeble, infantry shield and hp was lowered , especially noticeble on the MAX suits , weapon damage was also changed for some of them. Some of the utility or special abilities of the class was changed in term of drain/ cooldown/ effect/ power , making a significant improvement in 1 of the classes but a significant drawback for the other. Graphics wise, it still looks the same but something has been change and is eating up my pc's power. Vehicles have been change as well and their weapons as well, mostly buffed. The point system is overall the same , that or slightly better. The deathcam has been improve I guess , but only slightly. The Hossin map is still under testing phase so the constant infantry and vehicles stuck are neglible and the map itself is good , thought that area lacks people playing. The teamwork of the game have mostly been lost , and objective based gameplay is pretty non-existent , most players now just care about their kill death ratio. The factions itself is now very unbalnced as well , it was about 30% TR , 30% NC , 40% VS when I last played , now its around 60% TR 30% NC and 10% VS. Now right now I maybe sound like some VS supporter, but mind you I play as all 3 factions and my favourite is TR because of their increased firerate and magazine size. But now the factions dominance is so unbalanced it's almost impossible for other minority to recover some of their bases. TR can fight on 3 front of the continent and win 2 of them, while the rest fight on the remaining continent barely making progress. As usual SOE still kept their currency at a decent price not too high and not too low. But the charge for most of the in game item is still expensive and the progress of getting cert ( the games earnable currency ) is still very bad grinding no matter how good you are.   This is what gets me now, for all games I review based on 10 main things, the New user experience, the casual player experience, the experienced player experience, music , art style (or graphics) , price ( in this case in game microtransation items ) , progress (if the game has any) , its main theme ( multiplayer , single player , story telling , etc ) , its community , and last but not least , the MOST important thing for games, whether you are satisfied playing the game or completely hated it or mutual ( short version : fun or not).  New user (1 to 10 lvls) : Worst than before, the shield and hp system is very weak for the new user and hence they will die a lot faster and their starter weapons are not as good as they used to be.  Casual players (5 to 40 lvls) : Overall not much has changed based on what I seen , you can play normally without getting 1 shotted most of the time and an advantage will normally guarantee your 1v1 scenarios.  Experience players (41 and beyond) : Pretty much has all the infantry stuff mastered (not sure about vehicles ecause gameplay choices) , has very good gear that can overpower most low level enemy players and a very upgrade suit.  Music : Hasnt changed from what Iheard from the 3 factions, them songs is still the same I believe with TR a bit sadistic , VS and bit weird and alien like, and NC as um... western texas type of music. Weapons sounds have been change and is sounds much better now.  Graphics : No comment other than cant see cloaked inflitators while using low settings.  Price : Free but in game microtransactions are a tad bit high  Progress : Utterly slow at all levels unless you become a member, then you have a score system that actually means nothing when you think about it, cert gain is a pain as mentioned before ( exp 30 certs for a scope and 250 score pts to get 1 cert pts, so around 7500 score points to get just 1 scope) as for weapons, even longer as anyone would expect.  Main theme : It should be a competitive multiplayer on a very very very large scale. It does that well at the start but because of the unbalnced faction, its not like that anymore, you either win or lose with a landslide on the normal to large scale battles (not accounting for the 4v4 base atk and def, cuz that's not large scale :P)  Community : I chatted with the players in game, allies and enemies, visited the forums, overall quite good for a shooter, much much better than Call of Duty's community. The game is solid. I have about 38 hours on my steam account, but I've played the game for about 200-300 hours before it was on Steam.  It's a good game, you can check its undeniable qualities among good reviews around, but it has serious issues that still haven't been resolved after all these years.  - The faction balancing is very poor in regard of the Vanu; they are always (and it's been consistent for 3 to 4 years) more numerous than any other faction, which makes it almost impossible to win big battles against them, or even small skirmishes since they have the most veterans of the game.   (EDIT: I re-tried the game for the first time since a few months, and I fought (and died instantly) against swarms of Vanu players that had 20-30x more time in the game than me, so around 4000 gaming hours each. The game is now half empty, and the players left seem to be all lvl 2000-3000 Vanu veterans that will murder you without giving you a single chance of finding fun in the game. Just so it's clear.)  - You can't properly play solo to the game; if you're not with a considerable team, it's extremely complicated to join bigger squads for large battles on the fly, plus, there aren't really any chain of command, so orders either get lost or it's pure chaos, which can be fun util you go back to my first point: you can't win against Vanu if you don't organize your assault properly. Sure, you're gonna have some great moments if you try just to play alone, even in large scale assaults, but they're not gonna be enough to outgrow the constant frustrations.  - The F2P model isn't quite F2P. Sure you can stick to it and not spend a single penny on the game, and you should fare just OK. But it brings an even more massive problem:  - The progression is terribly slow. It's fun to fight and get points to spend in new skills, weapons, vehicles (aerial and terrestrial), upgrades for your shields, for the ammo you can carry, for the weapons of your vehicles, etc - until you realize that you need the SAME type of currency won in-game to unlock them all. You can't get said currency without playing a LOT - if you're outrageously lucky and proactive you can get up to 200-250 points in an hour of gameplay, but this is barely enough for two or three levels of any kind of upgrade, and I'm not even mentioning weapons, which can cost a few thousands and not be worthwile, or be completely unfairly strong.   You can get these points a LOT faster by paying the premium fee, plus a few other bonuses; the game isn't P2W, but considering the really, really, really useful and advantageous nature of the upgrades you can get for everything in the game, players who pay get a lot stronger a lot faster.  - Finally, my last point concerns the state of the server. It's actually pretty good, with a little twist: this is a massive scale FPS, making Battlefield look like a claustrophobic's nightmare; therefore, for the server to pick up the informations coming out of your PC, to transmit it to the server, and to do the same with every other character and object in the game, that takes a gargantuous amount of bandwidth; if your connexion isn't top notch, top tier, top whatever you want, you'll be gravely disadvantaged - a lot more than in any other FPS. In comparison, I have a pretty lousy connexion at the moment, which is new to me, but I fare just well in Rainbow Six Siege. In PS2 though, I'm barely more than a moving meatbag with a 'SHOOT ME' sign on his back.   So, TL;DR:   All in all, PlanetSide 2 is a good game. If you don't mind paying for the premium access (or if you're really patient), if you have large teams (like a guild or something like that) to play with at all time, if you're lucky on the amount of Vanu against you and if your connexion rocks, this game is a must. But without all that, it's gonna give you a hard time pretty much all the time. Try it (it's free after all), and make your own opinion on the game.

One word.... EPIC!!!  Planetside 2 offers a full range of diversity, from the run and gun to tactical stealth. I have been playing the game since release and I can say its come a long way, and is still going. The battles of 100+ players on each side: Momentus feats of accomplishment as 1 side charges an open field to take the enemy positions. Under fire bullets whizzing past your head people dropping dead left and right, but you gotta keep going gotta take that position! In the aftermath after the smoke clears you look at who made it, out of those 200+ guys you saw rushing the field a meager 75 left... and still a whole base to take. You look to your max, you charge... and in this epic moment you watch the max in his heroism fall, but you keep going the rest of you have to keep going. Finally the base is taken, the sun seems to shine once more, a buetiful sunset, but in that sunset comes another enemy... Time to bunker down! This and many more describe what kind of an adrenaline rush you get from Planetside 2, in combat it keeps you on your toes, back at base it keeps you thinking.   The only downside is the system requirements, I have a pretty solid rig after I updated my graphics card but due to only 4 gigs of ram and a factory processor that handles BF3 on ultra, I realized I'd have to update the rig even more. Planetside 2 ate all my ram, and it ate all my CPU. Leaving me loving the battles where I did not lag my way to rage heaven, extremely enjoyable, and extremely exciting.

It's alright.

Rewriting because I guess I didn't give enough justice, huh.  Planetside 2 is a massive game unlike anything you've ever played. If you ever think you've played something like it then no, you haven't. If you think you wil be automatically good when you play it, you won't. The learning curve is incredibly steep, and the fact is that skills you learn in Planetside will not transfer over to other games, simply because the game is unlike anything else.   SOE at times seems like a mindless company. Their executive decisions are questionable to say the least, but they're managed to maintain Planetside as an enjoyable experience. Its uniiqueness is what brings it most of its flavour. That's really what killed it. Your experience playing Planetside 2 will be unlike anything you've seen. Planetside 2 is like the little girl you knew growing up. She was proper and loved by everyone in Elementary and Middle School, and especially by you, but when you got to High School she all of a sudden turned into a crack♥♥♥♥♥. Playing Planetside is similar in that you become so attached to the game (If you don't quit immediately after getting dominated constantly and refusing to learn the game) and cry when you see the incompetence of the executive team and theoretically watching your true love get ♥♥♥♥♥ by a gorilla in front of you.  The FPS mechanics in this game are among the highest tier of modern FPS games. The gunplay is smooth and feels right. There are times where you'll be fun policed by zergs, vehicles, liberators, but overall infantry fights, if you ever manage to find any, are very good, And 'If you ever manage to find any' brings us to our next paragraph.  Populations are... fluctuated. I'm lucky because Connery is the biggest server in the game and that's the server I play on. You can find a fight for the most part at any time of the day. This is different from what I've read up on other servers, and from what I've experience playing on other servers. Servers such as Matherson and Waterson (East Coast) Suffer from horrible population imbalances and there's large scales of players quitting due to the lack of fights. SOE's involvement in managing population balance is... Not really there at all.  Overall, I would recommend this game, it is a very good game at its core, regardless of the pessimistic comments you hear from hierarchial players including myself. The main problem of the game is the poor executive decisions made on it. If you can get around that then you will have an amazing experience playing the game. It's truly unique and I can guarantee you will at least have 100 hours of fun playing it if you can get around the initial curve. If you can go hardcore and get 1000 hours in, congratulations, you're a masochist.

Planetside 2 is an amazing FPS game that emphasizes capturing objectives over having the best kill ratio. Definitely a recommended game for those looking for a different FPS. The MMO portion of this FPS makes it more interesting (in my opinion) than most of your standard FPS shooters at this time.  If you are looking to play, be sure to scope out the outfits that play. The game is overwhelming to start brand new by yourself and you will not get the full experience until you are playing together with a group of other players. This is not a run and gun game to be experienced by yourself. This game is a team based game that plays best with an organized group.  Do you like FPS Games? Do you like large scale combat? Do you like ground vehicle and infantry combat combined? Do you like to fly and engage both air and ground targets? Do you like progression style gameplay both in character progression and in-game objectives? Do you like free?  If any of the above appeals to you, you're doing yourself a disservice to not play this game at the price of FREE.

However, there is also a downside.  - tactics really do not come into focus unless you join an active outfit. PLEASE KNOW THAT THESE ARE MY OWN OPINIONS   I enjoy the game overall and I disagree that it is pay to win.* PROS: -Good substitute for battlefield -well made and detailed infantry combat -amazing graphics (especially for such an old game) -lots of upgrades for your weapons and vehicles -the paid-only items are cosmetic/useless items like firework launchers -a lot of people still play (the number decreases by the year sadly) -still receives updates and has holiday updates -HUGE battles (200+ players in a 2km radius) -large maps -same gameplay quality as a lot of triple A games -not early access  CONS: -VERY difficult to run without a high end setup -game is going to die out in the next couple years (from age) -takes a long time to get most weapons (about 10 hours to get enough certs for most guns) -friendly fire is on so large battles are bound to have a lot of accidental teamkills -the way the factions are balanced is wierd so new players are easily convinced that there is an 'overpowered faction' -the rendering distance for players is 800 meters for vehicles and 400 meters for infantry and you can't change it   *the reason I do not think it is pay to win is because all items are able to be bought using free currency. You may have noticed I said in the cons that it takes a long time to get a gun you want, but it's not a grind. Every time you play is an entirely different experience. It doesn't get repetitive.

Great PvP, I appreciated this style and think more games should use it, the style inspires a LOT more tactical planning and coordination than most FPS shooters these days. And an amazing feature is a playtime currency, which you keep until you log out, or spend it, making an obstacal for the annoying players that waste the vehicles in other games by doing stupid things like, wasting a vehicle on just themselves or just completely obliterating an air vehicle for just one kill. The temporary currency is also great, because it restricts the number of Maxes (The Exo-Suit Class, standard with a minigun and Heavy Grenade Launcher) that can be deployed. Although, the curreny is difficult as fudge to achieve if you want a new weapon or an expensive upgrade, it is a SERIOUS pain to grind the currency if your saving up for base unlocks too, costing 1000 for each base item unlock. Also, the character customization is severly limited, only allowing you to set your Faction and Face in the beginning, and only your Helmet, Body Armor, Decal, and Camo, which you need the buyable currency to unlock almost all of the customization gear, limiting players who can't afford currency to the devastatingly few helmets that are unlocked through ranking up. But it is still an amazingly massive scale game with different biomes and opponents that always keep you on your toes. So, in short, this game has its downs, but it is ASTOUNDING none the less.

In certain spots you can go from having really great FPS to certain areas where it can drop down to like 20 which is really frustrating. Man, I wish I could play this game on ultra settings... :/  Well its a free open world Sci-fi shooter where you have the choice to join 3 faction that are fighting each other for some unknown reason. There are 3 big maps, and the goal of the game is to conquer enemy bases to increase your factions teritory  The biggest problem with Planetside 2 (in my opinion) is the lack of lore and story behind each of the fractions and the world it self, you dont know why you are fighting the enemy and it kind of takes away the sense of faction pride and immersion   The world is big and beautiful, but yet it feels so empty, there are nothing to do beside taking over enemy bases and driving/flying around in a world of snow, a dessert world and I cant remember the last one, which becomes boring after a while.   Every faction has unique abillities and perks, which gives a good variation, so remember to look into those - and all factions have your standard FPS classes, like enginer, scout, assault and so on.   The battles are big and epic with good music to keep the fights hectic, and its especially engaging if you plan on playing it with friends or a clan/guild!  Well enough said, I recommend this game, not because I think its something amazing, but because its free, and a decent shooter at that, which may entertain you for a while or longer, maybe for a long long time? :)  Time is the only thing you have to waste here, and hey? Just be honest with yourself, you have a lot of that! :P

PlanetSide 2. There is one word which can sum up this review. Fantastic! The game's quality is simply stunning. Well think twice... the download size is huge! I literally had to wait for around 3 hours for my game to download. And once that was done, I had to go through a tutorial that had so much lag in! Its absolutely amazing! 9/10 is what I give it

I never thought it'd work. PlanetSide 2 is an MMO, it has hundreds of players living on a small amount of global servers – but it also has twitchy combat, bullets based on real physics, and the kind of vehicle fights that demand split second reactions. Few games have combined the two concepts well. The original game used behind-the-scenes number-magic that left weapons feeling toothless and combat floaty.  I find vehicle combat even more exhilarating. No game has ever made my heart beat faster than PlanetSide 2 has. I’ve spent much of my time in the air, in the exposed bubble cockpit of the Vanu Sovereighty Scythe. The Scythe - my reaper - is a speedy, one-person fighter that I’ve outfitted as an balanced aircraft, dedicated to hunting and killing enemy fliers. I’ve hurled my violet and black steed around crags, and settled in, nose-cannon blazing, behind vast enemy dropships, then escaped under base stanchions to throw off chasing air-to-air missiles.

From the stone monolith in the centre of the desert your allies rain down tracers, rockets and shells on the enemy convoys as they attempt to run the gaundlet and make their way through the desert to your base. Yet your defensive position begins to crumble beneath heavy fire, and your air superiority begins to fall away. Yet your main problem is the snipers and skirmishers which slip past stealthily the mountain you're deployed on. So you grab your carbine, a couple of frag grenades, some C4 and your trusty blade and use your jetpack to navigate into the canyon. Almost immediately you come under LMG fire, and you run past, ducking and hoping. You hide in a ridge, and pop up again. Beneath suppressing carbine fire you can take out the enemy infantry as they try to use the cover of ridges to make their way to your base. Yet at this range, none can match the T5 AMC for pin-point accuracy, and fall as soon as they enter your scope. All the while tracers fly overhead, planes launch devastating rocket salvos and your avoid tanks as they come hurtling pass. Yet for one of these tanks you make a rash decision. Breaking cover, you engage your jet pack and fly over the tank, on your way dropping your deadly package of C4. A few seconds later, you hit the button. Both you and the Magrider explode.   One of the most fun experiences you will ever have.

The only game where you can fight literally hundreds or thousands of players in truly massive battles. Expect to die a lot. That being said this is not a P2W game as must weapons can be bought with certs which are the earned resource. This game is so good I'm even willing to play it on my craptop which has a Intel Core2 duo 2.4 ghz, intel hd 3000 internal graphics, and 6gb ram shared with video chipset. This game looks amazing even on lowest detail settings and next gen on beastly machines. Just take a look at some of the videos. And yes there is VOIP but only between people of the same faction you are playing on, which is probably for the best.  There has never been a game like Planetside before that truly was able to provide such massive battles with multiple types of land and air based vehicles and have it be playable. And yes there are organized competitive events although these usually involve hundreds of people on each team because it wouldn't be planetside 2 if it didn't involve hundreds of people. The community is excellent, with a few exceptions, and it is easy peasy to mute/block anyone you don't want to talk to. And if that doesn't sit well with him and he decides to start tking you repeatedly then you've got a good reason to /report him and choose the button for Last Killer which will automatically enter the last person to kill you. He will be punished, you can trust in that.  Cheaters, harassers get banned and the /report tool is utilized not only by the players but by the devs as well. I can't remember the last time I noticed someone hacking, but I can remember the last time I saw a server msg about someone being banned for doing so. I've played this game since beta and have been running with the same outfit the whole time. 10/10 Love this game, but wished I could play in the massive battles with something more than a 15-20 FPS.

This game, Planetside 2 is hands down the best free to play game I have ever played. It is an amazingly huge game with astonishingly large landmasses and varied lands and environments to wage all out intense, thrilling, and immersing war in. You can play as one of three factions all with their own quirks. The gameplay has a lot of depth, and it may take a while to get used to. You can take control of many different kinds of vehicles. From light and agile aircrafts to strong and bulky tanks. There are three continents you will wage war over, with a total of two thousand soldiers on a server. There are no matches or loading screens, how power fluctatues is dependant on how well your team fights. Oh, did I mention the graphics for this game are simply amazing? If you're sceptical, you should just download and try this gem. It is free to play so you have nothing to lose. I don't have enough room to describe this game! Just try it!

The thing about this game is that there's nothing quite like it out there... Nowhere else will you find 300-man battles over a single facility with planes roaring overhead and tanks surrounding the base. 6 distinct classes, with multiple playstyles for each, ~5 air vehicles and ~6 ground vehicles, also with multiple playstyles.  Jetpacking demolitions-men, snipers chugging away from kilometers for minutes on end (without getting any kills thank god), and omniscient rocket-launcher guys in armor. This game has so much to it, and it's not P2W at all. Most weapons are sidegrades and all of them can be purchased with ingame cash which is accumulated through kills/etc (play better, faster cash) except for a few cosmetic reskins.

If your pc is beefy enough, you should really check this game out!  It's got massive scale battles over 3 continents, gorgeous graphics, rock solid gameplay and a great in-depth skill tree!  You can either go infantry and shoot people up close, or decimate the competition by jumping in one of the awesome land or air vehicles. Fight your battle, your way.  My tip for new players? Go medic or engineer for quick skillpoint farming, and enjoy!  Also be sure to use your microphone, it really helps (though it's not required).

Planetside 2 is a beast of a game, boasting large multiplayer battles with flying machines, tanks, large armored flying carriers, motorbikes and other sorts of motorized madness.  The server holds three factions, the Vanus, Teran Republic and the New Conglomerate. Each faction has thier own vechiles and weapons with slight twists on all of them.  There are at least 6 or 7 classes; from heavy classes to snipers and medics to mech suits. Each class also has its own abilities; for example Light Assult has a jetpack and the Sniper class (or 'Infiltrator' or whatever its called) can cloak.  The three factions strive for dominance on one of four continets, a snowy one - Esamir, a swamp - Hossin, a desert - Indar and a temperate one - Amerish. Each continent holds at least 2,000 players (I think, at least from what I've read) which means fights can get a bit crazy. Most of the time the continent is evenly divided into three equal parts. (Unlesss it's on Indar, because there everyone fights for that one territory by the name of 'The Crown' where every faction is *really* tested.)  Each class starts out with stock weapons which are pretty decent and most of which can be upgraded to have a scope, a silencer, to fire faster, etc. Other guns can be bought from the store which cost quite a bit of in-game currency or premeium currency. Now, at this point you should know that if you want to upgrade your weapons and abilities it costs quite a bit of ingame currency. For example the 1st upgrade for Light Assults' jetpack maye be 50 pts, the the 2nd upgrade may be 150 pts, the the 3rd upgrade may be 300 pts, so on and so forth (No, those arent the actual prices I'm just tossing numbers around, the cost is way cheaper in game, I'm just using those numbers as an example.) It can becaome quite a bit of a grind at some points but its not *that* bad. In game currency is achieved from 'doing things' I guess, I dont know where I get the in-game currency from.  Your vechiles' abilties can also be upgraded, such as the shielding, the planes' or tanks' guns etc. which also costs quite a bit of in-game currency, or some premium currency.  Now, some people say to get the most out of the game you have to join this games' equivalent of a guild; this is because you can have a leader of some sort give your guild an objective and you and your guild head over to capture some facility as a single group; all prepared; flying in large groups of Flying People Carriers(called 'Galaxies'). That way it's easier to get things done; and that way you dont wander around just hoping from battle to battle. This may or may not be true, I didn't join one, but I dont really care all that much about *teamwork* or *playing with friends* or whatever.  The game at launch was notorious for being poorly optomized, I dont know about now though because I got a new computer. I hover around 50 frames on Ultra. So that's nice.  Um 8/10 +Nice large scale fights +Diverse ways to fight +Nice graphics (If you can run it)  -Need to party up to have fun -A bit grindy

This is one of the best FPS out there, and being an MMO works wonderfully in making this an epic game - there big battles all the time, with more than 1000 players easily). Or if you want to play by yourself and just infiltrate enemy bases to hack everything and just be annoying to your foes, you can do it too.   There are also multiple vehicles, tanks and airships to suit your tastes, and with a great deal of customization too, both in utility and guns.  The only downside to it is that it's almost impossible to get too many guns without having to pay real money to get them. You get in-game currency REALLY slowly, it probably takes more than 10 hours of constant fighting just to get a cheap gun, and you also have to spend the same currency to upgrade your character's perks. It's not really a 'pay to win' game, but you will definitely have advantages if you do spend some money.  Playing with friends or with a 'guild' is really important if you want to have an impact in the bigger fights, coordination is key for being succesful in this game.  Just give it a try, it's free after all. You'll be lost at first and you will die A LOT, but once you pick up the pace you will have a blast, I promisse.

I've played Deathside 2 for quite some time (only recently began to play it through steam to count how many hours I've wasted) and I can tell you this:  Deathside 2, much like the original Deathside, is a fantastic game to die in. Now, some people have managed to have few deaths. Vanu is smiling upon them and giving them good grace to live. Every war needs champions, but the majority in Auraxis will die in every way known to man. If you've never played this game, then you should do so to die for Vanu's enjoyment. It's free to play! What's not to like? But, here's a list of spoilers in how you'll die:  - You hit Instant Action to send you into battle. You come down in in a drop pod, it opens, you're see this beautiful world only for it all to be ripped away as a tank runs you over a second later.   - You respawn in a base, you die from a grenade immediately  - You spawn on a deployed Sunderer, you exploded from another grenade  - You respawn on same said Sunderer, an aircraft just shot you  - For some reason you respawn on said Sunderer for a third time believeing 'three times a charm' method. It explodes as soon as you spawn, debris goes everywhere, and you think 'I live, I live!' and then you die from a knife.  - You're defending a control point, you get shot in the back of the head. A medic sits there staring at your lifeless body and contemplates the meaning of life instead of reviving you.   - You respawn, you run out of the spawn room and get run over by a cloaked ATV. Didn't even see it coming.  - You go to leave the spawn again only to be sniped in the head the moment you're leaving.  - You decide to play Infiltrator, you find a nice hill, you begin shooting enemies. This is working out well! Oh wait, you just got shot by a tank from long distance.  - You jump into your own tank thinking this will go much better than being on foot. Then you get bombed by a Liberator gunship.  - You're in an open field on foot because you're out of resources for vehicles and no one will give you a ride. As you run, you fall through the ground. And you fall, and fall, and fall, and fall, and fall, falling, still falling, keep falling, more falling. At this point you realized you've entered purgatory and Vanu is laughing at your pain. This is why you're given one single grenade. There's only one way out of this.  - You spawn on a Sunderer, Sunderer kills you a millisecond later.   - You decide to spawn an aircraft thinking being up above and away from the crazy people will make you safe and the moment you do you are kamikazied by another aircraft.   Glorious times of death. Oh, did I meantion this was all friendly fire? It's totally worse when you actually begin to fight another empire. Expect worse when it's a three-way fight. This is only a small list of what's happened. The rest you must find out on your own!   Just remember one thing: Shoot your enemies and avoid your allies. Both will kill you.  10/10 would die again.

Planetside 2 is an enormously awesome and epic First person shooter, but if you aren't great at conventional closed space shooters, don't worry. It is constantly updated and is one of the few games that really requires teamwork. If you aren't great at FPSs, then you can learn to be a pilot, either in a one man fighter, or piloting a gun ship to support ground troops, or flying a 12 man transport around, which people can drop from repeatedly, to be said ground force. If this doesn't take your fancy, then why not be a dedicated driver, and set up mobile spawn points, letting gunners take pot shots or be a daredevil and try and get up close to drop people on a point, then be and engineer or medic, healing everyone or setting up a turret and providing ammo?  This game is for everyone, and is best played with friends, although some of my best experiences involve joining enormous platoons (of random online players) and then organising full scale assaults and carrying them out as you see in the trailer

First things first, This is what i would call a niche game. At first it may just seem like another FPS but oooh no... it's an actuall MMOFPS. So i need to explain why this game is not for everyone. This game is so massive you could be in battles of litterally hundrends of players all at the same time. And that is on a contenant with potentally thousands of people fighting all over the map. What that means is... YOU WILL DIE... A LOT. Doesn't matter how good you are at COD or Battlefield, so if you can't stand dieing over and over, then this game isn't for you.   That said, let's take a look at some of the pros and cons of this game:  PROs: x. Multipule classes to fit yer playstyle and battle situation x. Absolutely massive battles x. Vehicle warfare (Land and Air) x. Inspires Teamwork (playing a support class you still feel like you are helping, even if yer not on the front lines)  x. Totally not pay to win (All weapons are side grades, there is no 'win all' weapons. you pick weapons according to yer playstyle) x. In game voice comms for squads and platoons  Cons:  x. Overwhelming at first (since there is no other game on this scale) x. Pretty demanding on yer PC x. Gameplay can sometimes feel repetitive due to capture mechanics being the same x. Sometimes glitchy   Overall i'd give it a 9/10. Granted that's because i love teamwork games and the massive scale of this game. If you are not into those kinds of mechanics this game may cause too much fustration for you and feel more like a 6/10. You have been warned.

In terms of gameplay style, this is very much like Battlefield. Several classes, all with unique perks (medkits, ammo resupply, turrets, anti-vehicle weapons, cloaking, jetpacks, and more), as well as ground vehicles and air vehicles made for either transportion and combat, and one of them even acts like a tanky spawn point for spawing in for battles so you don't have to walk all over or drive to where the fighting is.  The unique aspects of Planetside 2 come from the faction system and the continents present in the game. Every faction is unique in just about every aspect, from voices available, to armor, weapons and weapon functions, and even the sound they make when you coak as an infiltrator. Each faction fights for control of the continents on the planet, and after any faction reaches 15 VP (Victory Points) on one continent, that continent is locked down and they gain a passive buff, such as health regeneration or reduced cost for air/ground vehicles. Only two continents can get locked down at a time, and they eventually unlock to be fought over once more. Battles in this game are huge, and can get VERY hectic, so expect your FPS to drop pretty fast once the fighting starts getting bigger and bigger (the game is pretty optimized though!)  Being a F2P shooter, one might expect that its pay to win but thankfully its far from it. The progression in this game doesn't change whether you pay or don't, it only becomes faster. All weapons in this game are considered side-grades, that are only bought to complement a specific playstyle rather than be a straight buff to damage or handling. While you can buy weapons with cash rather than certs, all of it is easily obtainble by just playing. You can get by in this game with just the default weapons with a few attachments of your choosing and do just fine. You buy weapons and attachments with certs, which are also used to upgrade a class of your choosing. The upgrades can be passive, like resistance to infantry arms to reduce damage, increased ammo storage, or quicker shield regen. Active upgrades, such as the jump jets for the Light Assault, allow the class to manuever in air with less downtime at higher ranks and quicker regeneration; or the Heavy Assault to get an extras shield ability that allows them to mitigate more damage.  The game lacks a proper tutorial, however, which is sort of the downfall of it. Even the Koltyr planet, meant for newbies, doesn't seem to do much as they encourage you to simply hop into battle. Still, the game is basic enough and there are plenty of guides out there to help familarize yourself with classes, their abilities, and much more. This review only glosses over some of the things in this game, there is still quite a bit of things here like base building/construction, vehicle progression (they also take certs and can be specialized!), customization, etc.  Live free in the NC!

Like all games, this one has its pros and cons. What matters is do the pros outweigh the cons?  Yes. At least in my opinion.  While it's got some nasty pay-to-win sort of stuff, a pretty hefty learning curve, and some rather unfortunate balance issues between new players, veterans, and people who just paid their way into the game, these don't make it a bad game. Though you might get annoyed occasionally (or a lot).  It's if you pull through this and keep at it long enough to become good that the game really shines. I haven't even played all that long and I can see this (under 40 hours as I write this). If you find a large battle, with 100+ people fighting, it's intense. The adrenaline pumping as you hear constant gunfire, explosions, and yelling is why I play this game. The fight for survival and victory.  The number of situations you could get in are numerous. Trapped in an outpost, cut off from the main territory, and trying to retain the fortress long enough for allied forces to assist. Infiltrating an enemy biodome as your allies are bombarding it from the outside, but not making any headway. Rolling in, driving your very own tank and plowing any infantry that get in your way. Piloting a galaxy, trying to make a reinforcement drop and trusting your gunners to take out whoever's shooting at you. Healing and reviving comrades as you're trying to win over an enemy base.  Then there are also sometimes slow points, where there are only small battles, but as boring as these can be, the big battles make up for it. And something you need to get used to if you are going to play this game. Dying. When you start out, you're at least as weak as everyone else, if not more so. It can be very annoying if you seem to constantly die, but you just have to deal with it to get to the really good gameplay.  And then a couple more points, just for whatever. VR training is great, and for those who aren't paying actual money, you can play around with anything here (including cosmetics). And those resources you have regenerate, don't be afraid to use them on vehicles, grenades, max suits, or whatever. Also, it's free. So try it yourself before you make any decisions.  Summarizing most of what I said (since some people like myself prefer to read summaries): - This game has good things and bad things. In my own opinion, the good aspects are worth toiling through the bad aspects. - When the game shines, you'll enjoy yourself. - VR training is good. - Don't be afraid to use resources. - The game is free, try it and make your own decision.

The best Free2Play game I have ever played, not because it has a very decide payment model (which it does), but because of it's virtually unheard of scale. A 48+v48+ battle is the norm and I've even been in a few three way battles which adds a new layer to the intensity. Even on this scale I don't experience debiltating lag, altough I do have a relatively high speed internet which helps a lot I'm sure. Much of the gameplay is in the vein of the battlefield series, and it shows. Classes behave in a very similar fashion and certain skirmishes play out very similar to how they would in say battlefield 4. This is not necessarily a critique though as much as a note; if you've played the recent Battlefields and didn't enjoy it, chances are you won't enjoy PlanetSide 2.  There is more asymmetry than in battlefield though, the three factions have some very unique abilities and play styles, and I'm a big fan of the heavy hitting, damage tanking, freedom fighters. The most unique of the factions is the Vanu who have floating tanks, lazer, and plasma weapons, which make for a uniquely annoying enemy army. The asymmetry is well balanced though, all the factions work well against the others and usually it just comes down to teamwork and some skill.  Honestly, most of the time it seems like a legit triple A paid release, and I don't mind shelling out what I normally pay for an excellent video game experience. Feel free to pay nothing for the whole game, you won't be punished for it, although it will take a while to progress compared to other multiplayer games, nothing abherrent though.   I've stayed for the the dusk seiges on fortesses, the air drops on facilities, and the epic defence of key control points, it's simply unlike anything I have played before. Just remember to play with some friends or join a good clan, as that's when the game is at it's best. All in all a solid and challenging game that is completely free. (Are you downloading it yet?)

As someone who delights in playing FPS games, I've got to say Planetside 2 wins my heart. There are very few games that can match the massive battlefields and give you that war-like feel. And unlike other similar MMOs, this one puts you in a large-scale warring environment and lets you either take the charge on foot as infantrymen or taking control of an armored vehicle for pushing on the land, or even take to the skies in an aircraft.  The game is played by taking over land with the assistance of other players. Controlling areas of the map is as simple as locating the terminal in the enemy base and standing near it long enough for the enemy to lose its hold and transfer to yours. There are multiple variations of bases where you can do battle, from small outposts and complexes to immense forts.  There are also multiple classes that you can play, each with their own abilities and loadouts. If you favor combat, you can be a light assault who uses a jetpack to reach strategic places a lot faster, or you can be a heavy assault and use your armament of weapons to mow down the opposition or even destroy tanks. If support is more your style, you can play a medic which lets you heal or even revive your teammates, or you can be an engineer who deploys mounted turrets and can repair allied vehicles. Do you prefer to snipe or sneak up for up-close combat? The Infiltrator could be what you're looking for, who is able to use the sniper rifle and can go invisible for a time, they're even capable of hacking enemy vehicle terminals to give your team control over them. And finally there's the heaviest class that couples as an armored vehicle: The MAX. You're a walking juggernaut, but the cost is spending resources to equip and comes with a cooldown before you can use again.  Your time playing does not go unrewarded, however, as time playing and doing various things including killing a player earns you points which you can spend on lots of stuff. You can invest your points into purchasing new weapons, upgrading weapons you own, upgrading each class to make them more effective at what they do, or even upgrading vehicles!  And lets not forget clans, or better known as armies in this game. You can join an army and coordinate tactics on a more organized scale to make even more progress for your faction.  If you like the idea of large-scale war where victory rests on teamwork and coordination, this is the game for you!

I used to play this game back when it was only on the Sony Online network back in 2012, so I have seen this game change over the years. They have added new continents, new weapons, abilities and a whole new development team. One thing remains constant however, you will die. A lot. Dying and respawning is a intergral part of this game. And you when you first start out you are probably going to spend more time looking at the respawn screen than actually shooting at people. But, little by little, if you stick with it, you will gradually get better. Earn some certs. Get slightly, ever so slightly better guns. Then get sniped by someone a hundred levels above you from three hundred meters away who has a gun they payed real money for.   That being said, if you stick with this game it can be a lot of fun. They have added a lot of new features that make this game a lot easier to get in to. Including a continent for beginners and a leveling system based on achievments to give you the certs needed to not make your character absolutely awful. Of course, once you are through with that you will be transported to the main continents where the aforementioned expert players are.   The combat itself is really fun. Shooting people in this game is so much more rewarding in this game. Mainly because the guns are really hard to use. Bullet drop, tons of recoil and spread. Somewhat low ammunition amounts. But that is what adds to the fun. The vehicles have a bit of learning curve, especially the aircraft.   This game is a free-to-play, so naturally there is a divide between the free and the paid. All of the guns can be purchased with either real money, or certs you get for completing challenges and gaining experience. But I will say this game gives you a lot of content for being free and it rarely beats you over the head with trying to get you to pay for stuff. And honestly, I eventually had to throw the developers a bone and buy a gun just because I felt bad for how many hours I had played and not given them money.   Eventually you will realize that all of you work is for naught. Mainly people in this game just rush into whatever battle they can find and not provide any real strategic advantage. You will see your compatriots begin to farm themselves by rushing into the same choke points and getting slaughtered. You will also need to get used to your 'allies' rushing infront of your gun as your fire down a hallway and getting themselves killed. You will also get run over by their vehicles. You will also get blown up by their poorly thrown grenades. You will also hop in a vehicle being piloted by someone else only for them to rush headlong into enemy fire and get you both destroyed. Ah, memories.  Honestly, you should really give it a try, you can use all the classes and all the vehicles from the start, and apparently they are going to be adding some base building content soon. Its probably the best time to get into the game, I mean, it is free after all.

Ok first start the download before you read this - it'll give you something to do (the game is exceptionally good and it's worth trying atleast once)  The Planet's biggest and most popular MMOFPS - PlanetSide 2 is a marvel of technological genius. There are as with any free-to-play game pay2win 'elements' - but this largely counter-balanced by the fact that these are nothing more than 'shortcuts' to the same place. A Paying player will recieve only marginially different weapons and items. The truth is the game relies much more on how well you know 'how' to play than following some 'predestined' objective. Yes there are in-game objectives, but largely this game has evolved into a constant state of never-ending entirely PvP Warfare. There is absolutely 0 AI in this game (target dummies don't need brains after all). Everything you see is a combination of the players involved unified efforts.   Don't like team-play? Well you'll be plesantly surprised that this MMOFPS doesn't rely on preset 'teams' to get the job done, you have 3 major factions and on any given day they will go back and forth in an endless vie for control of the 4 contients. The game doesn't really rely on buddies but you can always make a quick friend in game, everybody pretty much works together whatever they are doing.   The great thing about this game is: there is an endless population boom, that has lasted since I first started playing some (months?) time ago. I had taken a leave of abscense but have recently returned to find the battlefields just as thriving and wild as the first time i played.  There is no 'wrong' way to fight this battle. If your playing you have a contribution to the team, even if it's just to distract the enemy. Was it not Sun-Tzu who said that the art of battle relies on distraction, trickery, and an open mind?  Also the in-game chat system is stellar, it's well thought out to the point that you can send the 9 most common messages a soldier would say to nearby people with just 2 keystrokes. (Among those being 'I Need Repairs','Heal me','I need a ride','I need ammo',etc...and although I rarely have time to use manners on the battlefield it also has entries for 'Sorry' and 'Thanks'.).  One thing you have to be cautious of is the enemy can hear/read most of your chat, unless it's speciifically targeted at your /squadsay, /regionsay, or such. Normal Chat has a range that's pretty short but it's long distance enough to allow for cooperation on a tactical level.  Indeed perhaps the most useful thing to understand is how resources work in this game, and DBG has simplified the resources system into 3 major 'resources' - One called 'nanites' you use these for summoning vehicles, and replacing consumables etc. One Called 'Certification Points' - you use these to get in-game skills and permanent gear. And of course there has to be a Real Money System or they don't eat so they have DBG Cash, which can be used in place of some certification points and for some cosmetics things. Nanites are awarded every few minutes, Certification Points require your active role in battle, and DBG Cash has to be bought with real-world money.  Now that I've explained how resources work, the next thing you'll want to know is that the tutorial is invaluable, go through it entirely (once it gets to the point that it suggests you end the tutorial by pressing 'I' go ahead and exit it or it'll just repeat that for awhile), You will be taught important things like how to determine friend from foe, how your classes specialize, and even how some logistics work.   So, all-in-all great game, doesn't even really feel like a FPS to be honest - it feels more like a real warzone, only the occasional yell/rant by the odd player about how their life is worthless dispels the immersive experience. But don't take my word for it, it's free-to-play - try it and see.

Just 18 hours. Not kidding. But here is my review for this wonderful game.  I MIGHT UPDATE THIS THE MORE I PLAY PLANETSIDE 2.  PROS: 1000s of players at once FREE TO PLAY Good enough graphics for me Good gameplay NEW CONSTRUCTION SYSTEM Fun with friends  CONS: Bad optimization (TRICK: Right click Planetside 2's process, click Set Affinity then uncheck the first core or 'CPU 0') Some weapons/vehicles are OP or UP. Some P2W stuff (What can you expect? It's F2P. Requires real good PC (You can't handle 1000s of players on that old PC man.)  GAMEPLAY It's 3 factions fighting it out on a bunch of continents seeking to conquer it all. It plays like a futuristic version of Heroes and Generals. It's weapons are good but some are underpowered or overpowered. If you have some friends who have this game, you could ask them to play with you and all of you can have fun stuff to do as a squad.  GRAPHICS It's pretty cool. It's pretty much from my experience your usual 2012 game graphics.  FACTIONS The New Conglomerate is you can imagine as your typical balanced empire. The Vanu Sovereignty is the tech-savvy guy. Imagine it as that guy who sits on the PC all day and making Harry Potter stuff. The Terran Republic basically is the Soviet Union + Futuristic tech. That double-barrelled tank tho.  CLASSES Light Assault is the guy who goes around the frontlines flanking enemies. I picture him as my run and gun guy. Engineer is that guy who can build you almost anything. Combine the future with him and you got PS2's engineer. Medic is self-explanatory. Run around shooting enemies while healing your mates. Infiltrator is that creepy guy who follows you around wanting to know your secrets. In PS2 his job is slightly different. Heavy Assault is the light assault big brother. He's more better off in a head-on attack rather than flanking. Max I do not know yet. Never played him yet but due to his name I picture him as a juggernaut.  So I say this game is: (DRUM ROLL)   9/10: Worth trying.      NOTE! I HAVEN'T PLAYED THIS GAME THAT MUCH YET SO I HAVE TO PLAY MORE TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THE GAME. LOOK AT MY TOTAL HOURS! 18 HOURS!     Meh. That's as much as I can think of. As more as I play this game, I might update my review.

My refusal to give SOE any money since I learned how they do business way back in Star Wars Galaxies stands. That being said, I do not regret one hour I spent on this game without paying a single penny. Sure there are some bugs and junk especially after patches. But for all the hours I have played they have affected my very little overall and I do not pay so I really can't complain. Alot of people complain about balancing issues but I find that your own tactical prowess can overcome any of them unless you are fighting an opponent that is playing smarter than you are or just plain outnumbers you by a large margin. Im not sure what everyone means about pay to win. I do just fine with nothing. But to be fair, it has taken me a long time to get the certs for my upgrades. I find that part of the fun of the game though. Testing my patience with an inferior weapon or armor (or both). I suppose not everyone would find that enjoyable though. That is until they employ the superior tactics they learned with a junk weapon to a good weapon and then destroy everything that moves!  TL;DR - For a free to play MMOFPS, this is my favorite. If I had to pay though, I think some of the technical issues might get to me more. If you are a solid tactician this game is worth a shot at least.

Only spent 10$ ingame. Over all 8/10.  The game is free to play but you can buy ingame credit to purchase equipment or you can play and gain certs to buy equipment. You can also purchase a monthly membership ( Which im totally against) but it offers you discounts and more EXP. The devs are always adding new stuff like holidays events, customizable skins, and equipment.  The Factions are TR (Red) NC (Blue) and VS (Purple/pink).  Each faction have different weapons and vehicles but also share some of the same weapons and vehicle weapons.  Cons.- #1 The players of the opposite factions tend to fight and argue throughout the game and I have seen some REAL hatred towards community players. One side says one thing is better then thier faction and next thing you know people are arguing and fighting with each other. But I tend to find that in everygame.  #2 Mass zerging can create a almost impossible or struggle to regain lost bases. The population does play a factor but if you can cordinate a platoon you can take over most bases if you know what you are doing.  #3 One thing about this game is that it does not hold your hand when it comes to making decision like buying weapons and upgrades. Depending on how you like to play, support, assualt, infiltrate, max ext... You should spend some time in the VR training grounds testing different weapons out and then decide which is better for you. So make sure you know what you're buying before you buy it!
