Now, at the time of writing this, I have about twenty-four hours invested in this game. I know I always prefer getting advice from people who aren't veterans when it comes to MMOs (or fanboys/girls when it comes to regular games), so I think this is the perfect place for me to write an honest opinion on a game I'll probably end up playing hundreds of hours on.  Was very cautious about this game, for a lot of reasons. However, after playing it, I have to heartily recommend Zerg Rush Tw-er...Planetside 2. I like the upgrade system, and the surroundings...they're awesome because (a) you believeyou're on an alien world and (b) they're crafted in such a way that you can get to a base multiple ways.I believe I was about two hours in, and it was the dead of night while lasers and bullets were being fired all around the rock formation I and a couple others were hiding inside in a desert no-man's-land that I thought, 'This game is effin awesome.'  It's somewhat like an open world Battlefield in terms of gameplay, in that you can use land and air vehicles to get around in (which you will occasionally need to do if a base is too far away, or if it's just so important to you to zoom around in a tank). I do like the transport system, though it can get a little frsutrating when it won't let you go anywhere when the pickings are slim.  In terms of classes, you've got the light assault (who can use rocket boots to ascend to good vantage points), Infiltrator (snipers that turn invisible), Heavy Assault (rocket launchers and a sorta extra shield), Combat Medic (who heals and revives players), Engineer (who fixes vehicles and Max's) and MAX (a giant mech you can trudge around the battlefield, but it requires points to be able to use). A nice varied bit of classes that force teams to have a variety if they want to survive an attack/defense.  Beware, though. There is...quite a learning curve for this game. I find it (strangely enough) comparable to the Souls series, in that you spend the first couple of days doing little but dying until you start getting the hang of it.  But you will die. No matter how experienced you are or how many FPS games you've played (been FPS'ing since Doom), you will die constantly. Banish from your mind any thoughts of the twenty-man kill streaks of COD or BF, because being elite only gives you an edge instead of making you an immortal soldier that will smash through the ranks of the horde. You won't ever be some grand hero turning the tide, you'll just be one more zombie pushing against the barred gates of the mall to get at the delicious brains of the humans inside. This is a game where it's not unusual to see thirty to forty people zerg rushing an outpost, only for most of them to get slaughtered within seconds, all of you to respawn only feet away and get killed again. It sounds terrible, but it actually grows on you.  I should emphasize, even though you do use basic tactics (flanking, infiltrating teams, etc), there was never a fight I was platooned up in that didn't end with the platoon leader throwing his hands up and just telling dozens of people to rush a base. It was a little disappointing, considering how much that bit got talked up on the reviews.  It helps to have thick skin. I've only seen trash talk a couple of times (woefully pathetic trash talk, at that), but that's not where the thick skin comes in, You're going to see a metric ton of elitism, mostly by people who've unlocked the ability to shout orders and think they're suddenly Stonewall Jackson. Then there are the team kills. You will get killed by your teammates. You will get shot by your teammates, whether it be because you walked in front of them just before they fired or they're guarding a room and you walked in and startled them. You will get grenaded by your own teammates. You will get run over by your own teammates. Just remember not to take it personally.

I've read the reviews made about the game and I also wanted to share my +600 hours experience with you, who are just starting the game, because oh boy this game was hard to learn.   Tutorial is mostly pointless, you'll learn the game by playing it. Don't quit easy!  You won't understand the cert mechanism and you'll look at all the 1000 cert weapons and say 'How in the hell am I supposed to make that many certs?'. Believe me, you can, but it takes practise and time.  You'll suck at air fights. I still suck at air fights, it's just so hard to practise with all the people who MAX upgraded their ESFs and learned all the flank moves, but you can give it a shot.  You'll probably won't be able to kill anyone effectively at the start, eventhough you have other FPS experiences. The fights are nothing like you've seen before.  Tanks and ESFs will be your main enemy in ground fights. You'll be bombed out of nowhere. My main advice is to buy those 2 packs of C4, eventhough it will cost you a fortune at the start. They pay you back, trust me.  Starting weapons are fine. Don't go ahead and buy a 1000 cert weapon. Upgrade your suit and utility slots. The only upgrade i'd suggest you is the bolt action sniper rifles for TR and VS. NC starts with a bolt action anyways.  Playing medic is a great way to make certs, but don't forget to upgrade your healing tool.  If you're looking for a good secondary, any NS pistol should do fine. Commisioner, Underboss or Blackhand. Emissary is an interesting choice as well. TR doesn't really need another pistol because the Repeater is too good already.  Do not initiate any target you see. This is the common sense for most FPS games because your target dies within less than a second, but not in this game. If you're a LA with a carbine and you see a HA 100 meters away from you and you try to gun him down, what will happen is that he'll turn on his NMG, aim between your eyes with his long range effective LMG and kill you before you know it.   Use your utilities. C4s and Concussion Grenades are lifesavers. They can also win a fight right away. If you manage to sneak onto that Prowler(Tank) who just had his 50th killstreak and blow him up with your 2 bricks of C4, you are the hero.   There are tons of things i'm forgetting here buy you'll figure them out by yourself. This is a splendid game and probably the best FPS game that I've ever played. Go for it, try it, you won't regret.

I recommend this game but maybe there are few things you might like to know before playing it:  No stunning graphics (Just good enough to be playable):  At first glance it look well, but then see the walls, objects... my weapon,, and I thought that it´s graphics options were set low as default...... ahhh not.... surprisingly it was set to ultra... but ignoring all this graphics stuff it´s a good game.   Not so well optimized, maybe low-end PC´s could get in trouble: (For those who have a mid-end to high-end PC´s just ignore this....)  Yeah, graphics are not stunning to get you pc in trouble....but there are so many objects that your FPS might go low a little, but nothing to be worried of.... but then in a game with a lot of players your FPS could go low around 5-15 FPS lower than it was. So, think you have 45 FPS (GREAT) - a lot of players 30 FPS (GOOD enough to play) - objects ? maybe around 20 to 25 FPS (NOT enough, right? ).   The game-play: Well it´s entertaining, it has many ways to play, many types of characters, weapons, cars, quadbikes, tanks.... and a lot of other stuff that will entertain you. Maps are big enough to handle different battles.. which is good......overall it´s a good game....well it has some bugs (maybe a lot of them)..  Summary:  This Free to Play game has a good game-play experience, but when you download something this big (not that big, just 15.3 GB) you could expect better graphics... Don´t you???  Oh remember... this is a free to play game you could get better if you pay.... better in-game advantage....no better graphics... :)  With FPS I mean frames per second..... not first person shooter...

The 340 hours on record should say it all, this is a fun game. However, it does have a very sharp learning curve which is not helped by the game pointing you towards the relatively fragile Light Assault. Like all FPS this game takes practice and the light assault is one of the less forgiving to new players.  My advice for new players is to start with Heavy Assault, its armour and shields will help you stay in the fight long enough to get you used to the game. Medics and Engineers are the next resilient and are not hampered by their specialised roles. The medic’s assault rifle is particularly effective in mid-range fire fights.  Things to keep in mind; when you pull the trigger you show up on everyone’s mini-map and if you spray and prey you will miss. Suppressors and scopes help with this but keep in mind that suppressers hurt the effectiveness of your weapon at mid to long range. My own thoughts are the increase in stealth offsets this but that's opinions are divided.  Also flash suppressors are not suppressors, they have some use but actually increase the range at which you show-up on the mini map so make sure you equip the one you intend.  Finally find an outfit that is active, it's a unit based game and solo heroes don't tend to achieve much.

If you are patient, and understand that at any given point in time you will have to be a foot soldier in an infantry battle, a pilot/gunner in a ground vehicle, or a pilot/vehicle in an air battle--and that at any time, all three of these can and will be happening around or somewhere near you, you will enjoy this game. Just look up a video or two and see what you want to spend your points upgrading, and pick a role and stick with it for at least [the standard amount of time that you would typically try to do something in a game.] Don't play an Engineer for 10 minutes, repair a vehicle without ever getting in one yourself and then say 'this isn't for me,' then switch to Infiltrator, get sniped in the face while trying to line up a shot of your own, and then quit. You will understand if you just give it a day or two. There's a learning curve, which is something to admire. There is no winning gear--your skill and adapatibility will determine whether you conquer the map or not. It's free, what do you have to lose, besides some of your time? (which you have way too much of anyway.) Join a squad, you blueberry.  TL;DR : The most important aspect of the game for me was learning that every situation gives a different build a different advantage, and you can never really be the OP beast you were in that other game you play, so don't be a lone wolf, and learn to have some patience, and some discipline.

Planetside 2 delivers a type of gameplay you simply cannot find in other games. You can battle it out with 100's of others in 3 continents, hopefully soon to be 4 with Hossin. If you tried this game last year in December or early spring, I highly recommend you give it another try now. The game has seen seriously awesome optimization, and has enjoyed quite amount of developer action based on player feedback. While the game does have a few balancing issues, and it certainly doesn't have the best gunplay, the amazing combined arms gameplay and giant battles you find in this game CANNOT BE FOUND ANYWHERE ELSE. Furthermore, if you found the game grindy when you played it last year, the introduction of ribbon bonuses and extra vehicle destruction bonuses, and the lower prices of some really good weapons (seriously 250 cert weapons are often the best ones to use) has helped made the game more enjoyable for those strictly F2P people. The addition of a VR room to tryout anything before you buy it has also made it far better for F2P people.  If you do decide to play this game, I highly recommend that you be not afraid to ask other players for help. It can be rather intimidating at first considering the layout you can do (Although there is finally a decent tutorial, instead of just drop-podding ytou inta battle). Join an Outfit, and you will enjoy this game far more.   Overall, in light of recent optimization and the upcoming balance passes due in December, I would tell anyone who was underwhelmed or disappointed when playing this last year to reinstall and give it another try.    Also FYI, as of writing this, the 'Just Updated' is seriously outdated. It fails to mention some newer things such as the new Harrasser buggy vehicle, and the optimization update which has done wonders for many peoples' framerate.

.....This game is terrible. I don't know any other game that I've disliked right out of the gate as much as I disliked this one.  .....Map, mode, and other general information is confusing and non intuitive. You have to create and level a different character for each server. Once you've chosen a faction on said server you can't change that unless you want to kill that character and start over. And there are only a few servers to choose from. .....Winning depends purely on numbers, how many people are playing for your faction at that moment vs the other faction? The only exception is when air vehicles come into play. Those that can fly them well will camp the enemy spawn all day and there's little that can be done about it. If you're on the losing team you'll be camped until your spawn is taken and then chased into the next spawn, etc, etc... .....Vehicles are difficult to operate and easily destroyed while learning to operate them. They are also limited in supply so good luck getting enough seat time to master them. .....Weapons are weak and poorly excecuted. Beginner level weapons are weak against equal level players and useless against higher level players. Accuracy is a joke. .....The leveling system along with a lack of anything that attempts to balance who you play against or what you have to defend yourself, makes new players cannon fodder for those already leveled up. .....The maps themselves are confusing with poorly marked objectives.  .....Overall it's just a terrible game.

I want to start by inputting that I've spent well over 400+ hours into this game and have played with some of the more organized outfits ingame on all 3 of my alts.  Also please keep in mind that I want this game to succeed and do well, because it has those epic moments that you truly won't find in any of the current games we have available today (Last Quarter of 2014), but after almost 2 years of playing this game and now seeing it in this state, I feel I'm going to need to go on a hiatus and wait it out to see what new features are happening before investing any more of my money and time (almost over $300 in this game from SC cards and SC membership accrued over my year and a half time...)  I have to say that the game has certainly made progress, but it is still EXTREMELY riddled with bugs, hitching, and netcode problems that haven't been fixed or addressed to a satisfactory level since it went live. Two years and we've barely just touched the surface on creating a sustainable playerbase through more functionality and metagame principles--it's truly sad. I really do love this game, keep that in mind. I guess that's why it's so hard to see it not at its full potential.  A lot of the veteran players whom I've had the priviledge of running with saw the signs far earlier than I have, and have already quit, never to return. I'm torn between my friends and the game itself, because I truly do love this game and want it to do well. It's just not at its fullest potential right now. It really isn't.  Perhaps the Playstation 4 release will help bring in necessary resources to this game, but the playerbase seems to be at an all-time low--many of whom used to be able to run the game but now can't even get past the log in screen.   As for if I would recommend this game, YES, I would definitely recommend this game for new players to try it, yes... but be forewarned that after your 100 to 200 hours ingame, you'll start to see that the fresh paint is starting to chip and crack, and you'll start to see how much of the old paint (new guns, pumpkin events, snowman events trying desperately to create an interlude from the framerate issues, buggy netcode, and other problems) has been there all along.  Good luck to both the developers of Planetside 2 and its players (both new and old alike). I'll have to check back in another year to see how things are. Crossing my fingers that this game will reach its desired goals sooner than later, because fewer players are logging in.

I've been waiting, itching to try this game for ages, so I did.... This review will turn out to be a rant, but in short: It's a game only for those who have the time and patience to get used to it.  -I tried it - I loved it. -I played it and realized I it wasn't as good as my initial impression was. -I got to witness the halloween events and finally realized this game is not worth much.  So why the change in heart? I'll try to summarize why I liked it and what changed.  I've been running around, trying all classes, running with other players - just participating in fights. So far so good.  I noticed some of starter weapons (like sniper rifle) needs a change bandly, so I looked at weapons and upgrades, in hopes adapting my weapons to my play-style, and realized that those are going to be a b**** to get. Most weapons cost 1000 certs and you get 1 cert / 250 experience you earn. To put this into perspective, that is roughly what I get by killing 1 normal enemy with 70% exp bonus. What's worse, a lot of the stats you see on the screen are REALLY deceptive, so you might buy a weapon that looks good for long ranged combat based on stats, but in reality is complete rubbish due to recoil (that is not mentioned).  This was the first real hit on my experience.  Then, halloween came! I was really excited to see what the game had to offer on events. I felt like I was playing one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ phone games when I saw what the devs offered on halloween.The only REAL change in the game is that you can run around like a goofball, looking for pumpkins (by the way you have to go out of your way to find a decent amount). That might sound like fun until you notice they are relatively rare and they don't REALLY give anything worthwhile until you find about 200 of them.  Then you have 'achievements' with rewards, which are devided into 4 tiers. Only last 2 tiers give actual items as rewards and to complete those you need to do 4 and 5 of following objectives (see if you can spot a problem): -Kill x people with mask on. (not a problem really). -Destroy x pumpkins. (a lot harder than it sounds, because everyone competes for kills) -Destroy a RARE pumpkin (close to impossible to find) -Obtain x masks (can only be bought with pumpkin seeds you get from pumpkins. Mind you I'm on tier 3 now - I still don't have enough to buy 1 mask and I need to buy 2). -Kill x people witha pistol that costs real money. -Kill x people with a knife that costs real money.  This was the point when I realized this won't ever be a game I take seriously: -2 of those require money, which means f2p players will never get the last tier (and that knife),  -1 of those is so rare it's close to impossible to find.... Killing one should immediatelly drop some kind of item - that's how rare it is. -Buying masks is also a bit of a hard one (that's putting it lightly) because with ~100 pumpkins destroyed (and i've actually spent time looking for them) I have got 402 seeds and the cheapest mask is 750. You need 3/4 masks at higher tiers.  To put it simply, to get everything this event offers you need to spend money AND either be insanely lucky or spend the 2 weeks looking for pumpkins.   As a side note, I checked around the forums and they've had this exact event since 2012. People complained about it being impossible to complete since then. I can only assume they don't take this kind of feedback into consideration.  So yeah... The good: -Combat and conquest thing is pretty fun. -It's fun to alter between classes.  The bad: -Steep learning curve. You really need to sit through hours/days of fails to improve. -It takes a lot of time and patience to get the weaponry and skills to suit your playstyle. -Some weapons that might be completely useless for what the stats imply they are for. -Huge accent on team play (Impossible to play alone for the most part). -Horrible holiday event design: Insane amount of boring grind AND REAL MONEY PAYWALLS.  -Devs don't care about feedback on events. -(not mentioned above) Quite a lot of trolls and such who will kill you (not neceserely by shooting you).

Me: 'My favourite part of Planetside 2 is the death screen.' Brother: 'My favourite part is the uninstall screen.'  Honestly, the game can be fun... When you're not dying to a Heavy Assault's pistol from across a large settlement, and realising that tampons for men are, and would, be more effective than your rockets.  PlanetSide 2 is a large scale, F2P FPS where three teams fight over a giant map when they're not walking about trying to get to said battle, and when they do get there, die to an Infiltrator that spent the time walking out of their base to come stab you in the ♥♥♥ when they could've shot you.  DeathScreen 2 has the potential to be a better game. If you spent less time looking at the death screen, and the guy with a female character with clothes tighter than David Bowies' pants in Labyrinth, you might be able to get the points to buy the better weapons that can actually fill someone with bullets and kill them. Which brings us to the next point.  PlanetoidAngle 2 has a currency called Cercs, which you use to buy weapons for each class. From what I know, you get 1 Cerc for every 100xp (?), which honestly, you can get a few depending on your luck in 1-3 lives. However, it's hard to get said Cercs when you have the starting Nerf guns, and everyone else has the Pay2Win nuclear bomb pistols that can kill you from anywhere on the map with any button.  With the concept this game has, it could be extremely fun if it wasn't as frustrating and featured more of a friendly weapon-obtaining system so you're not constantly getting mowed down by shotguns with the accuracy of a sniper rifle.  If I could, I would give the game a neutral recommendation.

I will not go deep into gameplay as plenty of reviews are available. I will just say this is not an easy game to get into, but once you get your bearings it's an incredibly rewarding experience. Read on for details.  To give you an idea of the community PS has, I served the Terran Republic for 8 proud years in PS1 over Johari, then Markov, and finally Gemini with Black Company as a combat medic, rising to the outfit rank of Captain. We disrupted enemy supply lines by hot dropping in enemy territory, blowing up generators, and blocking enemy resupply runs. My first commander, 888, taught me everything I know. Our elite Galaxy transport pilot was a housewife who had to leave to make dinner when hubby got home (boo!), and we actually had a couple retired vets as mechanized infantry and air support. I realize some of that sounds absurdly epic for a video game, but it's exactly the lasting experience you get. All veteran PS players have resumes like that, and happily swap war stories as the battle rages around them.  The game itself has some flaws and bugs, but those are almost irrelevant (as long as you can actually play) since the game's true strength is in its organizational framework that makes working with other players fun and rewarding. Don't get me wrong, I really think the gameplay is strong and real money purchases are not overpowered, just look elsewhere for in-depth analysis.  I really think that if you are new and want the full experience, you MUST interact with people and join an outfit. That way you can see how the game strategies work, what bases and base installations are important, etc. Concerted operations in the game are fluid situations, you are not likely to get a strong understanding from a static online guide. If you try to solo without knowing that stuff, you will suck and quit. Once you get the hang of things you can, if you want, then leave your outfit to Lone Wolf; and you'll know enough to have fun doing it. You will have a better understanding of what the coordinated groups are trying to do, too. Or, if you're feeling lazy, you can hit Instant Action, and just go Zerging (PS jargon for joining a horde of other players and overpowering enemy positions with brute force numbers and minimal coordination).  Again, I have to stress how much being in an outfit is what makes this game great, definitely when you start - and still a great option later on. All that said, it's a time drain. I was pretty dedicated back then, nowadays I got too many other things to do to really get into an outfit, but I still jump into squads now and then and pitch into the never ending war.  Victory is Our Tradition!

Imagine Battlefield 3, but with thousands of players, and a map 10x bigger. That's what Planetside 2 is.  Back in 2013 I played nonstop all the way to summer. It was a really amazing on how much you could do.  But, after playing for half a year, I had come to the conclusion that a game with so much potential was dying because of the developers. Pay-to-win, and couldn't balance any weapon (i.e. Buff One, Nerf Other)  I rejoined a half a year after and it's slowly getting itself back together (a bit too slow if you ask me), and I was a bit disappointed in the time of my absence on what has changed. OMF:G didn't really do much for my build, and the UI I don't really like but I've gotten used to. Esamir and Amerish redesigns are new to me so I'm enjoying those. Especially Amerish.  So I'm still definitely playing.  In conclusion, if you really want to try out this game, try it out with some friends. You'll love the experiences you will have in an open world first person shooter laughing amongst your friends while you crash your galaxy by accident killing everyone on board, rolling into hell with a sunderer and getting insta-gibbed, or team kill each other on 'accident.' Don't have any friends? Join an outfit (Like a guild in World of Warcraft).  I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone (with a decent computer, no seriously this game is really heavy on requirements)

Here's some things you need to know. No excess stuff, just pros and cons which I'll let you decide if it makes or breaks the game for you. Ignore the recommended rating. I just like the game.  PROS ++Epic large scale that no other game can offer right now ++Controls aren't difficult to understand ++Training continent that lets new players experiment with vehicles and weapons ++looks great ++sounds great ++Not P2W (but definitely not easy to get new weps by grinding) ++All factions have unique traits which can change gameplay a bit ++pretty epic when playing with an outfit (or if you're a good solo) ++large variety of weapons  CONS --Vanu (laser accurate, extreme DPS, lack of ballistics outside launchers, best MBT and JSF) --SpawnCamping 2 --lol where did that bullet kill me from?  --client side hit detection --initial tutorial sucks --very steep learning curve --not very well optimized --Instant Action (I love this already finished and calming battle) --no battlelines outside spawncamping --ZERG --if you're not at least BR 20 by now, good luck --only like 3 starter weapons worth a damn, completely outclassed by everything else anyway --will take considerable time to get new weapon worth a damn without paying actual money --good luck with stock vehicles --prepare for random TK

Quite decent game. Unfortunately it comes with unacceptable business model. Monthly subscription + item shop ( selling guns, boosts, armor, etc...). Often huge lag (250 ms ping) even on closest regional server. Really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ business model - for example: you unlock a rifle with one class, change class and you need to pay again to unlock SAME rifle on another class on the very same character. You can go further and buy optic/zoom for that same rifle, which is again locked on another class... no comment. We should stop supporting such greedy business models. I am totally fine with lets say monthly subscription, but selling rifles for real money which do give you advantage in a FPS game is just low. Ofcourse you can play for 459645978689476 hours and unlock all those shiny items ingame to become competitive. And before you say i am angry of getting pwned check my screenshot of me noobie player making like 200+ kills as infantry in one session. Planetside 2 is an OK game, I made those little less than 100 hours in like 2-3 weeks, but i just can not and refuse to support SOE's business model.   Going to uninstall the game right now...

The year was 2015 that this game went to all H <-- Escalation Point <---  I mean literally! Exclamation point !  Metaphor, bigger metaphor, huge metaphor.  So I'm sitting inside a base and I just spawned, so I decided be a nice guy, And I decided drop down some ammo, as well as put up an automated turret  To help of eliminate the opposing faction you no = Enemy  Well to my surprise the Guy in Front of me Falls Dead on The Ground, So I was really sort of surprise like wait a minute, im on the inside of the base..inside the Force Field?   Well after looking around to my surprised I realized that I really was inside the base, And yes I really was is in the spawn area next two and behind force fields.  So People started dropping like Flies.... And my automated turret Started taking some damage,.  Then I got shot.. yes by the way it was in a Head. The opposing faction shot me through the force field so  I decided be even nicer guy and reported by clicking on report. After while one of the opposing players yelled out metaphors as well as a bunch of nonsense. Of course everyone died and we ended up not keeping the base. So a few people on our team of ' TR ' stated that the weapons for these individuals or opposing factions, guns are overpowered their shooting as through the force fields. I thought i'd rewrite my review on PS2 yet again after a massive update that has added a new construction system.  TL:DR I think the recent changes are a step in the right direction for the game, hopfully we get to see more of these in future.  Pros  + Massive Scale.  + Construction System.  + Good graphics and sound design.  + One of the better F2P models out there.   Cons  - Very CPU heavy.  - The F2P model can make the game very grindy.  - Messy design choices can make the game needlessly confusing and hard to learn.  - Classes can make the game needlessly restricting.   Planetside 2 has had a massive update which added an all new construction system and i have to say i'm impressed, the Advanced Nanite Transporter makes a return in the role of resource collector and minor base builder. You collect a resource called Cortium and the ANT deploys like a sunderer with a terminal at the back that is used to purchase structures, you generally use this to buy a cortium silo to deposit resources for your base. Cort silos are like NTU silos from the first game, they are used to power nearby structures like turrets and base modules and like the PS2 ANT it has a terminal on it for purchasing structures. Indar has also had a revamp in response to the patch with other continents to follow in the coming patches.  In addition to this there's a new victory point system that was added not long ago which i was opposed to at the time but now it makes sense, each faction has to earn 15 VPs to win the match and lock the map. My personal complaint with this is it makes the game feel more like an arena shooter and not a large-scale war game but now with the construction system i feel the VP system has a purpose. Your faction earns VPs by owning the major bases, getting a lattice link on an opposing faction's home base and capturing all the major bases (tech plants, biolabs and amp stations) will result in an instant win, winning alets is also a good way to get VP as is refining cortium as you get a VP for every 10k cortium that's placed in silos and you get XP if it's your silo. In addition to this there is a structure called a HIVE which acts as a VP generator, when you build them they start off inactive but when a large group of players on the same team as the VP gen hang around it turns on, once the VP gen is destroyed if it's active it sets off a large explosion like an ACU being destroyed in Total Annihilation and it's spiritual successors which destroys vehicles and structures aswell as killing players in a small area around the VP gen.  The mission system feels like less of a hassle now thanks to the addition of the construction system because it doesn't mark player bases, although it does update it's waypoint based on where you are on the map. Lattice is also less problematic thanks to the Indar revamp because there are fewer bases, now there aren't many connections that feel pointless which helps the flow of battles.  Squads have also been changed a little, each squad has four groups that members can be assigned to by the squad leader which can help when organising battles. Each squads has 3 sub-groups in addition to a fourth group which acts as an 'unassigned' group.  Two major problems i would like to mention are:  - The game can be very damanding on your CPU as it only uses up to 4 cores, if you intend on playing this game at the highest settings possible i reccomend getting a CPU that has fewer, stronger cores.  - PS2 is also quite fussy about what you have on your computer, if you notice your game crashing especially when it's frequent then i reccomend doing a virus scan or look for any unwanted software. Some malware can be attached to software packages like System Protector in Winzip Utilities.

Previously the game was at least mostly competently managed, but the developers have a long history of breaking at least one major feature and worsening performance with every patch. It finally caught up to me. After more than a thousand hours, I can no longer recommend this game because of the awful performance on even minimum settings and awful game direction that seems to be geared specifically toward nickel-and-diming what little core audience still plays.  I'll keep checking the state of the game after patches, but I'm not going to change my review outside of a true miracle.

This review comes from someone who has never really been that into FPS games in general, with the rare exception.   I did get really into the original planetside way back when (up until they put in giant mecha robots?), and I played PS2 when it was in open beta quite a bit, and loved it. Now I've rediscovered it for free on steam and am loving it just as much.  Planetside is not a shooter in the classical sense of the word. The maps are not little battle maps, they are continents broken up into grid with bases to capture. This is one massive war with hundreds of people involved. You will die. When you are new you will die a lot. This is not because of your equipment, but just getting used to how the environment works, how bases are set up, how steep of a slope you can climb, etc.  Your starting weapons are plenty to go face to face with vets. I've read negative reviews that say they aren't but to them I say 'git gud'. find the gun you can do it with, maybe you are more of a shotgun kind of guy, maybe you prefer to snipe like a little ♥♥♥♥♥ up in the mountains, or maybe you enjoy a nice medium range assault rifle. Get used to the fact that if populations are high there will always be someone up on that hill or up on that roof, or around the next bend. The scale of this war always amazes me. By the time you get good with a few of the starting weapons you will have plenty of points to unlock something else. What that is is entirely personal preference.  When you die, the game breaks down how good of a life you had. You are going to die. Die with glory, die with flair. Dont be afraid to run into that doorway that everyone is standing outside shooting in, shotgun blazing.  Most of the complaints about this game can be broken down into one category: want something? do it yourself. Not enough medics? so suit up, doc. No leadership guiding the masses? take the reins. No air support? Learn to fly. Be as worthless or useful as you make yourself. Even if you suck at normal FPS you can contribute solidly as an engineer, a medic, or sneaking in and capturing bases when nobody is looking.  Have fun. Die.   10/10

Whether you can push past it or not, Planetside 2 is a pay to play. I say this primarily because the gap between those who have either purchased their in-game currency for better weapons, armor, and vehicles or have worked tirelessly to earn them (which, if you choose to strive for, bravo) will likely become the most obvious aspect of playing Planetside 2 once given time. This does not mean that you cannot have fun, that's up to you after all, but it does mean that balance can quickly become non-existent in the face of a player with far superior equipment.   The lack of balance is largely due to the fact that your only way to attain new gear is severely limited to what few Certs (the games earned currency) you can make at time. If given a day of gameplay, you may earn a single gun that is usable for a single class that is still the cheapest because it was harder to make more than 300 Certs that day. Whereas, if one looks around the main website of Planetside 2, they can see that if they purchased a package costing around $60, this would increase the amount of Certs you've earned, starting gear you have, and give you a fair sum of the paid for currency. To me, this said that I had merely been playing a demo that was attempting to get me to buy the full game so I could run around with everyone else to try and fairly catch up.  This is not in the spirit of a good free to play title. Those that truely wish to seek balancing only offer vanity and other small advantages, if any, to pay to play winners while making the rest of content an equal grind to all, so that everyone's time is worth the same. In Planetside 2, the real race is to be the first to pay enough to have their time of grinding for new weapons more valuable than all the rest. Despite the opportunities to be had in this game, and the things that originally drew me to it, I regret the time I spent of my friends and my own trying to finally have a fun experience in this game instead of being met with the horrible balancing issues when one inevitably fell into the constant wars of attrition that make up the bulk of Planetside 2.  There are better games to spend precious time with your friends, ones that will respect monetary investment or lack their of. Warframe provides a much more balanced free to play system with an inevitable monetary pay in for the bare necessities that didn't make me feel dirty.

Do I enjoy playing Planetside 2? Yeah, when I'm with my friends. Do I recommend other people play it? Only under certain circumstances.  I just started playing this game again after nearly a two year break, and a lot of the problems it had when I left are still here. This game is still a giant zerg vs. zerg simulator, and while that CAN lead to big, fun fights, it's more common that enemies will simply bypass one another to try and capture bases, or a small force getting completely obliterated by a vastly numerically superior enemy force. On top of that, the game takes every opportunity it can to try and convince you to spend your hard-earned money on minor upgrades and cosmetic fluff.  But beneath all that, Planetside 2 is a fun shooter with lots of toys to play with. As long as you're running with friends, you can get a lot of enjoyment out of this game. It's not P2W, and you can do just fine without spending a dime.  TL;DR: If you want to try this game, don't play alone. Don't stress about winning. Just grab some friends and go shoot some bad guys.

The game is horribly balanced. Players who're far longer in the game than you are have serious advantages over you. The netcode is rather bad, you often get shot around corners and at long range enemies teleport around so you can't snipe them. Close range you'll easily be rofl'ed over by somone who's whether playing one of the classes that can simply take so much damage to, or have so many upgrades and so good guns that they can, just turn around and kill you as you shoot your magazine empty on them, not letting a single bullet miss. The factions don't just have comparable ups and downs, some vehicles are seriously overpowered. The main tank of one faction can oneshot every other main tank of the other factions plus is able to take multiple shot from said other main tanks PLUS is a hover tank and therefore is able to move much more freely and dodge bullets.  Aside from the frustrating deisgn decisions the game has HORRIBLE hitboxes. You can't shoot through obvious gaps, for example the area between the sunderer and the ground is bullet proof air.  Fog behaves very weird. If you run though it, your screen turns white, then back to normal, then white again and so on and so forth.  There isn't much about the huge maps. They're just huge, they're not very interesting, not all that nice to look at and the buildings are just plain pieces of metal. The interaction with the environment is very poor. You can't even jump through a window. (btw windows don't have glass, and there's only doorhinges) All you can interact with are consoles and vehicles.  Since the maps are all so empty it gets really hard to survive, because there is little cover between the bases and even if there is cover, the distances give snipers plenty of time to kill you. Basically if you don't have a vehicle you're dead meat on open fields. Inside the bases everything is so open that there's always a way for the enemy to flank you. There are so many options to flank others, that you CAN'T stay alive. There's always someone using a jump pack to get behind you, using invisibility to get a clean head shot on you or uses heavily armed aircrafts to ruin your day. Buildings are basically just pixel camps and meatgrinders. Once you managed to take the base and push the enemies into the spawn zone things get really boring: The enemy can shoot out of the spawn zone, you can't shoot in. So you camp around a corner where the enemy has to come through and hope to get a kill every once in a while.  I just didn't have fun with this game. I'm a good player, I'm an excellent player in some games, but here I never lived long enough to enjoy any of the battles i participated in. Even if I managed to totally outplay my opponents they often had an unfair advantage that took every last bit of fun.  It's just a stupid respawn simulator.

Note: The game developers are no longer Sony Online Entertainment, and are now a new entity owned by Columbus Nova under the name Daybreak Games Company (DGC).   On the surface, it is fairly obvious that Planetside 2 (PS2) is a very unique game by being a MMOFPS. Its core FPS mechanics heavily resemble a Battlefield (BF) game with some differences. There are 3, relatively well balanced factions with different weapons. PS2 is set on 4 massive 64km^2 warzones where the lines in the sand are frequently redrawn, and rarely owned for a long time. The maps are persistent, with the only exception being when they are 'locked' by one faction conquering the map during an alert (2 hour special event triggered by territory capture).   In my personal opinion, Planetside 2 is one of the most unique games on the market and it provides an experience replicated nowhere else, at least until Warhammer 40K: Eternal Crusade is released. I would highly recommend it for those who are seasoned shooter veterans and BF players who wouldn't mind a bigger playground to be in. If you read nothing other than this, I would highly recommend the game.   Like many games, PS2 has some upsides and some downsides.  Pros: -The experiences you will have in this game are like none other in any game on the market. This makes gameplay relatively fresh compared to many other games, with many differences from other conventional shooters.   -The core gunplay will be familiar (for the most part) if you have ever layed hands on any of the BF series of games.  -There are many various playstyles to choose from, meaning you will likely never run out of things to try unless you pigeon hole yourself to a specific role.  -This game does F2P right, with most money being spent towards cosmetics or unlocking sidegrades faster. Even with the addition of implants, PS2 is still very fair to free players. The grind is noticable, but often your stock weapons may be the ones you use the most.   -If you have ever wanted more community in a game, PS2 is full of Outfits (clans/guilds) of varying types, specializations, and skill levels. Organized gameplay is the most rewarding (both xp-wise and gameplay-wise), making squading up and joining an outfit the best way to play the game.   -Speaking of community, the game's community isn't extremely toxic like many other FPS communities. Newb questions are often answered on the official forums or on the Planetside subreddit. Even more complex questions or technical issues are answered, so don't be afraid to ask.   -Whatever Anti-Cheat DGC uses, it is incredibly effective. Almost all of their games have little to no issue with hackers, usually driving the hacking scene for these games to extinction.  EDIT: As of the release of H1Z1, people have noticed an increase in hackers on the European servers. There have also been some changes in the Anti-Cheat, so take the above 'pro' with a grain of salt.   -The developers (and ex-developers) are relatively active on social media such as twitter and reddit. They'll often post stuff about WIP or changes they may be experimenting with on the test server or their own private servers.   Now, the game does not come without its downsides, and they can be fairly hefty.  Cons: -The game is very buggy and it is not uncommon for patches to break parts of the game (hence the joke name for the company, dey break games), or exploits to appear. This is due to the complexity of an FPS and an MMO, which are polar opposites as far as game stability goes. Patches and hotfixes appear fairly quickly though, and DGC has gotten much better about build management and bug fixing. Some bugs are more persistent than others, including crazy legs.   EDIT: rip crazy legs, flail on in bug heaven  -Balance is relatively good, and DGC has been getting better, but weapons are often overnerfed and then slowly rebuffed back to usable levels. Some weapons, like HE rounds for tanks, often get nerfed repeatedly or changed. The game is the most balanced it has been since its release.   -The game is a monster of a CPU hog. Like many MMOs, PS2 requires heavy amounts of CPU power and doesn't use the GPU as much as it should. The game also leaks memory like bad plumbing, which is a problem with all Forgelight games. Its hard to get your performance optimal, but it is still possible to get 60+ FPS on 1080p if your CPU is good and you optimize your settings (just keep in mind lower isn't always better, its hard to explain).   -This game will lag, especially in the massive fights it is famous for. If you have a Comcast monopoly in your area, you probably won't be able to experience the game as you might want to. However, clientside hit detection does make up for this, but it will lead to some pretty BS deaths against laggier opponents.   -The game has probably the steepest learning curve I have seen in any FPS. Expect to die, a lot. Eventually you will improve and you will enjoy the game more and more. new player experience has improved though, and the community has a multitude of videos for new players.   -With the recent aqusition by Columbus Nova, it is hard to see where the game is going. Some say the game is setting, while others say the game will liven up and improve. It is hard to tell, so the uncertainty of the game is a definite downside at the moment.   Overall, I feel the pros outweigh the cons. The game is still being supported, it is likely that it will still have servers up for coming years. However the game's population is slowly going down, and I feel that getting very invested in the game will lead to heartbreak. I would still recommend at least trying the game, as it is free to play.

To explain this game would be...a bit hard. I'll try my best to explain how the community works to the best I can.  There are three different factions: The Terran Republic (Military Dictatorship wanting to unite the lands) The New Conglomerate (Almost total Anarchy type of freedom trying to bring freedom to all sectors) The Vanu Sovereignty (Cult of Technology)  The Terran Republic usually has the regular bullet-like technology at the beginning and basically through the game. The people who are usually these guys are rather new to the game, as I played as them at first. They don't usually get along with one another, but the players usually accomplish whatever goal they need to accomplish with good heavy infantry and Maxes (Basically mechsuits)  The New Conglomerate, to sum it up, is basically if a bunch of shotguns got together and decided to turn into people. They excel in light assault shotgunners and heavy assault, but lack stealth. The people on this faction usually are nice people, but they don't usually cooperate that much with one another (results may vary). They end up, though, helping one another in the end by basically swarming with sheer manpower and excellent air power.  The Vanu Sovereignty is a cult of technology. They have some of the better later guns while lacking in beginner equipment. From my experience, they seem to have the better people tactically and they usually all get along, but they lack manpower. The beginning guns are basically crap, but as you play more as them you unlock some of the most overpowered weapons in the game. Basically, they are good at strategy and teamwork, terrible in numbers, bad beginning guns but some of the best later guns, and better technology than the rest of the factions.  For the combat, this game is full-on chaotic at times, but can also be quiet but deadly. You can end up in just a small skirmish against another faction, but you might also end up transforming that small skirmish into a huge battle to turn the tide of the fate of the continent.  The continents can be controlled by different factions, giving certain factions certain abilities. JUST REMEMBER THAT THIS GAME IS NOT A PAY-TO-WIN GAME! The things you can get on here with money can be gained with gameplay. This isn't like any other massively multiplayer shooter. This is NOT Call of Duty or Battlefield! This game will be, instead of 32 vs 32, will be about 200 vs 200 vs 200 just in one area alone. There are many servers and with each server there are continents. Within these continents are regions and these regions are fought over. This means that there is CONSTANT war between people. These servers hold about 2000 people each, most likely more, and each continent is full of warzones. There will be kamikazes, airstrikes by other players, snipers who snipe you from the other side of the map, basically everything.  This game is fun and frustrating. I cannot stop playing, but I also cannot stop getting ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at times. The community is amazing, and this game balances the frustration of wanting to achieve as well as the fun of playing greatly. The only think I recommend is that you have a good computer to run this game.  9/10.

I had to make a new Review as I played this game more.   Pros  Huge map  Huge intense battles Large amount of weapons and equipment  Funny people  Great Teamwork  Little to no toxic or salty players No two year olds screaming in voicechat This game is great if you are looking for huge battles filled with Teamwork and being able to turn the tables of a battle by yourself.   Cons  Requires a beefy computer  Earning in game cash (Certs) takes hours of constant farming All weapons cost 1000 certs (A large amount)  You can only get some weapons and skins by paying real money Stupid teammates (people who run you over, kill you, and all around arnt very nice teammates)  Starting weapons are weak (Opinion)  The map will not allow to to respawn on one side of the map if you have been playing on the otherside.   Anyone who says they use thir crappy computer to run the game and they get 60 Fps and it works fine is lieing. I have a $3000 gaming PC made for playing games like this and I get 20 fps with all lowest settings.   Certs take too long to get, Certs are in game cash you use to buy weapons without spending real money. To get certs you must earn 250 experience to get 1 cert. As you may have a number of ways to get EXP it will take you hours apon hours to get to 1000 certs to be able to get one single gun. And for new players who have trouble killing or finding out how to earn EXP it will take even longer.   All and all I give this game a 4/10   I like this game only because of the huge battles with so many players. But when you cant get a good FPS or get any kills the game becomes boring quickly.

When you first join Planetside 2 it seems just like any other shooter, but when you get away from the initial base and into a fight you can really see the amazing difference. Planetside 2 features thousands of players per map, and there are 3 maps per server that you can warp between (it also features a training are where you can test guns and other gear before you purchase them and lets you practice with no cooldown on vehicles or respawn timer as well as practicing in a friendly enviroment where your not getting shot at). And it does this with almost no lag i have only lagged a tiny bit, and iv played almost 100 hours, and they are working on getting rid of that tiny bit of lag that happens when the servers get super full. I absolutely love this game, its so amazing instead of being like all those other generic shooters you cant learn where everybody sits an waits, camping doesnt work so well. you have massive maps to fight on. you really have to stratigize and work with your teamates. there are three factions to pick from. You can do basicly anything you want, drive tanks, humvee's, atv's dropships, gunships whatever, the possibilities are endless. the classes are so easy to customize to your unique play style whatever that may be. Do you want to sit back and snipe, lay down heavy fire, heal your buddies? doesnt matter there is a class for you and if the fit isnt perfect, you can customize even further. Honestly i dont think this game will ever get old, and i really think that even as great as it is, its only going to get better. the realism is amazing. and as a plus if your parents are against M games, dont worry you can still play. I love how you cant just rush the enemy base you have to work together with other squads, your tanks, and of course your air support. No matter what you want to do, there is something here for you, and dont get discouraged if you die, this is war it happens.   My advice for new players is first find your class, then play with some other more experienced players. keep your head down till you get more experience and never give up.

The battles are very big and the victories are very satisfying, but underneath of it all, the soldiers are not organized. Everyone is just doing their own thing, with or without a squad. Before jumping into PS2, find a dedicated group of people to play with.  Getting points to upgrade your gear is very difficult and you are forced to grind. It took me 30+ hours of casual play just to get a sniper scope, a night vision scope, a different kind of ironsight add-on and a few upgrade slots. It's very tedious. Would be nice they included a trading feature in the Steam community.  I can't say I like the game very much, but that's not I say it's an awful game. If you're into this kind of game and willing to pay for perks, then you'll like this game.

Pay to Win don't mean anything in this game. Everthing has a learning curve with it. Learn the gun learn the vehicle, you will and can dominate. You may think that your team mate has a cool epic gun. Yeah, you are right. Can you afford it? Yea in abut 8 hours of pure grinding. But his gun has some pros and cons to your gun. Every gun is adapted for a situation and for a specific task. For example, need to cut through enemies without reloading? Dont bring a MWS-R with only 50 rounds in a mag. BRING A T7 HANDHELD MINIGUN WITH EXTENDED MAGAZINE AND NEVER RELOAD. For about 20 seconds.   There isnt much to this game than a HUGE learning curve to the weapons and vehicles. There is a huge amount of team work involved in this and beleive me it is vital when you have about roughly 150 people vs 150 people. The tide of war can easily change. One day I spent 3 hours fighting over Snowsheer Watch tower only to lose it again 2 hours later. Came back to the game a few hours later, still fighting over it. Oh by the way, battles can range from a small skirmish of about 30 people on each side to a full blown battle of around ehhhh 150- 200 people on each side.  In my opinion to start out, play as a Light assualt to get some action for a few hours. Once you have died 30 times in the same spot because you are in a massive biolab seige, try another class. I recommened a medic with the sheild regen shield. Upgrade it a few times then you got a massive Cert farmer. Just plop it down on the floor during a seige at a choke point and heal your allies then boom. Easy 100 certs in an hour. On an EXP boost event or weekends for members, ohh man the amount of certs you gain is like a new weapon every few hours or something if you grind hard.  Over all you need to learn how to play with the weapons and use them itherwise you will jst die. If you have a bad PC or laptop like mine, make sure you turn everything down low and CLEAN YOUR F.E.K.I.N.G fans otherwise it WILL BURN (I mean literally fire). Most games would rely heavily on GPU's (this does a bit) but a good CPU is needed for this because lets not forget, One map world holds 2000 players. and there are 4 map worlds. so there are around 8000 players or more that may be synced at the same time.

I've now put 80+ Hours into this game, it's safe to say that it is the most unique first person war shooter i've played. It combines FPS with MMORPG aspects, along with a constantly changing open world that is entirely player driven. On top of all of that it's a free to play title. Similar to the way that League of Legends handles their micro-transactions, Planetside 2 has many guns that you can unlock using 'Station Cash' which is purchased with real money. On the other hand, you can unlock all of these weapons using the certification system. Pay to WIN!? No, I haven't gotten there yet. This game also features a system that allows you to customize your soldier to your liking, you are able to buy armour that resists flak, or small arms, or even carry extra deployable items! All of these suit mods, utilities, attachments, vehicle mods, vehicle gun attachments, all cost certs, and can't be purchased using Station Cash. They are all essential to becoming a better player, and certs take time to get, so the player gets better and experiences a sense and feeling of accomplishment when they raise enough certs to finally unlock that forward grip that they wanted so that their gun could be more effective at a longer range. Anyway, that's what I think of Planetside 2, thanks for reading, I reccommend this game completely!

WE HAVE COOL TANKS, ALWAYS YELL, AND ALWAYS USE CAPS. LIKE THIS. SO JOIN THE NEW CONGLOMERATE TODAY. OR WE'LL SPY ON YOU. MORE THAN WE ALREADY ARE. I adore this game because of its scale, vast open maps with terrain that slowly alters as you travel across it, the continent of Indar is my favourite example, it has canyons, open desert and lush highlands all of which seemlessly blend together. And with four varied continents to fight across every login is different. One day you might be taking part in an armoured advance across a desert featuring hundreds of combatants in tanks, aircraft and on foot which is reminiscent of Desert Storm and the next you're skydiving with your squad mates into a hostile base right onto an objective in the middle of a firefight. I've found myself skimming the treetops of the jungles of Hossin in a Valkyrie (think Heuy Helicopter in Vietnam and you're not far wrong) and fighting through the corridors of Tech Plants trying to knock out shield generators like something out of Star Wars. With three distinct factions vying for power across four continents you can always find the fight thats right for you.  All in all the game is well rounded and you have lots of directions you can specialise in, whether its as a fighter pilot, tankie, medic, special forces or as PS2's equivalent of the Space Marine, the MAX. The battlefield however is an unforgiving place for new recruits, especially when you're not used to worrying about so many potential threats so joining a squad and later an Outfit (clan/guild) is an excellent way to stay alive and stay in the fights that matter. Earning the skills, weapons and equipment you need to be competitive isn't too labour intensive even when playing for free but earning those valuable cert points (xp) is much easier when you work as part of a team and listen to the leadership, you'll be more likely to be in the right place at the right time.  Anyway, its free to play and provided you're not afraid to adjust your style as circumstances change during a fight (sometimes your favourite tank just isn't useful!) you'll last long enough to earn plenty of cert points.  Join the Terran Republic today!

Planetside 2 is a fun, free2play game. It takes an interesting stance on an MMO. It turns everything into a constantly changing warzone that you, the player, can affect. Choose your faction from three very good looking ones, Vanu Sovereignty, New Conglomerate, and Terran Republic. (I'm a New Conglomerate guy.) It is very easy to jump into, although the tutorial is kind of annoying, it goes by fast. Some downsides are that some items need to be purchased with premium currency (Daybreak Cash). Other than this, it is a really fun game and I 100% recommend it!

They tend to zerg, and as they are nocturnal, the Vanu army is a fearsome sight in the day, clad in purple-black pajamas of spandex and NC tears. At night, however, they are far worse. New Conglomerate - They're pretty cool, though their bullets tend to hit their teammates instead of their target. Proof? I was squatting on a very high sniper spot I won't tell you about, when a cloaker materialized next to me. A sniper shot from an NC player took out the cloaker, allowing me to go invisible and hide. I know because I was the only one there for TR, and no Vanu were on the map. They're freedom fighters that like to wade into battle up to the waist in bullets.  Terran Republic- Space commies. All Hail Arnold! Hasta La vista! \ I think we have the best teamwork of the three factions, and also, best color scheme (red and blue) only problem is we need a higher server pop. Don't suppose you'd help with that?   Also, this is FREE. No refund problems if you don't like it.

I wrote a review for this some time ago but after a while I decided to redo the whole thing.  Be warned: This review is long and in depth!  Positive: - 4 huge continent's to play on. - Apparently up to 2000 players per continent (so says Wiki) - Over 100 people can be fighting in one battle (I've been in a battle with over 150 people before). - 3 Factions to choose from. - Large assortment of weapons. - 6 Playable classes. - Many vehicles included.  Negative. - The 3 factions are severely unbalanced (more on that below). - The weapons are locked and you need to buy them or trade in game points for them which will be a very long time. - The faction specific vehicles are severely unbalanced (again more on that below). - Players... rude, moronic, can not play so love team killing instead and also cheaters. - Lot's of cheating.  Each faction moans how over powered the other faction is, I've played all 3 so know what I'm talking about. Ok for the factions you have: Terran Republic (TR) - (Red) - (Normal Mode) - This team is more like the imperial army from Star Wars, they are a large government that has military might and forces law and order on anyone. New Conglomerate (NC) - (Blue) - (Hard Mode) - This team is more like the rebels from Star Wars, they are a band of freedom fighters who oppose the stranglehold of the TR. Vanu Sovereignty (VS) - (Purple) - (Easy Mode) - Umm... they wear purple spandex! :/ They basically believe that using alien technology is the only way humanity can evolve.  Why are the VS Easy Mode? Well they have energy based weapons so they have no bullet drop, their faction specific aircraft is very agile and accurate. Also their faction specific Tank hovers so can move very easily and is also accurate.  Why are the TR Normal Mode? Well their weapons are very accurate but do suffer bullet drop. They are also extremely rapid with little recoil. Their faction specific tank has 2 turrets which can be fired single barrel or both together, it's also very tough. The latest release of the vehicle mounted weapon - The Gatekeeper - can fire with high accuracy, fast firing, no bullet drop, high ammo count... not nice for anyone on the receiving end of this.  Why are the NC Hard Mode? Their weapons are slow firing, lack of range or accuracy. Their faction specific tank is slow moving, single shot... in fact nothing special about it at all. The NC are apparently the 'Shotgun' group operating better with close range weapons but even their close range weapons are absolutely useless compared to the TR or even the VS! Because there is nothing good about the NC I feel that the developers hate them and just can't be bothered with them.  Now the players... what lovely people they are. If you kill someone then you get a message from them saying how crap you are, how you are a cheat or how good your sister was last night! If someone on your team is s**t and constantly getting killed, they'll kill you just to feel better even though they get no points or bonuses. Some are just pathetic f**k heads and have no I have no idea why they go around killing all their team mates. Other players can not play at all so they do the next best thing... cheat! Yes they cheat a lot in this game, from aimbots, shooting through walls to warping about all over the place. Thing is if more than 3 (I think) people report the same person then they will get banned.  Now there are a lot of negatives here but I continue to play (at least until I reach level 100) and have given this game a Thumbs Up. The reason is is that I've never played a game of this scale before. Over 100 people in one battle! Intense!
Its like real life: your insignificant no matter what you do.

I can not say I would recommend this, unless you want to spend a lot of money on it ... or an even much larger amount of time.  Shame, really. A true shame.  Also: Grouping with other players makes this game slightly more enjoyable, but still requires a LOT of time/money investment. Enjoy at own risk.

Planetside 2 is a game I really want to enjoy, but there are issues that make this game a waste of disk space for me.  1. Latency. It tells you your ping and says that you are running smooth but in reality you lag. My FPS was around 36-60 most of the time and it was still laggy. Makes it hard to play but is manageable like most games. Not much of a game killer by itself.  2. New players are instant kills. As a new player, you have very few weapons to choose from and there is a level progression that unlocks better weapons and other perks to help you survive longer. But here is the catch! All those players that have been on much longer (There are level 120+ players too! o.o) have the better weapons that can mop the floor with you in just a few seconds. You on the otherhand have to unload a clip on many of these veteran players, and if you're lucky enough, that's all it will take to kill them. Did I mention they can kill you in just a few hits? Yeah good luck getting your kills and earning xp to level up. That will probably take a year to even get some decent weaponry to combat these veteran players.  I have played this game for a few hours and only got 1 or 2 kills during that time, and that was just because the guys were standing still and had their backs to me. I'm not a bad FPS player. I've played Call of Duty, Halo, and many indie games that have shooting in it and do decent to great on those games.  I like the idea of the game. it is great and with some more optimizations and balancing I think this game would be great. Right now it is decent. For those who have the high-end gaming computers it is probably great.  I do not recommend to newer players that don't have high-end computers. The better hardware might help a bit.

Whether you want to solo or play in the outfit aspect of the game (better) Planetside 2 is a game worth playing. Planetside 2 dives your character, part of either the New Conglomerate, the Terran Republic, or the Vanu Soveignty, into a world of multiplayer FPS action. With this being one of the only MMOFPSs out there, Planetside 2 provides an experience that is unlike the common FPSs like Battlefield or CoD. The start may be a little bumpy (the tutorial isn't something to be proud of) and the first 9 Batte Ranks (BRs) feel very noobish, if you can make it through that, you will start to really enjoy the game. Make sure your PC is good enough to run it and go install this game!
If you want badass infantry, vehicle, and airborn warfare, with no time limits and no stop to the fights, then this is the game for you!

Why would you play this

By far the best F2P shooter out there. A lot of you reading this may be thinking it's 'pay 2 win' because it's a free game, but that's not the case. Yes, weapons and attachments can be purchased with real money, but there are no weapons that are a direct upgrade to other weapons. When you use a different weapon in the same class (assault rifle, LMG, carbine, etc) you will sacrifice in one area to be better in another - close vs long range, large mag/slow reload vs small mag/fast reload, etc. Also, other items CANNOT be purchased with cash - ability upgrades, suit slot items, etc.  Graphically it looks pretty good, especially for DX9, but it's a bit unoptimized which really sucks for a free game. I have an FX-6300 and R9-270 and I can get a steady 45-60fps with my settings in all fights except 96v96 zergfests.  The core shooting mechanics are very solid - the game rewards good aim and trigger discipline. That being said, you will still die to 'WTF was that crap?' because this is an MMO and enemies will always be there. Usually it's a Stalker Infiltrator camping your vehicle terminal with the Blackhand sniper pistol, other times it could be a Lockdown Prowler up on a ridge shelling the crap out of your armor column.  Overall 9/10.

Cheating if rife and due to the free-to-play nature of the game the cheats just keep coming. This game really only appeals to guys who wished they had been given dolls to dress up for christmas. SOE know it because guns you can earn by playing the game, but a new hat or a different patterned camo always costs you real money. Very clearly marketed at kids who love to play dress up.  The physics of the game are buggy as hell, vehicals flip onto their roof and explode at the slightest uneven ground and there is no way to unflip them normally leaving you in the middle of nowhere to suicide yourself rather than running for 10 minutes to the nearest fight. You are a super soldier but you can't even step over a 10cm ledge, and forget about trying to climb a slight incline - you'll slide down it to your death.  Due to client-side hit detection you are constantly getting shot around corners and through walls and shields due to other clients being hacked to ignore them or simply because the other player is lagged and their computer thinks you've been hit (also means lag switchers get away with lots of kills in this game).  The bases that you are fighting over are terribly designed and every 'improvement' that is made every few months consists of putting up more walls in the middle of no-where that make no sense. Basically as you traverse the world you can only assume it was built by idiots.  Fights are always imbalanced as people are encouraged to join the faction with the most players as you then get more resources (thus easily able to pull heavy armour, vehicles, maxes, air support, etc.) and basically then you simply take bases by constantly shooting at the spawn rooms until you win thereby not even allowing the other faction to join the fight. No skill required. Of course if you do try and choose the underdog you get less resources and if you do manage to get out of the spawn room you won't be able to pull a tank or aircraft or max because of it thereby unable to make a dent in the larger faction.  In fact the resource system is the saddest part of this game. Each faction earns resources directly proportional to the amount of bases they currently own which of course means the faction with the largest army get the largest amount of resources and can therefor pull heavy armour freely to continue to smash the smaller faction(s). What should happen is the amount of resources should be divided by the number of soldiers the faction has such that while the faction with the most bases gets the most resources if they have lots more soldiers indiviually each soldier should get less resources thereby giving the smaller army a fighting chance (which in theory with fewer soldiers each should get a larger resource share). As it currently stands the strong get stronger and the weak just keep getting shoved back base after base until they are locked in their warp gate and most of them have quit to play actual fun balanced games or have switched sides to at least lie to themselves the game is fun.  There are no tactics to be used as the game is always won by whichever faction has the most players. There is no point in ever joining the underdog team and as it's free to play you simply have a character on every faction and switch to whoever is winning (everyone does) because if you don't you won't have any fun or ever get out of a spawn room.  Also SOE keep 'tweaking' the weapons and vehicles for the worse. You spend your time and hard earned certs (and sometimes money) on a weapon or vehicle you can effectively use and then a week later it gets nerfed and suddenly you're unable to get a kill with it and of course - no refunds. You are now stuck with a weapon or vehicle that had it been nerfed in the first place you would never have bothered unlocking or buying. If I was a conspiracy theorist I'd have to be wondering if SOE do this on purpose - make a new vehicle/weapon and make it OP, wait for everyone to spend money on it, then suddenly decide it's too powerful and needs to be nerfed. It has got to the point now that AA can't even make a dent in air support even though by definition that is what it should be good at. And at the time of this review a newly introduced glorified beach buggy is able to run around destroying heavily armoured tanks. It's a complete joke.  Basically this game has zero redeeming features and even at 'free' the cost is too high. I suggest not even getting started.  Update:  SOE have attempted to tweak the resource problems, but it still hasn't changed the constant one sided fights. As per usual the 'fix' for resource came bundled with another enhancement that has made the game even worse still: Continent locking. Now 3/4 of the continents are always locked forcing all players into a single continent and therefor making the over populated team even more effective at ruining the game. At least when there were multiple contients and there was an alert the overpopped team would generally leave to play the alert and there'd be a period of time when the fights became fair and fun. Now the alerts happen on the same single unlocked continent everyone has been corralled into and so the onesided fights are just amplifed making the problem even worse than it ever was.  I continue to advise people not to start playing this horrifically unbalanced and unfun game.

ArmA 3 can be played in both third person and first person view modes. Many vehicles, including tanks, cars, helicopters, and quads, can be driven by players in the game. ArmA 3 also features scuba diving, where the player must accomplish tasks underwater and can hide themselves while submerged.

Dont be decieved by their claims that this game is 'free to play'.   That's total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  True, you can   technically   purchase items with in-game currency. But what they don't tell you, is that it takes a RIDICULOUSLY long time. Amassing enough currency (called certs) to buy a single primary weapon can take between 10 and 100 HOURS (not minutes) of solid gameplay depending on the quality of the weapon. Before that, you're stuck with B-grade pea shooters with recoil through the roof. This makes it even HARDER to earn certs because it's HARDER to kill other people. Especially as the game is full of used-my-moms-credit-card-to-buy-the-best-weapons type people. Hardly anyone in all my hours of gameplay has not been wearing expensive camo and wielding 1000/rpm uber-machineguns. Without using real money it's extremely hard to play this game. As much as the developers try to hide it, there's no ignoring the effect micro-transactions have on gameplay.   BUT WAIT THERES MORE! On top of all this pay-to-win ♥♥♥♥ there are OTHER problems too! Before you can even START the game you have to endure an incredibly slow updater which can sometimes take an hour or more to finish. AND on top of that there are 2-10 minute loading screens everytime you spawn! AND on top of THAT the game can be extremely laggy at times DESPITE the fact that the graphics are atrocious! Jesus, I could write a whole book about how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ this game is. Oh and you can forget about teamwork and co-ordination, that died years ago. All squads do now is offer you a place to spawn and die. The vehicles are clunky and handle like rabid bulls, voice acting is pathetic, weapons sound terrible, gameplay is repetitive and uninteresting.  Basically, this game is terrible.   To conclude (because I can't be bothered writing down any more of the infinite problems with this game), though it may seem appealing at first, and will probably seem amazing for the first 20 hours, this game is NOT worth your time. Trust me, I would do anything to get back the 100 hours of my life I wasted playing this. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME! I cannot emphasize that enough. With so many quality titles coming out, you can not afford to be playing this putrid turd of a game.
