I have played Planetside 2 for a few hours and have come to know this game as one of the most beautiful, well animated, pieces of ♥♥♥♥ I have ever played! The new motto of pay-to-win, as Planetside 2 so perfectly demonstrates, is just a way of bringing in social classes in video games. This game allows those who have ample spending cash to buy their superiority in the game leaving skill almost completely out of it. If you plan on earning your weapons and extra tech with XP, like most of us on a budget, why not take your computer mouse and insert it anally and play that way, you'll earn the required points at about the same rate and the discomfort in your rear will get you used to how the game will treat you if you choose not to give them money. Now I'm not a self entitled prick who doesn't realize this game is free-to-play, and I understand the need to reward those who pay to support, but the purchasing system is based to punish those who don’t pay. The better equipment is bought via XP credits earned by playing but if you don’t pay at a greatly reduced rate, or special credits bought only with real money or membership. To make matters worse, the price for the gear costs more credits if you use the special credits. This would be a good idea if the goal was to get players not to spend money and earn their tech, but this is not the case. It's simply greed as many of the cosmetics and avatar personalization can be bought with these special credits only. I played for about 6-7 hours one night and was rewarded 6 credits for all my play, and the next gun up for just one class of character was 200 credits. What, REALLY?!? My ire would turn to support with one simple option being available, a flat rate to pay to unlock all of the games content. But no such option exists nor is it likely to ever exist. The only option is membership at $14.99 a month, then they will allow you to level up properly while feeding you a slow drip of those special credits, meaning you’ll have to be a member awhile to get caught up. Now I don't claim to be any sort of ace gamer, casual at best, but my many years of FPS experience was completely irrelevant in this game. To cite one experience (that happened many times over) I found myself flanking a sniper. I laid about four shotgun shells into this player at point-blank range which gave him the time to change to a pistol (bought pistol, not standard issue, which is what I was playing with) and kill me from full life and shields with just 2 rounds. 2 rounds!!! Another great example was when I was defending a base on a turret, I shot at an approaching aircraft until the gun overheated (hitting on almost every shot!) and he was able to escape without even losing his aircraft. I then decided to try a back attack using the same style of aircraft I had just fought, and was shot down at blinding speed by a lone gun man and one shot. Now in case any fan (or anyone) reads this, I am aware that the game has been out for about a year now and that some of those players may have gotten most of their advance weapons and armor from just playing it from day one. To this I say;  “Great! I’m glad you enjoyed it and I’m sure you will continue to. But because of this horrible balance issue, expect the new recruits die out completely as there is no fun to be had in this game anymore for new players. Your game is destined to die and lose support as it can no longer gain new players, except for the people who have hundreds of dollars to spend on advantages in a game. And when there are no longer ‘lower class’ players (like myself) to play, their advantage will be lost, just like their interest.” So if you’re considering this game I wouldn’t bother, but if you have lots and lots of money and you want to show how that solely makes you superior to others, this is the game for you, you pretentious self absorbed ♥♥♥♥. Better hurry though, I have a feeling this game won’t survive too much longer. And if it does… I don’t think I want to live on this planet any more.  P.S. this is my first review EVER. That’s how much this game annoyed me!   Happy Virtual Hunting,   Mr. ♥♥♥♥     (Like it or hate it? Drop me a line,  Mdick.55.55@gmail.com)

A piece of UTTER GARBAGE! Progression is so lopsided you are almost forced to pay and if you pay money you get to use the actually usefull stuff. Think Ground to Air rockets are an infantry necessity? NOPE! Enjoy grinding 3 hours before you have enough certs to buy a vital piece of hardware and then enjoy realizing it's utterly useless because you as a soldier don't matter. Nothing you do matters because the only thing you are capable of in this so called combined arms games is slightly annoying the players in vehicles and maybe kill a few infantry if you take them by surprise or it's exactly 1 on 1. Not that you as the new guy will enjoy playing as a vehicle because you haven't yet bought... errr I mean earned the right weapons yet, You are stuck with crappy chain guns whilst the others rain down hot fire rockets on your ♥♥♥ or shred you to pieces with more accurate better gear. The most hilarious of that all is that in this futuristic space age apprantly a parachute isn't standard issue... can you guess how you get a parachute? That's right, forking over money or spend a few hours smacking into the ground as you eject from your burning no longer avian wrecks.  The three factions whilst supposed to be assymetric are quite frankly ludicriously unfair. Just take your pick between the steady aim no bullet drop hover tank or the tanks that drive on rocky terrain and shake around with every move and have bullet drop. Or maybe you'd rather have a gun with no recoil and a COF the size of a flea. Then I know which faction you are joining! Or wait no I don't actually because you can customize your character meaining I can often barely distinguish you from anything except for the tiny triangle on top of your head. So enjoy getting shot by your team mates... allot! When 20% of your deaths are caused by your own team there's something seriously wrong with the game.  Nothing matters in this game because it's an endless boring merry go round. You have no objective, nothing to work towards because your work can be undone by a single lone survivor left behind who can immediatelly start taking over the bases you just finished taking. The three continents are utterly pointless and serve no function. 90% of the bases have no purpose and are just there to give you the illusion that you are actually doing something. You go from base to base to base in a nice big circle or if you are unlucky enough to get caught in some of the countless zerg rushes going on you will enjoy defending your base tooth and nail and then getting... 0 xp reward for defending a base against innumerable odds for several hours straight... yeah this game can go choke on my disgust for it.  There's a difference between portraying a long drawn out never ending war and wasting my ♥♥♥♥ing time with pointless wanking.

5/10  Pros: -Free 2 play with the worst starting equipment ever. -Vehicle camper paradise.  Cons: -Broken hitboxes or hitreg. (Run behind cover after being shot? Guess what. You're still dead. Maybe you got shot in your achilles tendon or magical bullets curved around and followed you inside.) -Overpowered vehicles.  -Antitank/aircraft guns for infantry = garbage. The damage output is nonexistant the only thing you can kill with one shot is an atv. It should be called 'anti atv' instead. A tank requires 6+ rockets to destroy which will never happen when an engineer can repair the damage you did in a few seconds also enemies can hear a beeping sound everytime you autolock onto them which is stupid. Also the perk system will make it take longer to autolock onto vehicles or your rockets miss on the 1st shot which is unrealistic. On top of that air craft already get flares... so there's no need for perks to make vehicles more god mode. -Antitank/aircraft autolocks are too long and the range is garbage. Vehicles can outshoot you easily while you can't reach them with the autolocking system. -Overpowered weapons for try hards that have played this game since it came out. -Horribly placed bases. Oh it's enclosed by mountains and walls? Must be safe? Nope. Infantry can still get over the walls with jetpacks and vehicles can easily climb over the mountains and enter. Or some dont even have the over shields which allows enemy vehicles to easily enter the base and r.ape everyone.   Overall it's a badly designed game. It has serious balancing issues that need to be fixed but that probably won't happen. Stay away from this game unless you love grinding/farming in game currency (certs) to buy better gear to actually stand a chance...  Or if you do play I recommend pimping out a tank first/airplane cuz those are obviously god mode.

Ahh, PlanetSide 2. The game where you pick a class, scope out a spawnpoint, and hope somethings actually going to happen with in 3 kilometers of you. And even if there is something happening, you're gonna fail to have fun with this even if you try. For the life of me I can't go one sitting without walking around the literaly 100+ square mile map that's an unforgivingly boring landscape of a frozen wasteland. I don't know what it is with people and this game, I usually am very polite with reviews but this game is just something else. And don't get me started with their 'anti-friendly-fire' they got going on, friendly fire is force enabled on all servers, and every server hosts up to about 300-1k players, (dead serious) and if you shoot too many people on your team too many times, your weapon is about as useful as the mangled Toshiba Satellite I have in my closet. Yes, I ♥♥♥♥ you not, your weapon becomes disabled on the spot after too many acts of friendly fire. I honestly can't think of a stupider way to go about ridding a game of friendly fire, you shoot too many teammates (who look strikingly similar to your enimies), and boom, you become a wet stick of dynamite, a CoD player in CS:GO, a baloon in a bag of sewing needles.  With te previous and incredibly large paragraph said, I feel it's also important to address the weapons, they're more cliche then a squad getting eaten by an alien because they split up, as these weapons are incredibly cliche for a futuristic first-person shooter game. If you want a decent future shooter, this probably isn't the way to go. Anyway, I think it is also good to mention that projectiles are completely invisible and have little damage. I ♥♥♥♥ing swear I nearly spent half an hour going through the useless tutorial which is incredibly glitchy and painful. I sometimes had to restart the game just to make it to the next objective of the tutorial!  As far as it goes, I think it is safe to say that this game is probably about as entertaining as sitting on a chair in a plain white room. You barely ever find an enemy, 99.9999999999999999999999% of the time you'll just be shooting your rifle or pistol into the forward emptiness that is the direction of the enemy base.  That just about wraps up this review, I know I only have 1.2 hours on record, but I think it's safe to say that that's a heck of enough time to make a first look desicion on a game. 'Nuff said.

Great and fun game. I love the vast landscapes. Graphics aren't amazing, but that is expected of a huge game. However, it is a pay-to-win game. Unless you are willing to pay money, it is very hard starting up when people dominate you with their paid guns. I would rather have this game be 60 bucks and then have no in-game purchases to make things fair for players. Because this game is a pay-to-win and basically enables some people to be overpowered, I can't recommend this becasue of the difficulty playing against these players.  Edit: I have been playing video games for well over 10 years and PC games for 7 years. I went (I think)9-4 KD in a match. It isn't that I am not good, it is that my deaths were caused becasue somebody had a higher power weapon that you have to pay for. It made me frustrated when I shot the person first (and continued hitting them) but because they spent money, they had the upper hand and killed me. I kept doing the 'How did they kill me first!?!' reaction and realized that they paid for weapons. Some people might say, 'Well then just pay 60 bucks then', but that isn't the point. It doesn't matter if I pay 60 bucks because somebody would have paid 120 bucks and still be better because they had the better guns. Whoever pays the most will have the upper hand. I won't put my money into an endless spending competition.

Can see why this game lost 2/3rds of its players.  This was never a great game to begin with, and has only gotten worse. /rant. The character creation process is bugged with server roulette and missing tutorials, unlocks are a pay2win grind, classes - factions - and vehicles are all unbalanced, every class needs a jetpack, no prone, ADS and hipfire mouse sensitivity don't match - though they can be adjusted seperately to force such an effect, events reward a team for holding the most bases - thats the normal objective - meaning events are pointless and have no impact on gameplay, trying to deploy a sunderer is glitchily restricted, HUDs for healing and repairs glitchily disappear, putting down turrets doesn't work in 90% of places, friendly player markers don't show half the time - especially on vehicles, night doesn't get darker - just bluer, graphic and network performance is terrible, as is the patcher, constant loading screens, servers crash, gameplay is a confusing mess, the HUD is littered with icons, none of which are useful, friendly fire is always enabled, dying feels super clunky, kill trades, insta-deaths, unrewarded assists, inaccurate hit markers, reviving isn't effectively communicated, every death feels quick cheap unexpected and unfair, enemies can camp vehicle hubs with mines - instantly spawn killing you, way-points are only marked by colors (not relevant letters), same for base names, all bases are made of the same handful of repeated buildings, maps are huge but mostly wasted space, like MGSV you can only attack bases from preset roads, vehicles are pretty much guaranteed to explode if taken off-road, spawn systems and map flow are terribly designed (though instant-action is probably the only good feature ever added),  everything screams unintuitive . And SoE was sold off after H1Z1. /rantForever

I will never recommend this game to anyone. It's far beyond broken and uneven; saying that would mean it was once a pieced together & functioning game. CONS:  Pay 2 Win period. Don't waste your time. (Boosters not sustainable by regular play). However you can after an extreme amount of time get most of what 'paying' will get, except the formentioned boosters.  Some weapons/upgrades are however Pay Only, however they seem to be niche more so than OP, from my limited time experiencing them.  Combat can be poor. At times one on one both players can put a clip into eachothers face and live, and other times it can be near insant death. Of course weapons made for this will vary with results, however this can be experienced with the same gun with varying results, with no explaination. (However that is semi-realistic at least right?)  Otherwise the game is poorly optimised and will tax most systems as if it were 4x as intensive as it actually is.  PROS:  You can obtain *most* things freely. But there are options you can not (excluding skins, they are somewhat usefull, but being lit up like a christmas tree they rarely matter). The biggest here is maintaining charge for the boosters.  The battles can scale from 1 on 1 to 200 v 200 in moments.  A pro and a con at the same time; squads make a huge difference and can make a battle on their own. WIthout good squads your team is likely guaranteed to fail. And with a squad, one can expect performance to scale from a 25 to 200% boost if teamwork is used. This can be a bad point too as the team without co-ordination is easily crushed and makes it heavily unbalanced. (So get some leadership fast or sink with the ship).  Conclusion:  (Opinion) The game is unique, and is worth trying, if Pay 2 Win isn't a huge sticking point for you. If it is as for many, it is painful.   The new mining offers near non combat opportunities for players to contribute to their team, although the hive system leaves a bit to be desired. Expect massive cert walls to the bases as usual, and necessary items are again cert blocked like proper anti-air or repair. (Same with anti-air for soldiers). Again, long time playing can buy you those however.  The game needs a massive performance overhaul as comparable and even far more taxing games run on a scale of 3-5x faster, so there is no excuse other than the work it would take to bring the game up to pace.

PlanetSide 2 is a massively multiplayer online first-person-shooter.  Pros:   -It was a very pretty and graphically pleasing game for its time.  Cons:  -It is basically a pay2win game due to the impossibble length of time needed to level up.  -While the player base may have ONCE been mature, now there only remain teabagging 7 year-old turdburglers.  -If they aren't 7, the players usually have devoted every ounce of time and are far too overpowered to begin.  -It has a dying fanbase due to this styl of game not being revolutionary.  -Loadouts are limited as all guns look and act almost the same.  -Teamkillers are rampant, and so is spawn camping (Can't go out of your base without dying).  -Vehicles have TERRIBLE controls and have almost NO variation.  -The game makes you pay to level up (as said before) making the 'Free Game' More expensive.  These are just my thought of the game in its current state. I belive the developers have given up on this title, and that is quite a shame. There is a lot of wasted potential in this game. Almost no background or story makes the sense of pride for one team almost non-existant. I've seen a better story from Minecraft

My favorite first person shooter. Even though the tutorial is lacking, just look one up online. The scale of the conflict is absurd, and I will never be able to go back to the small battefields of newer FPSs. However, the main reason why I recommend this game is because you don't have to be a good at shooting. It's not a huge deathmatch, and instead is a huge game of capture points. While you do get points for succesfully killing enemies, you can get even more for staying on the points, reviving your fallen teammates, repairing vehicles and mech suits, and just generally being helpful. I don't recommend playing by yourself, however. Click 'Join Squad' when you spawn in. That will place you in a random open squad. Then, click squad deploy in the bottom right of you screen, which will place you as close as possible to your squad leader, and you're set!

This is the good old days of Bad Company 2 except it’s free. If you've played Battlefield games this will feel right at home with a few interesting changes. There's an interesting aspect to this game regarding a perpetual world with three continents and three fractions combined with a territorial map control objective. It’s a very interesting gameplay dynamic that presents a lot of interesting challenges and scenarios where some interesting things can happen. The three main forms of combat – infantry, vehicular, and aerial – are all solid on their own respects and have some interesting synergy with each other as well. This game is fun I’ll say that much.

Jesu, where to begin?  Planetside 2 is simply amazing, long story short.  Pros: +MASSIVE battles for bases, resources, entire land masses. +Completely free to play- No need to drop a single cent if you don't want to +Very fun, fast paced gameplay with insane firefights  Cons: -Very resource heavy, and if you're not running a well built rig your game will stutter and lag, even on the lowest settings. -LEARNING CLIFF. No, seriously. CLIFF. -Can and will cause one or more of the following: Rage quitting, shouting, swearing violently, TEARS OF RAGE, heavy drinking, frequent smoke breaks, soiled pants, increased heart rate, meatsweats, sobbing quietly, anal diamonds, general hatred of everyone not on your side, and a grant fun time.   I got into this game several years ago, I saw a trailer for it and thought it looked interesting, installed it, reviewed the classes and picked my faction, got hot dropped into my first battle, and was so deeply hooked it wasn't funny. Several sleepless nights and a half crate of Monster later, I finally put the game down long enough to take a breather and just go '...♥♥♥♥ ME this game is nuts!'  The scope of the battles is unheard of in any MMO at any given time. Fire fights ranging in the 2-600 person range occur all over the map, with battles lasting HOURS at times while players fight over control of an area. You'll often find yourself in a situation where your screen is filled with tracer rounds flying back and forth and the air is thick with the sounds of explosions, automatic fire, the screams of the wounded and the shouts of the dying. Calls for ammo resupply, medics, and spot calls on enemy players creates a dynamic, confusing atmosphere that does very well in drawing you in to the game and getting your heart pounding. It's frantic, it's fun, and I've had some of the best times of my gaming life playing this game.  However, it does have its downsides. Graphical requirements are indeed intense, without a decent quality rig this game becomes completely unplayable and may cause your system to release all the magic blue smoke with a crackling pop. Though completely free to play, there is the subtle hints to spend money on the game (use SC to get your new gun now! See how much more XP you could be getting with a membership!) and some (very) mild pay to win aspects. As with all games, there are some minor glitches and bugs that can make the game quirky (random game closures and violent sound issues being the only ones that I've personally experienced.)  The initial learning curve is VERY steep (be prepared to have your lives measured in the 6-45 seconds range, at least for the first couple of hours while you get used to things) which may and certainly has caused players to shy away from the game, as there is no ingame tutorial and additional online training is rather limited. Until you get a feel for how the game plays you will be frustrated as a new player.  The game can feel a little grindy at times (Cert farming being the big one) and does occasionally feel very much like a song on repeat, the dynamic, flowing battle lines help keep things fresh (and keep the tears flowing when your squad slips quietly into another zone and completely takes it over while everyone else is busy killing one another)  All in all, I HIGHLY recommend this game, as it is an amazing game and full of insane, heart pounding good fun.

Ok, as a person who started from the Beta of PS2 and has played from then till now and still does play on and off i can finally sit down and review this game properly...  I will be rating the game on a 0 to 10 scale and giving my opinions on just about everything.  Let's start with some of the best things.  Graphics: 8 out of 10: This game looks gorgeous, even on Medium or Low graphics, and it runs at 60 FPS on my slightly older box. But, if you want the pen-ultimate looking game, this game isnt quite up to snuff, as it currently does NOT support Nvidia PhysX particles anymore, but hopefully will in the near future but it DOES look great in 3D.  Sound/Music: 7.5 out of 10: The sound effects and atmospheric music are great, Explosions sound beefy, gunfire (barring Vanu Soverenty) sounds realistic and the music tunes that play every now and again (like the redeploy screen, and about to win a hex section music pieces) are great, and each faction has it's own distinct 'musical theme' with my favorite being the hard rock pieces of the New Conglomorate. But, the voice actors for each of the base classes' callouts feels somewhat weak, each of the classes doesnt have quite a distinct enough voice, barring people with voice packs that they bought with Station Cash (this game's currency that you buy with Real Money)  Gameplay: Starting: 4.5 out of 10 Experienced: 7.5 out of 10: This section gets 2 ratings due to the extreme gap between New Players and Older Players. Out of the box, when you start you have hardly anything, and are just thrust into the game, typically at the Warpgate for your faction, and you have NO clue what to do. So, that's already kinda bad, but with the lack of teamplay that this game requires without a Squad or Outfit, you die, and die, and maybe get 1-2 kills per life, before you get the hang of just gunplay, and there's still Air and Ground Vehicle play to cover too! This game should reward new players with Double Certs for the first 5 days of their play, so they can get some of the better weapons and diversify their arsenal without needing Station Cash. As you become better at the game, you still will die, but less often and you will find the class you like to play the most and get good at it, but you should play all the classes equally to keep your enemies on their toes.   Vehicles: 6 out of 10: This game has a good variety of Vehicles to work with, from the Allmighty Sunderer which acts like a moveable spawnpoint with a healthbar, to the fast Flash which can hold 2 people, to the Valkirie which holds a small squad and can move at VERY fast speeds, Each faction also has their own Faction Specific Vehicles, both air and land varieties. But, Vehicles especially Tanks are pretty OP, you can 1-2 shot most Infantry with your explosive rounds, and are in-general pretty brokenly OP. Flashes are probably my favorate vehicle to use mainly because you can stick C-4 bricks to them and ride them up to things and watch them explode like 20 people, racking up the certs like a badass (also i can be a cool guy by not looking at the explosion [sorry that was kinda forced])  Gunplay: anywhere from 10 out of 10, to 0 out of 10: Depending on the matchup of Class + Faction you can either have the blast of your life blazing through enemies, or you can just keep on dying so bloody often. Heavy Assaults are by far the most OP class, you have essentially 3 Life Bars, and can use a Medical Kit to add practically a 4th HP bar... They are like a tank, in infantry form. Light Assault is my favorite class because it is Mobile, and has a great selection of guns, + it has C-4 Plastic Explosives, which are fun to latch on to tanks, and aircraft and watch them blow sky high!  Overall: Do I recommend this game? Wholeheartedly Yes, if you want Explosions, Gunfire, and Free. This game does it, it's like Battlefield, but Free and high tech.

One of my favorite games in existence. This game is immersive like none other. You will actually feel like you are in a war. There are battles being fought all over this MASSIVE world. Get deployed at any of them and FIGHT. When you lose an outpost, fall back to defend the next one. When you take one, march further down the front, and take more. It is first person, and everything you do effects the tide of war. It APPEARS pay to win, but it really isn't. I can confirm this because I went to go dump a bunch of money into my gear, and found that it really was a waste of money unless you wanted things like asthetic changes, or personal preference weapons. Really, the more hours you put in, the more you level up, and the better gear you get.

If BlizzActivision and EA games with their immediate, accessible hooks are the culturally omnipresent cigarettes of the run-and-gun world, PS2 is the fine cigar rewarding those willing to search for a more nuanced experience. Planetside 2 is a MMO FPS shooter which at first may sound generic and turn you away from this game but I have to say, this is by far the best futuristic large scale FPS game to date!   At first, you will have 3 races to choose which are:  Terran Repebulic: The faction that is basically the Russian Army if it was under better management. Your goal is to restore order and wipe out the rebel scum from destroying the Republic!  New Conglomerate: The faction that is America from the 90's but with the futuristic twist. Your goal is to bring freedom to the masses and force your freedom on the other factions. Literally that's your goal.  Vanu: The faction that loves alien tech a bit too much but does bring you some benefits. Your goal is to use your alien tech to better enhance mankind and destory those who do not wish to progress this way.  When you have choosen your faction you are given some customisation options for your characters but nothing fancy just templates. After that you have to endure a very..... very boring tutorial which then LAUNCHES YOU INTO THE BIGGEST BATTLE FROM OUT OF NO WHERE WHILE YOU'RE STILL TRYING TO FIGURE OUT HOW TO USE THE GOD DAMN SPECIAL! It's very unforgiving if you are not prepeared.  After that, you're in and this is where the game picks up.... massively. What you should do is to find a platoon or a squad so you can work together to capture objectives and earn certification points + XP alot faster. This game is clearly meant to be played with others so having a mic and knowing how to use it is just as important as knowing how to use your weapon. Also having a decent vechile is also very important since the maps are Gigantic, walking 24/7 is not an option in this game. Overall though once you give this game a chance you will start to be involved in some massive engagements that will make you feel either amazing or confused and annoyed.  Now there is a downside to this game which really will turn alot of people away, microtransactions and weapon purchasing. The currency for this game is called Station Cash (SC) where you trade really money for SC (£20 = 2000 SC). Now I don't really have a problem with this but when the weapons cost about 750 SC+ each then that is way too expensive! Especially when most of the weapons look exactly the same, just the stats are different which is a little insulting in my opinion. Also if you don't intend to buy any station cash, you can still buy weapons with certification points but usally a single weapon will cost you about 1000 Certs which is alot since you only get about 20 - 75 certs per hour. Just to add the cherry on top, every faction has there own specific weapons so if you intend to use an NC weapon for the TR then good luck to ya!  Outside that frustratingly bad part though, the game is completely free which is great! I feel that if it wasn't free and this was still happening then there would be a massive issue which would kill this game completely.   Ultimately though, this game is defeniately worth a checkout if you enjoy BF4 or any large scale FPS's. It will take you a couple of hours to get use to the feel of the gameplay but in the end you should have a blast!  ===============================================================================  TL:DR - Definately worth a play through for large scale FPS fans even with it's mircotransaction flaws  ===============================================================================

For those that think that Call of Duty is the best fps out there, and those that thinks that Battlefield is the best fps out there, listen, to what i have to tell you  You are wrong...  1. Scale: In Call of Duty, maps are often 6v6 (i may be wrong) and on Battlefield its 32v32, well in Planetside 2 its typically in the area of ~100v100, with larger battles being much, much larger  2. Map size: in Call of Duty maps are about 200x200 meters (i may be wrong) and in Battlefield its about 1500x1500 meters, in Planetside its 8000x8000 meters, and there is 4 of 'em now, with battles raging constantly, on each of them  3. Cost, how much did you pay for Call of Duty or/and Battlefield4? SOE asks nothing  So what are you waiting for?  Now for the more constructive portion of this...  You don't 'unlock' guns and attachments as you level up or use that particular gun for a period of time, you unlock them with the ingame currency known as 'Certs', you gain 'Certs' as you wage battle with your enemies, and progressively you pooled a significant amount of it, you can 'buy' a gun or attachments, or upgrade your class' pasives  War on Auraxis is waged between 3 factions  The New Conglamourate Terran Republic Vanu Sovereignty  The New Conglamourate (NC for short) is bent on being free from any forms of oppression, believing that a life lived in chains is a life not lived at all.  The Terran Republic (TR for short) wants to ensure that life is civilized on Auraxis and a goverment can be established so life would be boring and so on (pay taxes, rent and so on).  The Vanu Sovereignty (VS for short) wants to learn the secrets of the Alien technology to further their research and make weapons, more effecient  The attension of detail is very good, better than most to be honest and i must also say, its quite something to be part of battles the scale that they are on Planetside 2  In the first few days, don't expect to much on the area of unlocks and 'promotions' Battle ranks are far and few between (the level cap is at BattleRank (BR) 100)  The Comunity is very freindly, mature and most helpful. This game is...interesting. It is an innovative and kind of ballsy move to make the servers as big as they are. Unfortunatly, it just barely made it to being recommended. Along with all the fun you will have with this game, there are a lot of cons that come with it.  Pros: The servers are so big that there is very little possibility of a map dominating hacker (a problem that is severely under-reported). That said, the maps being BIG is a plus all on its own. The map sizes lead to some really fun confrontations. It leads a group (or individual) to use strategy in their attacks. Do you go in guns blazing or pick them off one by one? The class customization is well balanced and the sci-fi graphics are beautiful.  Cons: For my experience, there were few but fatal flaws in the game. The gameplay is not the problem, it is the way the game was made. The servers are prone to CtDs very easily. On a good day, I get 15 minutes of time on a game before it crashes and I have to start it up again. Now there are premium servers which crash less, but of course. THEY AINT CHEAP

I'll put it bluntly; there really is no game out right now Planetside 2, let alone one being presented in a Free-to-Play format.  The scale of battles is epic, with 200+ skirmishes (can you even call that a skirmish?) being commonplace.  The Free-to-Play model is the most ideal 'Freemium' model around; there is no Pay-to-Win as is common with many similar games, everything can be unlocked with Cert points earned through normal gameplay (barring nonessential items such as camos that can only be unlocked via real life cash).  The community as whole is pretty great, I've met tons of friends through platoons and outfits I've been a part of.  Gameplay itself is overall pretty polished and smooth, although every patch seems to bring its fair share of bugs, not unheard of in a large game like this.  My one gripe is how unoptimized the engine is for PC, its intensely CPU reliant, at times your high-end GPU will only get you so far. But things are slowly improving with updates. By no means let that turn you off from the great experience PS2 is capapble of delivering.  I kick myself for not discovering Planetside sooner. Play it.

After a week or so, I finally updated my settings to make it so that the game was actually playable.  I thought I was done there, and I could play the game all I want. I sure did. However, around the 550 hour mark, my computer couldn't handle it anymore. The game took too much memory and because of it, my computer as a whole got slower. Planetside 2 is fantastic. There is no other game I can drive a tank into a base, hack a terminal, call up a future plane of electric violence, land it just in time to jump out before it explodes from damage to shoot an armored super soldier in the face with a shotgun. UPDATE AUGUST 2015: Not much has changed really. Metagame could still be a lot better, still waiting on developers to make some meaningful changes, etc. Still worth a go.  It's a game that has me frustratingly taking it off of my list then putting it back on within a few months.  The gameplay revolves around conquest-style persistent map spanning four continents and thousands of players. This is Battlefield on steroids. Once you join up and have your first major alert or large-scale battle you'll be hooked. It's a beautiful game with some rock-solid balancing going on constantly. It's the best MMO I've ever played for sure.  The paying part of the game isn't necessary if you put many hours into it (except for cosmetics and faster unlocks) but I would suggest buying a few cosmetics just to stand out from the peons. It's worth the effort, believe me.  There are a few serious issues that make the game almost unplayable. The short TTKs can be frustrating at first, and the game is largely unforgiving in terms of tutorials. The steep learning curve may turn off some players. For those it does not turn off prepare for a terrible community both in-game and in forums, and an even worse developing cycle in which promises are constantly broken and information is fudged. This isn't a game you want to go to the forums about. The metagame is still being tinkered with, and hopefully by the fall of 2014 will be in place.  I'd give this a go if you enjoy any sort of multiplayer large-scale battles, as it does those in aces during primetime. Just make sure not to get put down by the terrible community and developers.

First off, as you can see from the decent amount of hours i've wasted on this game, I think it is pretty good. Many oppurtunites to troll people, many oppurtunites to be trolled, and countless headshots to be made. That being said, my personal favorite weapon is the AF-8 Railjack.   Now, down to business, this game is amazing, even on its lowest graphics setting. The gameplay is smooth and there are only about 10 hackers at any given time across the entire game. Aimbot is nowhere to be found, and ironsights often win the day. Grenades fly thru window openings just to ricochet off of crates back outside, and even though a MAX is a walking tank, it still get blown up nicely with a pack or two of c4 (or an anti-tank mine). Side note: took me about a full week to figure out that higby was actually the f word being censored (thank you devs).   Snipers make up about 33% of the total player population, so if you're looking to make some headshots, be prepared to take a few of those yourself. Light assaults make up the bulk of the initial assault forces, with heavy assaults trailing right behing, with medics and engineers throughout their midst. MAXes trod along well behind, their bulky armor hindering their maneuverability. Snipers hang far back while they pick off enemies at a distance (or rush ahead under cloak to lay tank mines ON tanks), all in all an excellent gameplay experience... BUT WAIT!!!  I'm sorry, I forgot about the ONE THING that all Planetside 2 players have in common, the need to be glory hounds. Yes my fellow comrades, it's completely true, once you get on the battlefield you try to rack up as many kills as possible before dying, sometimes failing to even move an inch before a well placed sniper picks you off as you spawn next to the sundy. This has lead to many mad attempts at revenge, only to be picked off by auto-turrets and heavy assaults in the process. Tempers run short and craftiness runs deep as players do everything they can to get an edge for their faction in combat. Whether it is parking their sundy inside of a defense tower, or perching atop a high-rise plateau to get a sniper's perspective of the battlefield, players are doing whatever they can to make sure that YOU, yes I mean YOU specifically don't make it past their base walls. Anti-personal mines lay in wait as you cross into the base, detonating and releasing a hailstorm of shrapnel as you press on through. And that's not even the best part.  Sometimes, if your lucky enough, you'll get put in a galaxy or libby that has a screwup for a pilot who rams into EVERYTHING. Yeah, I suck at flying as well. I've been in my share of fails as well, where the pilot miscalculates and rams headfirst into a mountain, or the ground (if he's THAT bad). Tank to Phalanx Turret combat is extremely frequent, and often ends in silent raging for many. Also doesn't help when someone with a good aim with turrets (like myself) enters one and starts sniping random enemies from a distance. Such fun! Pistols are a core part of the game as well, for who wouldn't gladly switch to a tiny revolver when he guns out of ammo for his big gatling gun? I sure would, as pistols have saved my life quite a few times.  All in all 10/10 cause great fails in this game xD   [Rate this review funny please]

At its core, Planetside 2 (PS2) is a first-person shooter. However, if you approach it like you would Halo, or Call of Duty, or Medal of Honor, I think you'll find it lacking. It's much more than just a shooter.  It is a team-based game. If you run off alone, you'll die and be frustrated. If you stick with a team they'll keep you alive, supplied with ammo, and provide other perks (like spotting enemies on your minimap) that make playing easier and much more fun.  I think a key aspect that people often overlook is that when you die, it's pretty easy to switch classes to something more effective to the situation at hand. If your base is being swarmed by tanks, you'll probably want to spawn as a Heavy Assault and use your rocket launcher to take them out. If you're trying to take a walled-off base, and the gate is heavily guarded, switch to a Light Assault and fly over the wall.   This game is entirely free to play. It is not pay to win. You can buy different weapons with money, or purchase them through in-game currency called certifications. You get certifications just by playing (healing team mates, supplying them with ammo, repairing vehicles, killing enemies, taking bases, etc). The weapons grant you more choices, but the default weapons for each class are more than adequate.   If a new player spent $5000 on this game, they would not have any greater chance of making a difference on the battlefield than a player that didn't.

In a previous version of this review, I talked at length about how, in spite of some utterly broken mechanics, horrible shooting, and uniformly hostile attitude towards new or casual players, that the game was worth playing. That a new player's first few bleak, infuriating hours being dropped into the middle of a warzone could be offset by the promise of some of the most incredible spectacles of warfare ever depicted in a game.  Yeah, well I was too generous. This game is f*cking appalling. In fact, it might be the single worst game I have ever played. Not because it isn't utterly beautiful to look at, or isn't full of incredible potential; but because how much of its potential is squandered. Mercilessly and repeatedly.  Your first experience of this game, past the hateful, broken tutorial, is being dropped into the middle of 'solo' play, which even Planetside's pathologically sycophantic community unanimously describe as 'really not very fun'. It's a miserable, directionless zergfest of epic proportions, in which tactics play almost no role at all, and attrition reigns supreme. You can join a squad, but all that really achieves is a few markers on your HUD and a measly exp boost. Your squad will likely be as directionless, bored and confused as you are, because that's all you can ever be while playing the game this way.  The 'REAL' way to play the game is to join an 'outfit', or a clan by any other name. This sounds like a great idea, but it's where the game's problems really begin to surface. Unless you're a high-ranked player with excellent twitch skill and kill-to-death ratio, then you can be one of three things - a medic, an engineer, or a burden. This hierarchy makes it incredibly difficult for new or less skilled players to actually enjoy the game. Repairing turrets and healing other players is tedious and thankless, and considering most players who signed up for this game wanted to play an FPS, it strikes me as a gallingly bad investment of leisure time.  It's been said by the developers that the game experiences a huge amount of 'churn' in terms of new players - that an overwhelming majority of players give up entirely before they reach Rank 8. Often in the past, on the Daybreak forums and on PS2's official Reddit, new players would air grievances similar to this rant/review, only to be branded as 'whiners and quitters'. This outright hostility to new players is perhaps the blackest mark of all against this game. While free-to-play, I nevertheless ended up regretting playing this game, not because it's a waste of money, but because it's a colossal waste of time. I regret every minute I spent playing this f*cking atrocity.

Planetside 2 is, still today, the most complete and interesting MMOFPS existing...   With nice graphism (even in the lowest resolution compare to other games) and pretty good servers (it may happen that you'll get a drop in ping occasionaly, making you feel like having a nausea because everything around is trying to synchronise back, but happens only when the servers are really saturated... which usualy means intense combats against hundreds of opponnents from the 3 factions at the same place... every team attacking/defending against the 2 others on one crucial place)   So, not only they have a good and smooth ping on all their servers, but for sure the fact you can just walk/run around, drive a wheeled or hover vehicule, or pilot a kind of plane/spaceship is pretty fun.... Every class has advantages or disadvantages and you will surely, like everybody, change class frequently to support in a way or another your 'Factionmates' ...   The BEST THING in this game is... Wether you want to play solo or not, you're part of a Faction, which will make you part of a family (with good and bad sides sometimes... don't kill your faction mates please it's not nice) ;) Letting you play either as a lone wolf, or as a team/squad/platoon member... or Leader!  The game is in NO WAY a PAY TO WIN... Arsenal you can buy from the store is far from being 'Twicked' and are most of the time, either only a little better or just plainly balanced. But may give you an edge if you chose them well 'compare you own style' of playing. You mainly pay for 'style/appearence' because you just want to show off a few things  That's why it's one of my fav game, and I'm not yet telling about all the good sides of the game... The bad sides... there's a few, like the fact there's only 3 Factions, there's only 4+1 Infantry classes, 4/5 ground vehicles and 4/5 air vehicles and only 2 styles of wall turrets being usable and 'only' about 60 types of wepons... and all this could be improved...   It's free, so if you want to make your own opinion, just download and play it!

Planetside is a HUGE all-out future warfare .. by huge i mean really HUGE ... one map contains usually more then 100+ players, that includes vehicles ... Customizability is pretty decent in this piece, however i've noticed little stronger pay 2 win basis, but afterall it wont really drastically impact your gameplay, you can still customize your weapons with very acceptable skills and points gaining speed  Pros of this beauty: - Tredemenously huge scale maps and battles (64 vs 64 battles, AND EVER LARGER ) - Very good optimilization - Dynamic and persistent world, battlefield constantly reforms between three sides, you'd practically have trouble to encounter same firefight at same place - Great variety of weapons - Sound design is moderately juicy, graphical design is very decent - Mediocore immersion - Quality feeling content, nothing cheap-feeling - Decent attention to detail  CONS of this beauty : - We know it's free2play, however having camouflages obtainable possibly mainly by cash is bit off the line, getting special armor with different properties? That'd be great, but not basic stuff such as camouflages - Missing balance of some minoritioes, as ending up captured maps by factions ( What happens is that just the game ends, pops huge-♥♥♥ thing on you to gtfo to another map or you'll die = not good, get players chance to done their game, and at least not able to be spawn again to conquered map - Minor hitbox issues ( As in any other game, attested and observed, 20-30 latency with no packet loss still gets you hit behind the corner, hitboxes and hit detection need tiny polishing)  There is nothing much to note of to this piece, i was playing PS2 just when it got released, and i have to admit it changed into VERY positive setting, and drastically ... get it! This is a game wich offers you either fun, serious fun, or hardcore, you can even choose ingame to filter groups that are for hardcore, serious fun or fun gameplay, platoons! Fun to play, I like the variation in classes that make it stand out from most shooters. The scale of the battles is wonderful and the maps are huge and varied. There's tons of vehicles to play around with. It combines the action of a shooter with the classes and support/attack features of an RPG. The population is sadly beginning to drop, but when you find a big battle, there's nothing yet that quite compares.

This game has class-based gameplay, aerial and ground vehicles, huge maps spanning three continents that contain dozens of bases and facilities that can be captured. You can upgrade your classes with certifications (experience, basically) and each class is able to do something better than all the rest. Light infantry have a jetpack, heavy infantry have a shield generator, medics can heal and revive, engineers can repair and place turrets (that have to be used - they're not auto), MAX are armored exoskeletons with heavier weapons and Infiltrators are sniper/sneaky types. So far, I'm enjoying it and SOE has quickly fixed crashes/glitches that have popped up. It's got a bit of a learning curve but most of the best games do. It's free to play (pay to win?) but seems fairly balanced despite that.

Awesome, awesome game with some caveats for newbies. All I can say is from an infantry perspective be patient and forget about unlocking any new guns when you first start playing. Play heavy assault. It has the most HPs in the game with the shield button.   Concentrate on armor/shields/med kits/attachments for the starting guns. Max out Nanoweave, Resist Shield first. Get med kits, forward grips, sights, soft-point ammo (if available), or what have you. Trust me that you'll enjoy the game much more and be able to endure long enough to learn the finer points of the game.   Yes, it can be confusing. Yes, the map can be overwhelming. Yes, not knowing where to go or what to do or where to spawn can be intimidating, but again, I would suggest using 'I' for instant action and 'U' and just enjoy shooting things. Everything will come in due time.

Considering the f2p aspect of this game, I would recommend it. It scratches the same itch that Battlefield 2/2142 and MAG used to. You can spend actual currency if you want to cut earning in-game currency or want to look nongeneric, but it is not a requirement. It offers little depth, minimal story, but that's not why you want to play Planetside 2. Ps2 is for pounding the ground either by your lonesome, with a group of friends, or in a mass of gunfire and gumption. It's a decent distraction and the lack of initial pricetag helps a lot.  My only real big issue is the netcode and how some players are able to lag around and score easy kills/ tip the battle through shoddy tech rather than any decent skill. It can be annoying but so far I have not encountered it enough to really be disuaded from playing.  Hopefully they'll release a Ps3 in the future that fixes this problem and tightens up balance a bit while maintaining faction uniqueness.

In the hands of any other developer, this game would be the messiah of FPS games. As it stands it is a game with enormous potential, but it has deep-rooted flaws that have been neglected for years.   My thumbs down has large caveats. You can get on this game and have a great time here or there, in fact I recommend it because there are experiences in this game you just can't get from any other shooter. If you decide to play it long-term however, the issues will grow on you fast. The largest issue is a general gameplay one. Terrible base design turns most fights into shooting at spawn doors. The way spawning in general works is flawed. Taking a base requires several mobile spawns that have to be created and maintained by players, without these spawns, attackers don't stand a chance. Therefore it is the defense's objective to take out these spawns, but as a result a fun and engaging battle will be ultimately lost.  Attacking in this game is extremely punishing. Everyone loves to head to a base and defend it, you get a fun firefight that usually results in a win unless the attackers drop so many people on the base you can't even step a foot outside the spawn shield. Attacking takes a ton of effort and the game doesn't help you out any. If you want to run to the next battle, you'll die and have nowhere to spawn except back at your base a mile away. If you want to try and deploy a mobile spawn to the next base, unless you have a whole squad of back up, your mobile spawn will be destroyed before you even reach the base, or maybe last a few minutes if you make it there. After all, it is the defense's objective to destroy it. So it gets destroyed, you're back at square one at your base. By this point the other side is trying to attack your base, but you do the same to them, and on it goes.  The bottom line is the funnest engagements in this game are so rare and fleeting that most of your time spent in this game feels like frustration. You might find a good firefight, it might last for 5 minutes, then a friendly squad may redeploy from a nearby base and zerg the attackers spawn and destroy it. You no longer have targets to shoot, and you're left with the only option of trying to mount your own attack, but you know it will only end in wasted time, resources, and punch a hole in your stats.  The funnest time you will have in this game is running with a zerg platoon as they run around crushing everyone during a world event. You won't be experiencing the game at its best, but you'll get to do some fun coordinated teamwork actions while making decent experience, though most of your time will be spent idling next to objectives as the enemy is hopeless driven before the zerg.  The best thing for this game would be a competitor. Major gameplay changes need to be made, but development has been slow since the business was bought out. The future is uncertain, and I can't quite recommend spending any money on the game.

This game is truly one of a kind, and I recomnend it to all. Planetside 2 is the only place where you will find battles between hundreds of players on one giant map, not a small confined one, a full contient to traverse. Planetside 2 is the only place where you will find such weapon and playstyle vareity, from driving a tank to piloting a jet, you can do it all. There are weapons cleary designed for different engagments, from CQC to long range. Whatever your playstyle is, you will find it in Planetside 2. The lore is also very intriguing, but not very present in the game.   Here's a short version: An expidition from Earth travelled through a wormhole and became trapped on the other side. Enventually they found a planet they named Auraxis, and began settling there. But tensions were high, with the discovery of ancient alien artifacts from a long dead race known as the Vanu, the Terran Republic, or TR, banned researching the new artifacts, and began oppressing the scientists who researched the artifacts. Along with oppressing new technology, the TR began oppressing everything else, such as corporations. This didn't sit well with corporate leaders, and they formed the New Conglomerate, or NC, and succeded from the TR for opressing them. At the same time, the scientists that had previously been reseaching the Vanu artifacts, seized the technology, reversed engineered it, and declared themselves the Vanu Sovreignty, or VS.   Each faction has 'good' and 'bad' sides, so choose carefully.  The Terran Republic wants to reunite the factions, but they are a dictatorship and rule with oppression and fear. The New Conglomerate wants freedom from the TR, but it is made up of mostly mercenaries that only fight for the next paycheck from their corprate leaders. The Vanu Sovreignty believes the only way for humanity to evolve is through technology, and they kill anyone who disagrees with their views.  Each faction also has different weapon characterisics. The TR have high rate of fire weapons and somewhat large recoil. The NC have low rate of fire weapons, but they do more damage, and also have higher recoil. The VS have mid rate of fire, great accuracy, and decent recoil, along with no bullet drop for all weapons except for bolt action sniper rifles.

Planetside 2 is a remarkable game for its time, having been out for a number of years now, and the developers are still updating it and coming out with new stuff all the time. Planetside 2 is a large scale warfare game where thousands of players choose between three factions, NC (New Conglemerate) VS (Vanu Soveriegnty) TR (Terran Republic) and fight on four continents, plus a small continent for new players, so techinically five. Its got great graphics, especially because of the sheer size of the game, the continents, and numer of players, its rediculous how they managed it, but its amazing.  Unlike many typicall popular FPS's of today, instead of being a run and gun game, its a tactical warfare game about capturing territory and securing victory points to conquer the continents in the name of your faction. It may include shooting as many people as you want, but at the same time, you capture points to capture bases, and then defend and attack, all over the continents, every gameplay session is new and exciting because of the masive amounts of change that can occur while you're offline. Its not for everybody, but once you get a firm idea of what to do, its extremely fun, even if you dont know what to do, getting crazy and doing stupid things can still be fun.  One of my favorite parts is definitely joining an outfit, and fighting in a functioning squad and platoon. The community is extremely friendly, with everyone looking to have fun. No salty people screaming at you over the mics. There is nothing like participating in a battle with 200 other players in a small area of the map with your sqaud leader giving directions and leading your squad or platoon to success. If you like close teamwork and territorial conquest as well as shooting as many people as you want in a never ending supply, or eeven doing whatever you want on your own without someone telling you what to do, this game is for you. Good Luck and Have Fun.

2000 hours in game (not through steam). BR 106, 86, and 15. Never boring. So many things to do. Fly a plane? SUre. Drive an ATV? Go for it. Smush tanks with a galaxy troop transport? Why not. Planetside 2 provides an adrenaline-filled, massive warzone with plenty of hours of enjoyment. Factions commonly use tactics to win battles, whether it be a decisive flank, or simply deciding to knock on the enemy's doorstep. The best part though is that there are hundreds of players shooting eachother. Unfortunately, without a friend, the game may feel somewhat boring after awhile, so it is best to hook up with a group/clan for more enjoyment, though that is my opinion. Also, leveling up and purchasing weapons truly can feel like a grind, especially if you're not willing to fork out $10 for that new rifle. While it is possible to get a new weapon without spending money, it almost feels like it simply isn't worth spending hours and hours, possibly a week or more depending on skill level to get a new weapon.

If you like massive battles, this is THE game to play. If you're familiar with Battlefield and the old Tribes multiplayer (or even, to some extent, the old multiplayer for Unreal:Awakening), it's just like those, but persistent. The map is giant and there could be 3 + large battles going on in different areas. You can literally walk away from a battle, travel for 5 minutes and come across an entirely different battle going on. Join a squad or be a lone wolf.   Not a bad learning curve at all. Again, it's like Tribes and Battlefield. If you're an FPS player, you're gtg.  On the technical side, the network code must be top notch. I've not experienced any issues connecting and playing. Graphics look great and it's not a process hog (but I'm sure the machine you're playing on will decide that for you). The menu system for your character, deploying and stats is intuitive. Everything seems to have been designed to let you jump in and play.  Negatives: none so far. Of course, if you're a COD twitch player who enjoys running around in circles shooting the same guy over and over, then this will be different for you. Not knocking COD players, I'm just more into objectives and working hard for them.  Bottom Line: It's free, it's worth hours & hours of your life. If you haven't tried it yet, give it an hour and play. This might be the first Free To Play game that I drop money on.

For anyone who enjoys open-area FPSs, this game is a must-try. Offering several different classes that are designed to fit to your play style, the game offers a tutorial that is detailed without dragging on and on for hours. The game doesn't rely too heavily on team combat and strategizing, but it does bring a little of both into the game. Offering three expansive maps, each with their own combat hotspots, the game gives you the ability to explore and look for your own ways to exploit enemy weaknesses. While this game is not strategy-based, it is not meant to be rushed into. Any kind of player that usually rushes into everything with guns blazing will likely not survive more than a few minutes at best in combat. My only true gripe about the game is that I think combat could be a little more extensive. I get that this is a Free-to-Play game, but ground fights usually depend on who can get their guns firing the fastest. However, the combat is not a huge problem, since it is still enjoyable, and the varied classes offer a decent amount of replayability.

Planetside 2, PlanetSide 2. What a game. Let's start with this: the graphics are beautiful. You can see the hair on enemy's chins waving around in the wind. This is no ordinary FPS game either. With it's unique futuristic twist on an ever-raging war, this game is in all ways, epic. You can ride an array of vehicles, from ATVs to Tanks to MAXes. The game has an array of highly customizable classes, which provide tons of fun. There's nothing more satisfying than slamming your ship into another ship, and at the last second jumping out, only to starting holding down [Space] (the 'Light Assault''s special ability of JETPACK can be accesed this way) and slowly drifting to the ground. This game is in all ways, great. The goal is to take over the entire planet, which has never happened in my history of playing this game. No one really wins, because there are over 300 players per continent per planet! There are three factions as well, the rebels, the techies, and the Earth Lovers. The best part of it all though... IT'S FREE TO PLLLLLLLLLAAAAAAAAAAAAAYYYY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

PlanetSide 2 is one of the best F2P FPS I have ever played. The sheer scale of the battles is unmatched by any FPS known to date. However saying that, there are a few problems that I have about this game...  There are three factions, each one has different weapons, armours, vehicles etc, and there are three large worlds to control. Each world is arranged in a hexagonal pyramid layout and players must control sectors. I used to think Battlefield 3/4 had large battles, but this is just insane! Saying that, large battles often become disorganised, and during my experiences playing, I found that once your forces mount a large scale assault on an enemy fortification they will almost immediately be destroyed by waves of enemy tanks. Teamwork is the key to winning, and in my time playing I have not find anyone whos taken leadership roles. Perhaps they should add that, leaders who command units where to go, it would make up for some great strategic battles that no other FPS has.  To add to infantry, players can also spawn and use ground vehicles including tanks and of course aircraft. Ground vehicles include tanks, support trucks, buggies and quadbikes (each one has customizable weapons, skins and perks) and the aircraft are only limited to one fighter, one small transport and one larger transport. I found the driving to be very slippery and unrealistic and piloting aircraft is a challenge for new players. In all honestly, using aircraft is rather pointless in contested sectors, since there are so much god damn AA tanks and units, but if you manage to be the last aircraft in the air, and you have friends controlling the cannons you can rack up some easy kills (since the Shredder cannon on the smaller transport is OP as hell.)  But one of the things I did not enjoy was the combat. With so much people shooting, and so much action it is difficult to keep track of enemies, and when you do finally get a kill it isn't as satisfying. Plus another nuisicance was the lack of useful hit detection! I want to know where I'm getting shot, and I would love to see some blood or something covering my screen to show that I'm injured! Instead you have a healthbar, and you have to keep looking at it to keep track of your health. The combat could be improved on so many levels.  Bu even worse was the fact that there is absolutely NO leadership mechanic. In one of the battles we took part of, our team (Terran) was fighting to take back a biolab from the rebels. If you don't know what a biolab is, it's a giant dome standing on a couple of legs. They offer HUGE strategic advantage to the team that's stationed there, and in this case our team was losing badly. We were all trapped in the spawn room inside the biolab. Every single exit into the facilty was covered by at least 10 NG soldiers, and if you so much as put your shoulder out into the fire you'd probably get shot at and die. What the game needs is to add leader classes, where veteran PS2 players can give commands to their team, such as to push in this area or send the heavies and medics behind them etc... and if people follow those orders they get some sort of award such as XP or money. That way, organising assaults on enemy bases would be so much more organised and less chaotic, and when there are enemy leaders on the other side it would make for some really interesting games.  Despite the slippery driving mechanics and the rather unfun combat, I found this game to be absolutely epic. If your team finally manage to form an organised host, prepare to see some serious action!

This is one of the best shooter MMO games I have played. It has intense furturistic action both on the ground and in vehicles that you can drive anywhere you want around the map. The game is completely self explanatory and in my opinion you don't need to waste an hour on the tutorals. You gain certification points (certs) from killing people and destroying vehicles which act as a curency to upgrade your weapons and vehicles. You also have 3 types of currency (aerospace, mechanical, and infantry) which is how you buy your vehichles, grenades, etc. This game takes place in space and can at times have 50+ people (for each team) in one battle which makes for awesome action! I highly recommend this game if you like first person shooters and vehicle driving experiences as well as futuristic action and nonstop combat!

Long story short, This Game sucks (If you go into it thinking youre playing it like call of duty) lets make this clear: You will not get magical instant kill attack dogs, You willnot recieve missiles launched from the ♥♥♥♥ing hand of god and you willnot recieve an indestructible suit of armor. If you go into this thinking you will be a one man army you are DEAD wrong. This game is 110% abut teamwork and tactics. My recomendation FIND AND OUTFIT, this will greatly reduce the chance of you running into ridicoulous roadblocks (This game has a very steep learning curve) . Theres several rules for the factions in this game: Join Vanu= You are gay. Join The New Conglomerate = Youre a a shotgun spamming noob. Join the Terran Republic= You are the freaking king of the world and will instant achieve fame and success in both virtual and real life (Loyalty untill Death) . Rules 2 (Non faction this time) Dont run out by yourself, this is the surest way to get killed. Rule 3 Play as a medic or engineer, this is the quickest and easiet way for new players to contribute to the fight, while also having decent combat abilites (Dont play the infiltrator/sniper, nobody likes them) . Rule 4, Fly a bomber plane (that plane with 3 seats , 1 pilot 2 gunners) . Rule 5, Learn to apologize for crashing that bomber plane into your faction's mega tank colum. Rule 6 Avoid being shot by your own guys while learning to fly your plane. Rule 7, Play Smart. Rule 8 DONT FREAKING TELL ME HOW TO WRITE A REVIEW DO BETTER, I DARE YOU. Rule 9, Ask where the zerg swarm is. Rule 10 Always join the zerg swarm. Rule 11 ZERG ZERG ZERG ZERG. Rule 12 Always be in their base killing their dudes.

The game is fairly decent if you have good framerate. If you don't, support roles are more liable for the person but is somewhat still hard to keep up with the game. If you're around 30 FPS, controlls would lag about 0.4-0.5 seconds, which is not good. Having that mentioned, the optimization isn't very good. Compare to a game like battlefield 4, it requires so much processing power and only looks about half as good, but it is pretty decent. If you're thinking of sniping, I highly suggest you get a high DPI mouse and lower the sensitivity in game so that you can move decently without skipping angles too much. The game is obviously more suited for those who can find a group or an outfit, but playing alone is somewhat possible, and could be pretty immersive. The game is a pretty big pay-to-win, but the starter weapons that you get are fairly decent. Overall, I think the game is above average, but if your rig and your mouse can handle it.

This is a great game for people who like FPS on a very big scale. First and foremost is to try and join a clan early on so you always have someone to play with as you won't be able to accomplish much by yourself. After that you'll get to enjoy tons of action as well as feel like part of a big unit out to accomplish a certain goal. The game has a ton of vehicles and different vehicles per faction. To get new weapons/attachmenets for your guns and vehicles does take a while but everything you start out with does not really put you at a disadvantage. All of the weapons are situational with the starting weapon being a very very good all around weapon so even after hours of gameplay to try to get your new weapon it still may be worse in certain situations than your starting weapon. Overall, if you enjoy FPS on a massive scale and like to feel like a grunt in a futuristic **** storm this is def a game you should check out. One downside the the frame rate issues this game tends to have even with high end PC's but I would still recommend it.  Pros :  - In game voice chat (A must for coordination and best VOIP I've expirienced in any FPS) - Massive Infantry and Vehicle Combat - Tons of Vehicles/Weapons/Classes - Persistent World ( Watch the Night Sky get lit up by bullets, rockets and lazers!!) - Mostly friendly/helpful community - SOE seem to be very involved in the community and keep you updated - SOE not affraid of hitting hackers with the banhammer - Not a Pay to Win Game  Cons:  - Bad frames still plague this game (although they claim they are working on it) - Depending on your time of play faction population may be imbalanced on certain servers - Earning Certs for weapons/attachments is time consuming - Balance issues ranging from faction to faction - Game crashes from time to time

This is the dream shooter if you're a certain type of player. It fulfills the promise of Battlefield 2. Remember squad based com and objectives setting? Remember driving to the front in a variety of vehicles while planning strategy? And large scale? This game does all these things, and better. Communication, team strategy, opening up new flanks with mobile spawn points, a flanker class, combined arms, a map with strategic features that lives and changes, coordination in a small squad up to a platoon of 48 or several platoons, ...in short team strategy and tactics in large scale shooter!   What's more, they got the pay to play (not pay to win) model right and the development model is a thing of beauty. Here we have devs playing all over the game, in clans (or 'outfits'), broadcasting and generally dialoguing with the players all the time. Rich community. They have a roadmap where players set dev objectives. They iterate and patch nearly at the level of a League of Legends. And all in discourse with the players. Heck, there are many continents to come.  Other stuff: sniping as a real thing (not strictly CoD style twitch sniping), stealth against real human beings, vehicles (tanks, atv's, fighters, gun ships and transports), emergent story up the wazoo, whole swathes of the game that emphasies priorities other than twitch shooting (ie. leading w teamwork/objectives, hacking systems, healing, repairing, spotting...)   There is much to dig into and learn to up your game. This is a great, great shooter. It's f-in' free. Check it.

One of the best FPS's I've ever played. You can do anything ranging from massive tank assaults or you can take it to the sky and dogfight. This should be the basis for future FPS's. Also it's not recycled and repitive like COD.

'What is planetside 2? I live under a rock!' This is what you must be saying if you dont know what PS2 is. Planetside 2 is an FPS like never before. For one thing, it's an MMO with thousands of players. There are 3 factions. The rebellious new conglomerate, the dictating Terran republic, and the advanced Vanu solventy. All factions have something uniqe about them. Fly warships, make large scale invasions with other players, go undercover to capture an enemy outpost- This game is truly a work of art.
Extremely team focused science fiction shooter with huge regions to explore and conquer. If you have a beefy computer and prefer team based gameplay, you probably will like this.

This game is one of the most interesting multiplayer shooters I have ever played. It is an MMOFPS, to be exact. The game takes place ona massive planet. On the planet, there are 3 different continents which you can play on. Your goal is to capture as much territory as you possibly can. What sets this apart, is that the world is persistent. It is not match based. The round doesn't end when you take a territory. You have to fight to keep it. The incentive to capture territories is to get resources you can use to purchase vehicles, grenades, and other things. The controls are very similair to Battlefield, so if you have played that, you should feel at home. The graphics are also the best I've seen in a free game, but the game is very demanding. Since it is a free to play game, there are microtransactions, but the things you buy from the store are mostly cosmetic, but you can buy exp boosters and such too. Overall, the store seems pretty balanced.  The controls are tight, there are lots of players, and the progressions in this game is great. Best of all, it's free, so if you have a computer that can run it, get it! 9.5/10

I can not stop playing this damn game. It does have a steep learning curve, but damn the game is addicting once you get a hang of it. This may just replace Final Fantasy VII as the best game I've ever played, and I'm a sucker for great story lines which this game completely lacks.  EDIT: It's been just over a year since I first posted this review and I have say this game has evolved into something much better. Many players were intitally complaining that this game was released too early. They were both right and wrong. There was a lot wrong with it at first, but this being an MMOFPS, the community involvement was crucial in making it the much more polished game that it is today. The core game is essentially the same, but many vast improvements have been made. The most notable of which are not so obvious and are fairly recent. Those being the many software and hardware optimizations. There's finally support for more than two CPU cores and I havn't had a memory leak in many months. Having said that, this is still a brutally taxing game for most PC rigs and I can't recommend one even try it unless they can handle one of, if not, THE most demanding games currently available. However on the slim chance that one can run this game at max settings with ~60 fps, you'll experience one of the best looking and most engrossing gaming environments ever.

Epic. That's all I can say about this game. Although that is obviously not true since this is a review... Ha. Anyways, Planetside 2, this game has been out for a year now and may I say that it retains its epicosity very, very, very, VERY well. Its ability to put over a thousand people fighting against each other all in the same area is absolutely ridiculous! No other MMO has been able to put itself into Planetside 2's level. It has a good amount of customization allowing players to purchase different kinds of cosmetic armor variants for each class while at the same time, allowing players to buy stronger, faster, more powerful weapons for each class. In the sense of customization, all players can play as either one of 3 factions with each faction containing each of their own variant of weapons, and vehicles. But the game doesn't only boast its war-capabilities but also its world in general. Planetside 2 contains in its world a beautiful environment. A good balance between nature, and technology. If you're looking for a game with awesome multiplayer, an epic battle whereever you are, this would be the game for you.
