After playing this game for a while and seeing everyone else recommend it i have decided to play devil's advocate.  Now yes this game is a good strategic battles simulator and is great to play as a large group, it does however have some large flaws.  First of is that having numbers is often all you need to win, this may not seam like a flaw but when you are outnumbered to the point that you can not hold a single location you can be forgiven for just quitting.  Second is the huge drops in frame rate that can occur during large battles making it hard anyone because by the time you fired they have already moved.  Third is the fact that it tacks a lot of grinding to be able to afford the best weapons and equipment, unless you are willing to pay for premium membership or buy things outright.  Now as the is a free to play game you have nothing to lose by playing it and if i have not detrude you by all means give PlanetSide2 a try. Also have a look at the other reviews, as my option is just a point of view.

Planetside 2, in all honesty, has a good concept to it; you are on a planet, running around trying to capture specific key points for planetary resources as you play 1 of 3 of the factions that no one really cares about. This would be good, but there are numerous problems. It suffers a ridiculous amount from being pay to win and grinding for things is laughable, as the monetary amounts make Tribes items look like a walk in the park. I tried it for about 20 minutes, and all we did was hold in one position and literally run into an area and try to get 1 tiny piece of the area to actually 'win'.  Gameplay wise, its a basic FPS. There's nothing really spectacular about it that other games haven't done already or do better. The style of combat boils down to whoever can enmass the more overpowered equipment on one team at a time wins, and half the time you will spend more ingame time humping your way across the field to last about 20 seconds in the fighting area. It simply isn't a game that you can jump in and be on a decent even footing. The whole game reminds me of the Sleeper encounter from Everquest.    Its cool for a bit, but its just like many games in this day and age; all fur coat and no knickers.

I played during the very beginning of the closed beta phase before any of the optimizations had taken place. It led me to really find the game distasteful because of the consistently low framerate on all quality settings even with a machine that's more than powerful enough to run it.  After the latest patch (this review was posted on November 28, 2013), I've found it to be a lot more enjoyable due to the large amount of performance optimizations the game received from player feedback. If you're looking for a game to waste some time in, this is it. Plenty to do, lots of ways to play, a little unbalanced, but I feel it's a massive improvement over what I played during beta and just at release.

Planetside 2 sucked until I joined an Outfit.  If you're a fan of the extremely voice-based tactical approach to warfare, like Battlefield, you can take it even further with this game. If you're willing to spend a decent amount of time playing this game, however, it is almost a waste to NOT become a member, since the amount of time spent playing otherwise will be heavily multiplied, with the many members-only double xp weekends and free station cash given to members each month to purchase the otherwise monthlong grind unlocks.  This isn't really a game to buddy up with friends and play, unless all of your friends become super dedicated and set up a schedule to play together, since usually you want to play with people who dictate commands and tactics, and when you're friends aren't around, turning to outfit members is a much more reliable choice. The few times I've enjoyed playing without outfit members were when I played with other players actively communicating ground movements and such, even though in one case we were constantly losing ground for that entire session. The massive battles and persistent world hold up to make both an original and engaging free-to-play FPS, but if you try to hop in without finding people to buddy up with (despite the fact that people are always recruiting, but low levels can definitely get shafted, and putting in around thirty hours or so will be what it takes for people to consider you a legitimate recruit for a more skilled outfit), you won't feel involved or engaged with the battles at hand, and will probably get lost trying to figure out what to do or how to navigate the plethora of menus without spending time practically studying it. One final con is that there is no real push by the developers for trying new types of engagement (no capture the flag type objectives or anything besides conquer and move on) , and oftentimes instead of finding an actual battle, you find yourself sitting in the enemy's base just watching your teammates get blasted from a one way shield spawnroom for five minutes until the timer-based conquering system registers that your forces have taken the base. On the bright side, however, this game offers a wide range of vehicles--dogfighting is awesome even if you suck at it, and the vehicle combat feels prettey balanced at this point with the infantry anti-vehicle options. This game basically feels like a co-op shooter while playing it, and it's extremely fun and rewarding if you focus on the objective and follow or give orders from an organized group. There is room for epic setpieces (but many of those require hard to unlock weapons and items/upgrades). I'd definitely reccomend this game, because time flies when I play Planetside 2 like no other. And its free to play.

I love this game. I got this game approximately 1 year ago and even though I don't have a lot of time to play it due to school, I play it whenever I get a chance. You can fight massive battles between THREE huge empires on FOUR huge continents. Games like COD are okay for very small fights, but those fights get very boring very fast. Here there is no such thing as a small fight, a normal fight consists of around 50 people fighting for a base constantly and it does not just involve guns. There are many different vehicles that can all be customized. The best part of this game, it is free. It is also not one of those free to play games that those who spend money are automatically on top. You can play for free and you can still have a chance. I can not recommend this game enough to anyone who has a decent computer and who loves large scale warfare. The game is constantly updated with new features and SOE (Sony Online Entertainment) even has a development log on Planetside 2's website that shows what they will be adding and they even listen to input from the community. My only complaint with this game is that you need a decent computer to run it so you may have to tinker around with the graphics settings to make it work the best it can but other than that it is probably the best free to play game. I would even argue that this game is one of the best games in general, not much can compete with it. I have never seen another MMOFPS like this and I don't believe I will see another one like it for a long time to come.

Planetside 2 is one of the only game that the gameplay trailers show real game play as in for game like BattleField you see these massive battles with squads clearing room and stuff like that but in reality it nothing like that most of the time its just an arena shooter like Call of Duty, but with Planetside you get tank squads giving support for troops to get in and clear buildings and aircrafts dog-fighting or bombing the area.   Since the game is an MMO you can get reinforcements at any time turning the tides on the battle, your could be losing terribly but then a friendly platoon come to back you up and suddenly you pushing them back and the game doesn't just end with you capturing the base because since the game has three factions the other one can attack wall you are regrouping to push the other enemys even further then they come from behind and ambush you turning in to an all out slaughter with all the factions.  The strategic factor in the game play a bigger role then you would think (not saying you need it to have fun): if your in an outfit or 'guild' that plays the game seriously you can (speaking for experience) set up formations and other strategies you conquer the battle field so in stead of needing 2 or 3 platoons of armor and infantry you can use one platoon that squads have pacific jobs to fulfill I.e: having a scouting party to moving and hack the enemys vehicle spawners and then get to a ridge then start sniping and having tanks vanguard a troop transport to set up a spawn for you team then send the squads to capture the bases at the same time making it much harder for the enemy to stop you.  Planetside's progression systems might seem pay to win at first but you will see soon that's not the case for instance the starting weapons are not terrible like in most free fps games, I personal use the starting the weapons to this day and I have been playing since the beta. If you wanted to use new guns you don't need to play IRL money for them but it need to be said that some of the guns are pricey but none of them are 'impossible' to obtain like in other FTP games. The only things you need to pay for are camos and cosmetic stuff and how things are going you might even by the time you read this that might not be the case. The 'station cash' it self is not that expansive and I spent a good amount of money on it and other promotions and I can easily say it was worth it.   Planetside 2 is a must download game for me for some people it might not be their bread and butter but its a free game so there is no lose getting it and trying it out 9/10 game for me.

Planetside 2 is FREE. It's FREE and it's pretty good quality for such a FREE game. It's hard to complain about when the game is FREE, but the game is actually a little difficult to jump into right away. There is a bit of a learning curve and it can be kind of frustrating sometimes. However, once you get a grasp on the concept of how the game works and what you need to do or where to go then it can be quite enjoyable from time to time. The gameplay itself is best decribed as a mix between Battlefield 1942 and the original Tribes but on a much more massive scale. You've got hundreds of people fighting on the same continent so if you have a weaker PC, it might get choppy. The graphics are really nice. Very impressive for a free to play game. I really wish there was a way to win a game. There is no end to it, unfortunately. It's just constant battle you're trying to control points around the world for your faction. But whatever, it's free and it's fun enough. Download it.

A total lack of instruction and direction leads to a frustrating experience that only the most persistent players will find appealing. The polish of a completed game is wasted on incompetent or non-existent guides for what you should be trying to accomplish and how to go about doing so.  This game makes me appreciate the game design decisions in Team Fortress 2. For example, in TF2 a short video clip plays the first time you try a new game mode. It shows you the objective of the mode you are entering in order to provide you with clear directions on what you should try to accomplish.  PlanetSide 2 does not do this. Instead, you are dropped into a scenario in which you have no idea where to go, what to do, or how to get somewhere else fast. This last point is important due to the massive size of maps. Walking is impractical, so vehicles or redeploying your character becomes necessary. The player is left to figure out how to access a vehicle, how to control it, where to navigate it, and how to exit the vehicle. I honestly do not know if exiting a vehicle is allowed, just to be clear. Redeploying is done by going to a 'pause' menu, finding the map, and selecting a different zone to redeploy in. This is not explained at any point that I can remember. Where to deploy to is not mentioned either. Do I go to the front lines? It seems that I should, but why is this not made clear? And why can I go somewhere else if the front lines are the only places that I should be deploying to?  The first point I deployed to had no enemies, just a bunch of teammates wandering around. After minutes of wandering the non-descript base, I eventually found a plane to fly. I did not know where to take it, so I flew for a while until I came across what appeared to be a friendly base. I began to be pulled towards the base when I got close (I think I was pulled, maybe I just did not navigate competently). Thinking this was the game trying to 'land' my plane, I just kept cruising towards the base. I crashed, died, and respawned. Awesome time.  Team Fortess 2 has such clarity in it's objectives that I took it for granted. It is indeed possible to alienate a new player in a sea of information, menus, large spaces to traverse, and unclear gameplay elements. It is shameful that this game was released with no tutorial, and I suspect meeting a deadline had something to do with it.

'hey wanna join my air squadron,' as i flew around in my anti aircraft scythe i knew this would be fun, so i joined this air squadron. we had 20+ scythes, all armed to the teeth. we made our course to the TR warpgate knowing they were preparing a massive air assult. The figthing started when our squadron plummeted from the sky onto their unsuspecting air force. the combat was crazy, esspecially at night streams of bullets flew through the air as my highly outnumbers squadron fought to the death. planes were exploding left and right, but we had the upper hand when it came to fighter planes. we were cordinated well picking off warship by warship in a sycronized fashion.  Now i have never played a game that made me feel as bad @$$ as this one going into battle, wether your going in battle on foot or in a floating killing machine you still have the same satisfied feeling of having a massive numbers advantage. This game is not about individual play but it can be played solo, i do it all the time. yes there is a large learning curve but once you join a platoon they will help you find the fights pretty easy.  i would reccommend this game to anyone with a pc that can handle its specs, and yes lately the DC's have been a bit more common like once every 2 hours or so but still a amazing game; wish they had Planetside 3 out there.

Planetside 2 is a incredibly fun game, and also a very unique game. Instead of small servers with about 20-30 people, Planeside 2 has 4 HUGE SERVERS, like 500-600 people on at any given time. It is a great game, due to the fact that it is very huge and has many areas for large battles to take place in. Sadly, although there is many places capable to support huge battles, rarely do these areas actually see fighting. Most fights are skirmishes between 12-24 people to take or retake an outpost. The launch trailer shows this game as a game which is about a gruesome war. However, in game the graphics and the environment have bright colours and beautiful landscapes. All that hype of a war zone is gone. In fact, the landscape hardly shows any sign of warfare. Taking outposts is fairly boring and pointless, only allowing the next outpost to be taken. Only large outposts like Amp Stations and Bio Labs have strategic value. Adding more value to outposts and increasing the sense that the players actions have effects on the world and the war would improve the game a lot. 7/10
I recommend this game to everyone who loves a good MMO FPS, Despite the lag in the massive battles you get into the game is a blast! Literally.

Planetside 2 was fun for a while, the alerts are fun and weapons are very well diverse for people to even customize them with whatever attachments they had available at the time, I have played all three sides, so I have read the chat of the three factions to see their opinions on each other. It's gotten even better since Daybreak does ban cheaters compared to the previous owner SOE. However, of my many times participating in some alerts there are some things I'd like to note for people playing this game either new or returning after a break, which would be some current events that have made it an issue to play this game.  1. The poor connection to this is pretty known to current and past players as even the devs are trying to fix this still, however that's not a real major issue compared to what I have seen.  2. Even though Daybreak bans cheaters all they do is create new accounts and get right back on and cheat again, teleporting behind players and using aimbot at point blank with a shotgun or an smg I have seen now and again. They still walk through walls at times and are reported then banned just to repeat the process all over again.  3. Then we have the outfits, there has been a major issue with every faction's outfits. There is a South Korean outfit for every faction, this wouldn't be too much of a problem if they hadn't actually flooded the Connery (American West) server, usually these outfits control these regions during an alert so I have no idea why they are not playing on their own server, all I know is that they have become far superior outfits to the others and no one really stands a chance anymore while some of us even have to wait to get into some warzones as the zone is completely full of people because of them. There are other awful outfits as they have recently done nothing but team kill other players trying to help them who are not on their outfit roster as I have been team killed by the same outfit over and over again under different circumstances. The strangest occasion being a 30 year old man strangely screaming 'Bad guy!' while I repair his vehicle as he proceeds to shoot and kill me my character says 'I fight for Vanu!' and the outfit proceeded to trash me because I was the little guy in no outfit at all since I didn't meet the 'requirements' of having a microphone. I actually had quit this game because of this very same outfit with their try hard people and some even being cheaters or just don't seem to even have any simple form of common sense.  3. The Terran Republic has a pretty bad reputation of having cheaters join their ranks while the New Conglomerate is considered to be the newbie group and is widely disrespected among the other factions except for the famous 666 Devildogs outfit being one of the very few with actual honor. (Not saying there aren't really any others with honor on different sides but not many actually punish team killing like they do unless apologies are said and people are revived.) The Vanu are considered 'overpowered' no matter what the circumstances seem to be and even have been nerfed by SOE in the past.  The game itself is fun, I loved playing it while being around the few good platoons left. But the community has become awful compared to what it used to be a couple years ago when I didn't play so much on a steam account. I have seen games change like this before and this game has become no different. It has become from a fun game with competition to a game that you will hands down lose because of the outfits being so close to each other that they'll kill any other person on the same faction but not the same outfit just for fun with no punishment other than 'locking' their guns for a period of time and not noticing that the person that they killed was the only support soldier in the local area. As I said, I had fun with this when I could, but there was no more fun to be had and I simply had to leave. People will say 'Well if you joined an outfit you'd still be playing and be having fun as this is a MMOFPS game.' Well, I didn't have enough time to join a outfit, nor did I plan to join one unless it was one of the more honorable ones for fear of being framed for being a team killer while I hate team killing all together, nor did I meet the requirements since I was waiting to buy another microphone.   Overall, I have to rate this game at a 3/10, it's not the worst free fps I've played (The worst being Blacklight: Retribution) since I love how the game works with the people being specific classes while handling jobs like piloting and I loved how teamwork used to be back then but the community once again ruined a good game. I'm sorry but I just can't recommend a game that puts a new player down so hard, or veteran players being attacked personally for the things they do in a game by children or lunatics to the point to where they switch to a similar war game searching for a better community. I honestly expect this game's American servers to be taken over by either South Korea or Russia within the next few years because they are the few outfits I actually saw who seem to just win every single time over any english speaking outfit and almost seem to always be on the Connery server. Sad to leave this game in the dust with a review that bashed it, but I used to love this game, I played a day straight getting certs for unlocking weapons and other useful things. Now it's a game where everyone doesn't trust their own team and would rather kill their own team than work with them.

'Loyalty Until Death, Strength in Unity'  what can i say to someone who has yet to try PlanetSide 2, how can i put into words my emotions in a manner that will deliver them to you, the readers? Maybe i could write down some of my more memorable moments of gameplay..  Lets start with my most cherrished memorie  it was a very dark night at The Crown, but there were few clouds to block the light of the moon. Even the stars had there role to play in illuminating the road below us. We are the Terran Republic, i was one of a number on night duty. We were tired, after a hard days fight...pinned down on both sides by our enemies. across the valley infront of us was the Vanu, and behind us over the lip of the cliff had been the New Conglomerate. And as we were about to be replaced by the next shift, the silence was shattered by a thunderous boom! it sounded as if an entire mountain had fallen..and night,lit up.. suddenly the dark sky was illuminated by tracer fire, small arms as well as plasma trails left by the Vanus Magriders there heavy tanks, wich had the farther range... in the sky above the the Vanus Magrider lines came a swath of darkness, like a great black cloud. Scythes,Liberator as well as a number of massive Galaxy Carriers, probably loaded to the gills with enemy infantry. the call went out to every availavle TR player active on the map,they started to arrive, a trickle at first but before long we had hundreds, still outnumbered. the base defenders manned the turrets, filled the air with flak. our Mech troops standing shoulder to shoulder in an attempt to blunt the threat of the incoming aircraft.Medics and Engeneers running bravely through the madness laying down ammo here and there, and as the Vanus forces in the air arrived.. so did there ground forces.brilliantly timed, Mechs, touph, well built leading the charge, Engeneers behind them repairing them, Medics repairing them, enemy snipers, cloaked in the fields watching them, all there ducks in a row. Enemy Lightnings..there light tanks, aptly named for there speed, forgo thicker armor for speed and manuverability.by this point friendly squads had been formed, dishing out jobs for the defenders. great pillars of light, beacons placed by our forces allow air dropped reinforcements. a wave of us ran into the base and formed a line at the terminal, changing our gear for the fight infront of us, a number bringing out there customized tanks, while The Crown was an easily defendable position, it lacks the size for us to man a large group of tanks, our double barreld Prowlers. our aircraft the Mosquitos, exrememly fast, able to tumble and flip behind the hands of a skilled player! i put thermal imaging on my rifle, just hoped the fight dont deterierate to the point where its needed, we need to keep them bottled on in the valley. i ran relay, bolstering our forces where needed. one moment an Engeneer dropping ammo, repairing our tanks or mechs..placeing mines and claymores at choke points, next a Sniper, picking off the occasional straggler with impunity. mostly a Heavy Weapons expert, firing homing rockets and missiles into the night. friendly Heavy Infantry with there massive heavy machine guns, litterally spit lead at our enemies. between them, our tanks and mechs, a barrage of grenades. we held our own, there forces falling before they could make much progress, but we new somehwere nearby, in the darkness was a Sunderer, a vehicle capable of acting as a mobile respawn beacon..it had to be destroyed, so those of us most proficient went out, a group a cloaked sniper. silently weaving through enemies and relaying its position to us, now its time to call in an air strike, a friendly squadron of Mosquitos, armed with hellfires, unguided, air to ground missile pods, most of them had the night vision purchased, or thermals. making locating and dispatching the Sunderer a simple task. the fight would drag for hours, one side having the advantage, then the next. by the time the sun started to rise our forces had been pushed back into The Crown, the very base we had been defending steadfast through the night.our forces were splintered, cut off from one another, desperatly fighting to protect the flag. the enemy would need to control 2 out of 3 flags to take our base.all around us you could hear weapons fire and explosions, proximity chat screaming for help, the wounded and dieing needed the medics, those still standing needed ammo from engeneers. just when we thought it couldnt get worse, the New Conglomerate attacked, they had been watching through the night waiting for there moment. and with both the Vanu and our Terran Republic exhausted, there Reavers and Vangaurd tanks, lauphably slow but more armor and firepower then 10 Lightnings, found little resitance to be had and had us routed within the hour.  do you have the strength, the iron will to serve? can you push on when all would seem lost? would you give your everything for your kin?  if so then you have found a home in PlanetSide 2, a family in us!.

This game has balanced play, useful classes, ridiculous verticality, massive scale, gorgeous graphics and a killer learning curve. In almost every moment you feel like you're contributing to a part of something huge.  The drawback is that being a soldier among many can come with a feeling of insignificance and loss of incentive to play if you're just not very good at shooters. It's not a game that is instantly fun when you jump in because so many people will be better than you. Once you start to improve, though, the game just becomes more and more fun with every kill and contribution you make to the ongoing war(s).  Another note: although impressive optimizations have been made to the game graphically since launch, you still need a pretty decent system to handle this game, and things like draw distance and detail can actually offer a tactical advantage in a large-scale environment as those in PS2.

Everything is attainable in this game, and the massive community that fights inch-for-inch on every piece of ground involving hundreds of players and simple but varying playstyles distinguishes it from other free-to-play FPS games in this day and age.

This game is one that I have put a bit of time into. I generally put a few hours into it at a time, and then for a week or so play it often. After that I have gotten a feel for all the new additions, and move on to other games. That being said, I always come back. Its a really fun game.  Things I like: Class defined gameplay. Some games have 'classes' so that they can divide up who gets what guns or equipment better for balancing the gameplay. Planetside seperates the classes because it makes the game easier to play. For example, some people, (like myself) really like the engineer role. We repair vehicles and Maxes, give out ammo, and provide supportive fire from our manned turrets. (those need a slight buff I think.) However, if you like to be in the fray but like the ablility to flank, light assault is for you.   Gameplay: The maps are huge. I am unsure if they are 'ARMA' big, but they feel like it. I never felt like I was in a possition that I couldn't flank the enemy if I chose to drive/fly a vehicle around far enough. Base taking is a full team effort, and you will only be able to take the objective if the number of skilled players on your team outnumbers the skilled players on the other team. However, Defendors tend to have the advantage as far as respawns and cover go, so it could go either way.   I like the new feature that locks down a continent whenever a red alert ends. Whichever faction 'owns' the continent at the end of a round gains temporary boost to their purchase stats. For example, if you want to buy a Sundee and your team owns (I think its Indar?) You get vehicle cost -15% bonous. Basically, the cost of vehicles is reduced by a percent. (Numbers and locations are not accurate.) The currency is earned by 'killing' the enemy and by capturing objectives.   What I don't like: Sometimes the game can feel pay-to-win. You will run into folks who have spend a crapton of money and can just buy all the guns, accessories and armor they want, simplily becuse they have a couple of hundred extra to spare. That is frustrating. HOWEVER. IT DOES NOT MEAN THEY WILL WIN. STRATEGY COUNTS. If you and your team work together and play the objective, you will beat a time of lone wolfs with 'big guns.'  In closing, I do reccomend this game. It's free, *You can unlock everything in game if you put enough time into it* and it has some battelfield scale that not even the Battlefield Franchise can provide. 7/10. Thanks for reading my review BTW.

ok so i played for a long time really getting into it before i decided to review and honestly this game is very good machanic wise however to give you an honest review i must say if you are looking for a personal experience were you feel like you really contributed this is not a game for you the battles are always based on numbers if you go in solo you will lose and accomplish nothing the game basically makes you takes bases and push lines but it is impossible to feel like you really acheived anything by yourself it is severly based on team combat if your team/ faction isnt working together you are doomed to fail. I will give an example of combat that is common i this game such as tank rushes, galaxy drops and airborn assualt. first off tank rushes pretty straight fwd your team basically pull as many tanks as possible and rushes the base in most cases this is super affective but also leave the solo player feeling a sense of uselessness and barly doing much of anything. Second the galaxay drop mostly used on bases that are inaccessable by ground vehicles its done by getting your team to grab a bunch of max suits which are basically to heavy mech suits with dual heavy gund such as cannons or A.A guns you load them into a couple of galaxies fly over a base and the driver ejects you wich prevents you form taking fall dmg so a bunch of you drop center of the base and take it from the inside out but again this leaves the solo player feeling unacomplished as its also heavily based on out number there base as fast as possible. Third the air assualt is done by simply getting as many air born ships and simply flying above the base droping constant bombs and shots at the gates to the spawn point preventing anyone from getting out of spawn and a few people take to capture point while this is done. Lastly i would like to mention a very negative fact spawn camping in this game is a key to winning sadly i find this very anoying cuz you are locked in a small room for a mojority of battle stuck behind a forcefield that you poke out of and shot and hopefully dont get shot instantly or blown up the second you poke your head out. This being said even with the beautiful flight machanics and combat system i have to not recommend this game as it left me feeling like i wasted my time because i was solo however if you have a lot of friends that enjoy shooters and fly this game is definatly for you just hope you are on when your faction has a lot of numbers xP

I never, NEVER post any sort of review for anything, but this game in particular caught my eye. I've been playing it for the past couple days with my brother and have to say, it's nothing short of amazing! Playing for the first time, my brother and I spawned immediately in to the action. We found ourselves pinned down with a small group of friendlies in the snowy area of the map trying to defend (what was left of) our base. Outgunned and outnumbered, my brother and I activated our stealth field generators and made a run for it to higher ground, in this situation, the higher ground was an ice glacier. Playing as the sniper class, we managed to peck off a few of the enemy foot soldiers before friendly reinforcements arrived! Quite a few tanks and gunships came in from seemingly nowhere, with guns blazing, lighting the enemy force up like the fourth of July! The victory was ours! After doing a little tea bagging on the dead enemy soldiers, we made our way to a vehicle spawner and hopped in a 3 man dune buggy. While I drove to the next objective, my brother was in the gunner's seat firing at any enemies that would cross our path.     While that was far from the beginning of the adventure me and my brother had that day, it is needless to say that this game is action packed!   The pros and cons that follow below are strictly from personal assessment and point of view, I hope they will help!   PROS  - Very large map  - Action is non stop  - Great graphics  - Good fighting mechanics  - Vehicle designs are cool  CONS  - Game mechanics make your vehicle (whatever it may be) more likely to flip  - You have to grind a lot to get a good amount of certs (free in-game money) to buy a decent weapon  - You can easily pay your way with real money to gain a slight advantage over your opponent, but at the same time everything is balanced. (I know those two sentences conflict but once/if you play the game you'll understand.)    Overall this game is fantastic for a f2p. I hope my review has helped!

If you are out for some casual fun, play this game. If your out for interesting and 'revolutionary' gameplay, look elsewhere.   now, I'm about to inform you on one of the most effective ways to kill a game.  I've been playing since closed beta, with 580 hours on record (I didn't use steam for a long while) and the game and its concepts are wonderful on paper, horrid in excution. I've acutally stopped playing in recent months because the developers have repeatedly changed what the games core concepts where about.   When I started in open beta, the game was about squad or platoon tatics. The lattice system wasn't in place so the map offered alot of tatical options for how you wanted to take on the enemy. However, this lead to a problem for the devs, because big groups of players would simply go around eachother, with only skirmishes on the edges. So they introduced the alert system. The alert system is fantastic! it allowed us to play skimish-y when we wanted and we could all gather for a mega zerg when alerts come up.   that was the best stage in the game, and I would've kept play had it been that way, but the devs decided that planet side 2 wasn't about a whole bunch of smaller battles , with bigger batles tossed in here and there. Planet side 2 was about mega zerging all the time, with small battles being a rarity. So they introduced the lattice system.   basically, the lattice system prevented you from going around an enemy force, you HAD to defeat them, which made quickly explotable tank forces nigh impossible to besige , you simply couldn't get around them. This made the game filled with mega zergs all the time.   The problem with a mega zerg is that you can't be tatical with it, you have to be tatical within it. I was part of the max clan, and we pulled in a full platoon most nights, sometimes 2 platoons on fridays, and before the lattice system, we had power. We could affect the map and make a differance for the NC. When the lattice brought mega zergs, we lost alot of our power, we didn't even make up half the population of the zerg. If we wanted to do something tatical we had to hope that our OWN faction of disorginized players in the zerg, would act in our favour. Often times we would get screwed by our own zerg, or simply be unable to make a dent in the enemy zerg because we were too small.   put aside all the balance issues with the game, but aside the map design, all the bugs and all the little nit-picky things , all those could be fixed. But what will never be fixed, is the games ability to make a community of gamers feel absoutly powerless.   50 guys all in comms, a team speak heirchy giving flawess comms within squads and within platoons.  20 guys are in the air, 6 liberators and 12 revers  20 guys in armour , 12 in tanks, 5 in harrassers and 3 supporting sundies 10 guys on on the ground, engies keeping the tanks rolling   but we need more boots on the ground to protect us from infantry, and what does the zerg of randoms do? they spawn a horde of tanks, our force can't get through, its a traffic jam, the enemy attacks, we can't return fire because were choked by friendlies , our ground force is wiped and then our air follows suite when we have no counter for the enemy AA.   50 guys made useless by the mega zerg.   thats how you kill a game.

A great F2P game, with an annoying but not crippiling microtransaction model. P2P will NOT have an advantage over you except in air combat with their ESF fighters. I will explain in a bullet list:  - Microtransactions: you can play F2P indefinitley. P2P players get acess to cosmetic upgrades and can get guns faster. DON'T freak out! All guns are basically side-grades and what money you spend goes to personalization not power. You can get everything with the F2P cash called Certs. This is where it gets annoying CERTS take forever to amass, meaning that it can take up to 20hrs to get one of the more expensive weapons.  -ESF fighters: Purchasing the upgrades for ESF's with cash does NOT sidegrade them, IT JUST IMPROVES IT! its annoying. so either fly a gunship or cough up money to upgrade you fighter.  - Gunplay is fun, and every class has a purpose  -watch a couple of youtube videos, the ingame tutorial sucks.  8/10 alone, 8-9(depending on what your friends are like)/10 with friends/a squad/a outfit

Vacation to scenic sunny Auraxis in PlanetSide 2, which combines some of the best aspects of the MMO and FPS genres with some of the worst aspects of their playerbases.

Allows a one of a kind experience where you can travel here and there to find either conflicts much larger than Battlefield will allow you to do, to fights were there are less than 5 people, just need to seek it out.  tl;dr If you can break into this game you'll enjoy a one of a kind experience, but it is quite difficult and frustrating to do. Would reccomend going for one of the older Battlefield titles for scale, or Counter-Strike for squad-sized skill match ups.  pros:  Much like Battlefield, but on a larger scale, and all for free! Real money can only be used to speed up progress and buy sidegrades. Great class variety, and all are fun in their own ways. Lots of great sights to buy. Different factions all have their own flavour that effects gameplay in interesting ways.  cons: Instant action sometimes puts you in areas that were just getting invaded by one or two guys who were just trying to backdoor/ghostcap a base. Instant action sometimes just put you back to where you already are. Redeploying to a non-reinforcement area in the map requires leap-frogging. Getting free currency (certs) is a huge grind that allows you to upgrade your classes/tanks to be flat out better than others, or to have options that were otherwise unavailable. Zerg rushes are quite common. Entire continents/zones can be locked down for quite some time. Have a favourite area? Hope that an outfit (guild) doesn't decide to cap it. No real area to properly learn how to play or improve (Koltyr for those under battlerank (level) 15?) Bases can be incredibly confusing to navigate w/o prior experience w/ previous bases on the continent.

Very interesting MMOFPS with battlefield-like combat mechanics. Edit 2015: Unfortunately, this game has far less active players than it used to. Given that this game shines in situations with a lot of action (large player counts), this negatively affecs the game, as it's harder to find large fights. Still, the game remains solid. This is the only game that I know of where you can have HUGE multiplayer battles with hundreds of people on a side and a pretty open map to travel in. If you want sci-fi FPS action with vehicles, where the vehicles are just part of the massive battle rather than a huge problem, than this is the game. You can get pretty much anything in this game for free, with aesthetic stuff as payed for items. For a free to play, there is a lot here to do with zero cash invested. Having said that, they do make some neat stuff to buy, along with various packages to save you some cash if you want everything in the package. If you like it, give these guys some money so they keep working on it. Lots of things to specialize in, lots of different weapons, a lot of different vehicles, and all of them are customizable with attachments, different armaments, paint schemes, etc. I'm not going to bother explaining all the intracacies, I'm sure many have done so before me, but there is a lot here to enjoy. Many have promised a game like this, only Planetside has ever really delivered. It is a unique experience.

If you enjoy massive futuristic military shooter with hundreds of players on each side this is for you  PROS: 1. Game is PVP (Player vs Player meaning there are no AI controlled characters at all) 2. Semi-Open world (on the continents you can travel from one end to the other without a single loading screen but traveling from one continent to another will require you to go through a loading screen) 3. Amazing arial combat and variety of aircrafts (dog fights ,arial bombardment etc.) 4. Amazing land combat (driving tanks, Humvee, ATVs etc.) 5. Customizing these vehicles to suit your playstyle  6, 6 Unique classes (you are not restricted to play one class you can change your class whenever you want however similar to Team Fortress 2, Dirty Bomb, Overwatch) 7. Custumizing these classes to fit your playstyle in both variety of weapons, attachment for weapons and perks for the class it self  CONS: 1. You may feel overhelmed at the beginnig 2. Game is PVP (there is no AI controlled characters and NPCs or PVE content) 3. Not so fun if you intend to lone wolf the game is designed around forming squads(party) and platoons (raids) 4. Game requires a good PC machine because of the scale of the game and battles  NEUTRAL: The game may feel pay to win (though I highly disagree the stock weapons and decent understanding of FPS genre games are more than enough to defeat any enemy players)

Short version: The best and most non-p2w f2p MMOFPS around.   Extended version: A wonderful online shooter with a great progression ladder, it's definitely a shot if you don't want to spend a buck since only skins and infantry/vehicle sounds are money-only.  To add, all weapons are entirely balanced, the starter weapons are not 'better' or 'inferior' to any other weapon, only in different situations some weapons have preference (i.e. a shotgun with more range to clear larger rooms easier at the cost of rate of fire for example).  A tip for the starting player would be to search friends or an outfit (a guild/clan), since lone-wolfing will get you killed without revives all-too-often, and thus will halt your cert-gain (currency) considerably.  Here are the pros and cons of the game:  PROS: - Graphically good for MMOFPS. - Fun teamgame. - Big battles with more than 100 players on each side in an area. - The ability to upgrade your character like you want (you can choose what kind of mods on your weapon and character, for example you can take a suit which allows you to wear more grenades or ammo, a damage reduce-suit or if you feel like it, a sprint speed suit). - Different weapons on vehicles (this is much fun if you want to convert your light tank to a mobile AA and stuff, also the previous point about mods also applies to vehicles). - > BALANCED WEAPONS! < (the struggle of 95% of MMOFPS's)  CONS: - Need a decent rig to get 60fps on full graphics with more than 30 people and some explosions around. - By decent in the previous point I mean very-decent, a 700 bucks self-sorted PC with new gen game graphics (like the Nvidia GTX *50 (* meaning 5 to 10) and up to *70) might still have 40 FPS or lower in certain situations. - Hard to lone-wolf. - Learning curve if never played big battle games like this or Red Orchestra etc.  SCORE: 8.5/10 Never seen such a well-balanced f2p game before. These devs are doing it RIGHT for a change.

Im not into FPS so I dont love this game.. but i keep playing it trying to get better?  6 classes.. main difference being weapons loadout and armor and special ability. Anyone can use any vehicle.. from main battle tank to giant attack planes to assault choppers to motorcycles As you play you gain points to unlock/modify new weapons. NOT pay to play.. it's more like customisation. You can buy the upgrades.. or sidegrades as well. For the most part the 'upgrades' let you customise more to fit your play style.. though there are a few things (that arent actually that important) like construction that do require $ (construction is VERY rarely useful for anything). The world is HUGE. 3 continents with dozens of bases on each.. all very different. There is ALWAYS a battle going on somewhere. Though i dont think its nearly as busy as in its hayday. A very good player playing the physically weakest class can annihilate a newbie/bad player with the most armored/heavily armed class Aircraft are badass. Easy to fly.. hard to fly CORRECTLY (ie not die) Vehicles can dominate a battle.. or sit around completely useless/get slaughtered  Factions: there are differences between factions. I play nc (slow HARD hitting guns that kick like a mule) The differences arent that huge. NC imho isnt the faction to pick for infiltrator.  Try it . It's free. Put a couple hours in and you'll either like it or love it. You wont hate it. Expect to die a LOT. And quite a bit through things you cant control. Also: Stay out of the road... vehicles on your team will run over you without a thought

I'm currently sitting at over 96 DAYS of playtime and I can tell you, this game is truly epic, one of the best games I've ever played. If you want the most badass FPS with epic fights against hundreds of other players in a persistent world with infantry, vehicles & aircraft, this is your game.   It's can be difficult, even brutal sometimes as you learn the game, but the payoff is some of the most fun and amazing battles you've ever played.   To top it off this is probably the best free to play game you'll ever see for how they monitize. Cosmetics are cash only, everything else can be unlocked from just playing. To top it off, the default guns are some of the best in the game, seriously.   To give yourself a good head start in this game: 1. Watch Wrels videos on youtube for starters. 2. Join with a buddy or 3, watch each others back. Get in a squad.  3. Focus on 1 or 2 infantry classes. Watch some videos about recommend loadouts, cert guides. 4. Join an outfit that's beginner friendly. 5. Wait until you're comfortable w/ the game before you start certing vehicles too much.  6. Learn the map and understand when you're in a fight you can't win.   If you have a decent computer and couple friends to play with you'll be hooked, it's an amazing.
Not bad, Not bad at all...

Edit: Basebuilding and some new stuff  The ability to build bases around the map with the harvested resources, which every map now features, works really well with the rest of the game. The main goal is to get a HIVE in your base to generate victory points for your faction to win the battle over a map.  (There are many ways to do this, the HIVEs are only one part.) But a base without a HIVE is of use too, as its turrets provide additional firepower and the fortifications help slowing down the enemy advance, while providing cover for players.  The only downside I can think of, is the need to unlock a few expensive things, like the turrets, with certs (ingame experience currency) - but it's not a grindy game and if you played it for some time, you have enough certs anyway.  Btw, most (new) bugs have been fixed and the game runs smoother than ever.   PS2 is a game I gladly return to, if other shooters start to bore me and it never fails to absorb me for a few weeks more.  *** Planetside 2 is the best FPS-MMO there is. Massive scale battles with inf and ground+air vehicles, that no other game can offer, combined with persistend maps to conquer and defend.  Of cause there are a lot of minor things to complain about, but that's not what I want to do here, because PS2 improved a lot over the time I played it and it's still a lot of fun.  And the best is - it's free and absolutely not pay2win. It has the best F2P-model I have ever seen. You have to try it.  (I recommend tank or air gameplay if you don't like the huge healthbars the infantry has.)
The game has seen significant updates to it's content recently, and the devs are pretty responsive to the community. Give it a looksee!

For its faults or nitpicks still is the game for a real massive multiplayer war that exists nowhere else.  Of course its free and optional sub, try it, get hooked put it down try it again. One great thing I must emphasize about the way it works unlike say most liniar MMO's with increasingly powerfull weapons or armor, anything you start out with is good and effective at killing with many weapons being sidegrades, providing more utility in one way. Its nothing like say wow or destiany where a experienced player or someone who buys lots of things is so much better than a noob because of weapons that are insanly more powerfull, all power in the game is ultimatly skill and tatics. Nothing about the game is liniar squad matches, it is a continental sci-fi war simulator.  Honestly the daybreak company sucks, but..... this was a game developed before them and they have slowly added some extra things to it and not broken it, it is free from a good deal of medicoure development they have displayed in just about every other title. I won't negative rep this game to give a fair account of it, it itself, is good and has something lacking in any other up to date FPS.

* This review may be biased due to my history with the game. I will be updating this review when new things pop up.  My Experience with Planetside 2: I have played Planetside 2 a year after the Beta when it was still under Sony Online Entertainment (SOE). I have BR47+ characters in Briggs, Australia. Ever since there was little to no updates after the new continent 'Hossin' was released, I quitted like how some Veterans quit a game if it didn't meet their expectation. Now that the new Construction Update and Performance Tweaks have been placed into the game after the switch of management to Daybreak Games, I am thoroughly enjoying Planetside 2 again. Some of my old clan mates are gone but that is to be expected  Update and Game Status: - Lots of new content - Healthy number of players all day long (Briggs, Australia)  Why Planetside 2 is fun: - Dynamic Gameplay elements make it such that experiences are very varied (Can be a negative. Will explain later) - Its Free - Great Community (When played in platoons/outfits)  Why Planetside 2 is NOT fun: - Zerging and Spawn Camping. When dynamic elements are captured and seized by the enemy, most solo players will either ignore or contest the area (usually without help). This results in mindless zombies walking around - No friends? This will probably result in you not having fun - Friends with no experience? You're probably both going to get wrecked and do a deservice to the game  What to do when jumping into Planetside 2: - Find a INTERACTIVE platoon or a outfit (Outfits=Clans). The game is not all that fun playing solo - DO NOT GET TILTED. Having a low k/d is fine in PS2 so long you help out others. Playing support in Planetside 2 can play a key role in victories - READ UP AND WATCH VIDEOS. I can't stress this enough. Without prior knowledge of EVERY game mechanic, you'd be jumping in to a hell fire zone - Expect Zerging. PS2 still has a 'More people=victory' meta. Make sure you don't get demotivated from it and just spawn to another zone to fight in
To put it simply. no other fps comes close to being this good 11/10

Good game, Bit of an initial grind.  Wrel, on a certian video site, tends to have better details than I.. and tons of video. Catch some of that to get a better handle on the game because there really aren't good resources in-game for learning.  I have close to a thousand hours in this thing, some with a membership, some without... not a huge difference there, more at the end of the review.  <Review 6/26/2016, because it changes> ---Use VR training on the item BEFORE you buy it, use attachments too, and then trial it if you can in-game... make good money decisions, don't be me---  1. Daybreak, and before them SOE, took on an epic task to mainian balance without wrecking a massive game. Don't kid yourself, this isn't easy.  Every faction has (some) good starting weapons, the Heavy's LMGs are VERY different, but all surpisingly balanced, if you use the right tactic, and I will cover paying in on 'What to Buy and what to grind' (point 3)   2. In the ever present struggle to introduce new content, make the game balance out, maintain parity between factions, and actually make money (they have to do that too), they have lost sight a bit on the vehicle aspect of things (currently, and for quite a few months). It's currently a bit too easy to wreck air vehicles, in some situations Tanks are too easy to wreck with infantry as well.   Also, expect salt from old players. Some old strategies <some of them exploits> just don't work anymore and not everyone wants to learn new ways to play.  3. IMPORTANT! Buy the NS-PDW....I got mine in black(NS-PDW-B), it looks better, you can also earn it (normal, no colors to it), for ONE character at a time, this is why you BUY it with real money. If you buy NOTHING else, buy this weapon. You may shift faction, or want to play as more than one. This will help with that.  Get a camo for yourself if you don't get it black, (Walll Hugger is closest and most useful, also cross-faction, can only be bought) it will work for you and your guns as well, save some money and be harder to see in facilities.    3.1 NEVER buy anything that is NOT an NS weapon, cross faction camo, or cross-faction decorative gear with REAL money. (well, you could, but NS is a better deal)  BUY BUNDLES of NS weapons if you can and don't want special colors. Better deal, wish I had... Here is why. NS weapons unlock for every character you will EVER have with that account. If it's not attached to a tank, fighter, or related to the construction system, an NS weapon or cross-faction gear will unlock for every character.  You can still get them with certs, and if you are good, ddo that, BUT, you need to be unlockingg things that you CAN'T buy. You have to EARN your infantry armor, get it first.  4. Things to earn RIGHT AWAY (you CAN'T buy these, they change the game). Grinding gear, like  a. maxing out engineer repair tools, b. maxing out medic gear and ailites, c. upgrading (but not maxing) infitrator recon darts d. maxing out explosives proxies, tankmines, and sunderers (essential vehicle)   Absolute must ASAP after grinding a bit, or other cert gains?  a. Maximum nanoweave armor for infantry.  b. Deployable explosives. This should be an early earn, and should be upgraded based on playstyle. Engineer, this is a must, 3 tank mines in the right place makes for a spectacular credit gain, including a group kill, killstreak, and other bonuses on top of everyone you kill in the vehicle. It''s also fun, and delays reinforcements to your location. The explosives 'dwell' they stay until they blow up, are disabled, or you log off. They will change the game for you. Don't be shy aboout crowing to your squad when it happens. A good squad will recognize how much you just helped.  Membership It helps with resources and cert gains. It's not really pay to win, exept that you get a 50% boost to vehicle pulls. I would say that if you are bad with vehicles or go through alot off infantry resources (mines, C4, grenades, medkits...), that becomes a pay-to-not-suck.  If you are a decent driver and careful, you shoudn't need to pull a vehicle every 3 minutes, so  That's a bit of a guide and a review. Follow at least some of this and the game will be a bit more fun.

OVERALL: Strong 8/10. Highly recommended. Worth a try at least sense it's free. =================================================================  Prior to the recent updates to refresh the game PlanetSide 2 was becoming increasing boring, repetative and it was difficult to play because anyone that wasn't a veteran player was basically just farming crops for the veterans. 'Veterans' as in those that have played the game long enough to know every little detail and advantage.  However the new updates have changed that with all sorts of new changes, from character, world and the new construction changes. Not going to give you a change log of the updates, so if you want further info on it just look on the official sites or forums.  Anyways, now the game is once again pretty fun again. Pretty much everything is properly balanced now and it's all fair. No more just being farm crops for the veterans. Items are still way over priced though, both with in-game credits and actual money - it's pretty ridiculous.  Experiences may vary. Don't go into this game expecting to have a K/D of 5.00 or something (competative outfits typically only have a minimum K/D of 0.5 so that kind of gives you an idea.) In this game you're nothing but a number, fighting along side squads, platoons and outfits is the only way to victory. You can go solo, but it's more for snipers and guerilla tactics. Outside of that you won't get too far solo. For new players this game is going to be extremely intimidating and you're going to die over and over again. Just find your playstyle and stick with it and soon you'll become a proper player. On average it probably takes a good week or two before you get comfortable. If you can rough it through that long you're in for a treat as this game is like none-other. Massive scale conflicts, teamwork, leadership, any vehicle you desire, passive playstyles or agressive. There's something here for everyone and everything contributes to victory. Unless you sit idle in a spawn room.  Factions really don't matter, A LOT of players join the faction which they most believe in rather than what they offer. Which is pretty awesome. A quick summary of the factions.  TR: Rapid fire, large clips, moderately in between good armor and agility, usually medium to long range.  NC: Slower fire (and tanks,) smaller clips, better damage and damage resistance, close ranged.  VS: No recoil (basically the CoD faction,) very agile and fast.  In the end though it's all balanced so it doesn't matter what side you choose. You may cry OP! But if you were on the other side you'd probably cry OP! As well. It's more about playing smart with teams than solo run and gun like in BF/CoD/most other shooters.

I have played this game off and on since it has come back and while after long times of playing I get bored and walk away I always come back. A game that every time I hop in I feel like I am making some difference in the battles in which I take part, a game where people from all walks of life come together in a war managing logistics, troop movement, battle tactics, grand strategy and have to actively out think other commanders. A game where individual skill can turn the tide of a battle and teamwork the tide of an alert (more or less a specified time for a war). A game where infantry battles rage, tank forces clash, and air wars rage mixed altogether in one beautiful picture. First a warning: this game requires a strong pc, otherwise the lag will be unreal.  Planetside 2 is one of my favorite fps games ever. One of the best shooters out there due to its large variety of gameplay and dynamic nature. Planetside's variety of combat roles allows players to experience multiple different aspects of combat from small scale skirmishes or sneaky flanking maneurvers up to massive 100 vs 100 soldier fights or large armor colums facing off each other in a persistant open world. Aside from your infantry classes, there are multiple combat vehicles and player base constructs that can be used. In one game session you can go from sniping, then flying in a jet plane, to building a base as a road block, switch to light assault to use your jet pack, and then bring a tank to destroy the enemy.

My PC isn't good enough to handle major fights on the main continents, so the current hours I've clocked were from the newbie zone. Being a small, six-zone island you'd be surprised to clock in a full day of playtime but Planetside 2 can be pretty addictive. This game is fun, hands down. You will also die a lot. Don't get frustrated, take your deaths as a learning experience and continue playing. Working with a team will help you out big time, as everyone working on the objectives together will succeed.  I feel the reason I like this game is it tops Battlefield in the sense that there is a limit to how many people can be in a server at one time on Battlefield. With Planetside 2 there is only one lobby (four if you count servers as lobbies, I don't) and if there is a limit, it's much higher than Battlefield's. When I do manage to get into a big fight it's glorious, like a real war with far more troops than 32 on either side.  Combat and gameplay tactics are taken a step further with three factions fighting each other instead of just two. This means that it isn't just a simple attack and defense between two teams, while you're going after one faction the other could be just as easily taking your bases on the other side of the map.  ----- I'll be upgrading my PC over the holidays so I can experience more content of Planetside that I haven't already. If I feel the need to update or continue this review I will, I know I missed some big points like guns, vehicles and outfits/squads, but as I said that's content I still need to fully experience. Happy gaming and I hope to see you guys in-game!

When i first started this game, i didn't have any FPS experience and had no idea about what was going on for most of the time. The Map was huge and everything was full of Symbols. Luckily i joined an Outfit so they could show me the way around. I won't try to explain the mechanics of this complex game in the review, but the core is to Capture Territory in huge Battles for your Faction (Terran Republic, New Conglomerate or Vanu Souvereignity) to lock one of the Four Continents (Indar, Esamir, Amerish, Hossin). Just Note that this War never ends: If you lock a Continent, another Continent will get unlocked again. The game will be very Confusing when you first start playing it, this is why i suggest new Players to join an Outfit. Just a side Note: Don't join the Outfit with the most Players but rather search for a mid sized Outfit (~200 Players). Jump on their Teamspeak and they will be happy to help you out and show you how the game is played! And my last tip to survive the first few hour of playing:  Prepare to die. Alot.  After that you will get hooked to the game, since there simply is no game around like this.

Pros: +Free to play,everybody can try it out +NOT pay to win,everything but cosmetics can be bought with in game currency (you can still buy weapons with real life money but most weapons are sidegrades,real upgrades that make your soldier ''better'' are only unlockable with certs which you gain by playing the game not paying) +Amazing graphics +Big variety of playstyles,with 6 different classes,3 different empires,ground and air vehicles,the ability to form squads/platoons/outfits and the construction system,everyone can play the way he/she(there are female players playing this game for some reason) wishes +Massive battles,with 4 ''continent'' sized maps which greatly differ from each other and thousand of players in each server,there are plenty of different situations you might find yourself in +Evolving battlefields,with the addition of the construction system some months ago,you might find yourself attacking,defending or even constructing a player made fortress which will probably greatly change the flow of battle +Great Community,unlike other f2p games,planetside's community is very mature and helpful.Even ''enemies'' fighting for other empires will gladly help you out if you have any question  Cons -Performance.CPUs hate this game,its like their eternal enemy for some reason -Slow start/bad new player experience.Even with recent changes to the ''new player experience'',being a ''newb'' in planetside 2 sucks. -NC pilots tend to allahu akbar you if they are about to lose a dogfight  9/10 VS RULES
